%newline%The Journal of Mormon History fosters scholarly research and publication in the field of Mormon history. Manuscripts dealing with all aspects of Mormon history are incorporated%comma% including twentieth-century history%comma% regional and local history%comma% women's history%comma% and ethnic/minorities history.

%newline%

%newline%Utah State University Press is a refereed scholarly publisher and division of Utah State University Libraries. Established in 1972%comma% the Press's mandate is to acquire and publish books of superior quality that win the esteem of readers and that appropriately represent our university to the community of scholars. Vital also to our mission is publication for a broader community%comma% including students%comma% who use our books in their studies%comma% and general readers%comma% who find in them enjoyment as well as enlightenment.

%newline%

column3: 1652.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection of oral histories portrays the lives of pioneers and early settlers in the closely-knit communities of Alpine%comma% Blue%comma% Nutrioso%comma% Eagar%comma% Springerville%comma% and Luna%comma% NM in the late 1800s and first half of the 1900s.

%newline%

column3: 1653.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Highlights of the Catholic Diocese of Tucson includes documents and letters from the time of Bishop Salpointe%comma% from the late 1860's to the mid 1880's. Most of the documents are written by or addressed to Bishop Salpointe himself. The collection also includes the first baptismal register from St. Augustine%comma% the mother church of the Diocese of Tucson%comma% from 1861-1878%comma% as well as an alphabetical index.

%newline%

column3: 1654.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Images collection consists of photographs of bishops and priests who served Catholics of Arizona from as early as the 1860s. Most of the earliest priests and bishops came from France through the recruitment of Archbishop Salpointe and Archbishop Lamy%comma% of Santa Fe. The collection includes some later priests%comma% those ordained in the 1920s and 1930s%comma% who%comma% like Rev. Msgr. Don Hughes%comma% were active in building and improving the Diocese as Arizona began to grow.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1655.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

David Swing (1864-1945) studied art under his father and Thomas Lindsey%comma% but began his career as a musician. He began to give violin concerts in 1884. He continued to play music in the orchestra of Theodore Thomas%comma% the Pasadena Municipal Band%comma% organizing and directing the Alhambra Municipal Band and Orchestra%comma% and to play violin and cello in the Phoenix Symphony Orchestra. From the start of his musical career until his move to Phoenix%comma% David Swing worked with lithograph firms and as president of an engraving firm. In Phoenix%comma% he eventually gave up his career as a musician to focus on painting desert life. Along with his Golden Gate International Exposition paintings%comma% Swing also painted for Masonic temples%comma% government hospitals and theaters. He continued painting until the end of his life.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1656.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

George Burr%comma% born in Monroe Falls%comma% Ohio in 1859%comma% began sketching and painting by the time he was 8. By age 11 he knew he wanted to be an artist. By 14 he experimented with etching. In 1877 he attended a business college in Oskaloosa%comma% IA and then 1878-79 studied at the Chicago Academy of Design.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1657.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Lon Megarge was born in Philadelphia in 1883. He changed the spelling of his last name to Megargee and the story of his past while he made his way westward into the Arizona Territory around 1896. Arizona became the 48th state on February 14th%comma% 1912. Megargee was commissioned by the state to paint fifteen large canvases which were installed in the State Capitol building. These paintings portray early Arizona%comma% encompassing landscapes%comma% natural wonders%comma% the customs of Native Americans%comma% historic buildings%comma% and the life of early settlers. The "Five Cs" of Arizona's economy (cattle%comma% citrus%comma% climate%comma% copper and cotton) are represented in many of these paintings. The original paintings are still displayed in the Arizona State Capitol today.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1658.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

In 1957 Arizona made plans to construct a new Capitol building. Believing that the submitted plans for the new Capitol were tombs to the past%comma% Frank Lloyd Wright offered an alternative to the people of Arizona. Wright felt that Arizona's Capitol should inspire the citizens to loftier heights. Wright's architectural dream of the Oasis captures the spirit of his vision - an oasis from the heat of the desert%comma% an oasis from the mediocrity of our past decisions%comma% an oasis for open government and unconstrained ideas. This collection also includes an early version of the Oasis with three spires%comma% a typewritten transcript where Wright expresses his opinions regarding the various plans for Arizona's Capitol Building%comma% and images of the restoration work completed by Kenneth C. Truong.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1659.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The USS Arizona became infamous on December 7th%comma% 1941 as the first U.S. battleship sunk during World War II. It continues to be in the forefront of American consciousness as a memorial to the servicemen who died during the war. The Arizona Capitol Museum is home to the silver service that was donated to the USS Arizona by the citizens of this state in 1919. This service is comprised of 59 distinct pieces on display at the Capitol Museum. Documents associated with the service are located in the Arizona State Archives.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1660.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Since February 1863%comma% when President Abraham Lincoln first recognized the Territory of Arizona as a protectorate of the United States of America%comma% mining has been the backbone of the Arizona economy. And for over a century%comma% the Arizona Geological Survey and its predecessors have collected and archived information on mines and mine activities in Arizona.

%newline%The Mines Collection of the Arizona Geological Survey contains information on thousands of Arizona mines -- only a select few are displayed here. All told%comma% the collection comprises more than 82 linear feet of files filled with old newspaper clippings%comma% accounts of mine histories%comma% geologic reports%comma% mineral assessments%comma% production reports%comma% historic letters inquiring of ore reserves and economic viability%comma% and to a lesser extent%comma% maps%comma% geologic cross-sections%comma% assay reports%comma% mine schematics%comma% and photographs. Most of the files were compiled between 1900 and 1960. These files shine a light into individual mines%comma% which%comma% when taken collectively%comma% illuminate the rich and diverse history of mining and miners in Arizona.

%newline%The earliest miners were prehistoric Native Americans who harvested outcrops of salt%comma% clays%comma% hematite%comma% quartz%comma% obsidian%comma% stone%comma% turquoise%comma% and coal. In the late 1600's%comma% Spanish explorers began the hunt for metallic deposits with especial focus on gold and silver. In 1854%comma% in Ajo%comma% Arizona%comma% the Arizona Mining and Trading Company launched the modern era of hard-rock mining.

%newline%A burgeoning mining industry fostered growth in the Arizona Territory%comma% and by 1864 nearly 25 percent of the male%comma% non-native populace was made up of prospectors. By the 1870's%comma% an uptick in hardrock mining yielded prodigious volumes of copper%comma% lead%comma% zinc%comma% silver and gold ore. In 1912%comma% the newly christened state of Arizona supported 445 active mines%comma% 72 concentrating facilities%comma% and 11 smelters
column7:
their gross value that year was nearly 67 million dollars -- equivalent to 1.4 billion dollars in 2006.

%newline%And here at the start of the 21st Century%comma% the important metallic commodities of Arizona --listed in order of decreasing value -- include copper%comma% gold%comma% silver%comma% molybdenum%comma% and lead. Important non-metallic (industrial) minerals -- listed in order of decreasing value -- include sand and gravel%comma% crushed stone%comma% clay%comma% cement%comma% gypsum%comma% lime%comma% perlite%comma% pumice%comma% and salt. Arizona's is world-famous for its turquoise%comma% peridot%comma% petrified wood%comma% and for striking%comma% copper-bearing minerals: turquoise%comma% azurite%comma% malachite. Energy resources of Arizona include coal and small quantities of petroleum and natural gas.

%newline%But copper is king! In 2007%comma% Arizona's copper mines produced more than 750%comma%000 tons of copper with a value of 5.5 billion dollars. Most of the copper mined in Arizona stems from porphyry-copper deposits%comma% which are associated with intrusive igneous rocks similar to granite. The term porphyry describes the typical texture of these rocks%comma% in which individual mineral grains%comma% from about one-tenth inch to a half-inch in size%comma% are fixed in a matrix of smaller grains that are barely visible to the naked eye. Other minerals common to copper porphyry deposits are molybdenum and silver.

%newline%

%newline%
column11: Calumet & Arizona Mining Company%comma% Bisbee%comma% Arizona

column3: 1661.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Spanning half a century%comma% this collection begins during the Arizona Territorial period and continues through the era of the polio epidemic%comma% the Korean War and the birth of television. The minutes of the Pima County Medical Society offer a detailed look into a broad range of medical%comma% social%comma% political and professional issues -- some of these at the local level and many at the national level. Any thorough study of the history of medicine in Arizona will benefit from a careful exploration of these documents.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1662.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Oral Histories of Gila County Ranchers captures 5-7 generations of stories from pioneers and early settlers in Arizona%comma% some arriving shortly after the Civil War. Not only did these families come early%comma% but they also remain in place%comma% or nearby%comma% to this very day. Their stories provide a unique and fluid account of how this segment of Arizona's culture has adapted to pressures and influences brought about by environmental and political events.

%newline%

column3: 1663.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Arizona Historical Foundation houses two collections pertaining to Arizona's two World War II Japanese Relocation Camps%comma% Gila River and Poston. Wade Head served as director of the Poston camp from 1942-1944%comma% and his collection focuses on the administration and documentation of camp life. Frances and Mary Montgomery were teachers at Butte High School%comma% located at the Gila River camp. The Montgomery collection contains student photographs and correspondence%comma% yearbooks%comma% and educational materials. This exhibition showcases original artwork%comma% documents and photographs that illustrate the dichotomy of these two collections while honoring the spirit and culture of their American subjects.

%newline%

column3: 1664.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Ruth Reinhold (1902-1985)%comma% an aviation pioneer%comma% was one of the first woman pilots in Arizona. She marked many milestones%comma% from barnstorming to teaching pilots to fly four-engine bombers during World War II. These images were selected from the 1200 photographs researched and collected for her book Sky Pioneering. It is a remarkable survey of aerial landscapes%comma% pilots%comma% aircraft%comma% airports%comma% landing fields%comma% and aviation events in Arizona dating from the early 1900s through the late 1970s.

%newline%

column3: 1665.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection represents the photographs created by members of the Arizona Photograph Company from 1894-1909. The photographer of each of the individual photographs is unknown. This is not a complete collection of the company's photographs. Other photographs can be found at the Sharlot Hall Museum in Prescott%comma% Arizona http://www.sharlot.org/. All photographs are 8"x10" gelatin silver glass plate negatives. The original condition of the plates varied from very poor and broken%comma% to very good with minimal scratches%comma% dirt and dust.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1666.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The women of the West were both saints and shady ladies. They did not and could not fit the Victorian models of womanhood. Those artificial standards were impossible to maintain in the newly settled West. It would be ridiculous to ride twenty miles only to leave a calling card%comma% and many of the other rules of conduct were equally inappropriate. While the spirit of gentility – care of family%comma% consideration of others%comma% and moral fiber – was present%comma% the outward appearances could not be kept; therefore%comma% none of these women could truly be considered "ladies." Instead they lived practically and industriously. Famous or "unsung heroines%comma%" their lives and works shaped the form and spirit of the state of Arizona.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1667.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Winnie Ruth McKinnell was born 1905 in Darlington%comma% Indiana%comma% the daughter of a Methodist minister. At the age of 19%comma% she married Dr. William C. Judd%comma% a man 22 years her senior. The couple moved frequently looking for work. Their travels took them all over the United States and Mexico before they settled in Los Angeles%comma% California. In 1930%comma% Winnie Ruth left Los Angeles and her husband for the dryer air of Phoenix. On Friday night%comma% October 16%comma% 1931%comma% Winnie Ruth went to her friends' apartment for dinner and drinks. What happened next became an enduring and sensationalized part of history.

%newline%

column3: 1668.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This exhibit is dedicated to Dorothy Webb whose family has been interwoven with the Arizona ranching industry since before Statehood. Her husband%comma% Bud (Milton D.) Webb%comma% served as President of the Arizona Cattle Growers Association. In 1983%comma% after Richard Schaus' death%comma% Dorothy organized and identified the photographs%comma% and created the extensive finding aid for the Schaus Collection. Soon after%comma% she also arranged for the transfer of the Arizona Cattle Growers Association papers to the Foundation%comma% and has donated significant additions to this collection since then. For decades she has been a good friend and unwavering supporter of the Foundation's activities and an outstanding champion for the preservation of Arizona's history.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1669.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Mexican Heritage Project was a groundbreaking effort at the Arizona Historical Society to help preserve and tell a story which was in danger of being forgotten or marginalized -- the story of Tucson's Mexican-American community from the Gadsden Purchase until World War II. From 1979-1983%comma% a group of dedicated scholars%comma% field historians%comma% archivists%comma% librarians and community members united in an effort to gather photographs and oral histories directly from Tucson's Mexican-American community. The project's founders recognized the urgency and importance of such a project since it was clear that due to population influx and resultant growth%comma% Tucson was changing rapidly. As descendants of pioneer Mexican families aged%comma% their photographs%comma% documents%comma% traditions and memories were in real danger of being lost and remaining forever absent from the historical record of Arizona. During its approximately five years of active collecting%comma% the Mexican Heritage Project sought to address this by collecting over 4%comma%000 historical photographs directly from community members%comma% all of which were catalogued and added to the permanent collection of the Arizona Historical Society Library and Archives in Tucson.

%newline%

This assortment of images was selected to share a broad sampling of the images collected as part of the Mexican Heritage Project. These photographs portray a wide range of subjects%comma% including formal studio portraits of individuals and groups%comma% street scenes%comma% parades%comma% wedding portraits%comma% interiors%comma% ranch scenes%comma% musical groups%comma% workers%comma% theatrical productions%comma% school class photos%comma% and casual family snapshots.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1670.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This Arizona Memory Project online exhibit%comma% created in conjunction with Geronimo! Revered and Reviled (The Man Behind the Legend)%comma% features images of Geronimo%comma% other Apache leaders%comma% U.S. military leaders and the Apache scouts who worked for the U.S. Cavalry. Also included are rare C.S. Fly images from the 1886 Canon de los Embudos negotiations to end hostilities%comma% an event that saw Geronimo and Gen. George Crook sitting down face to face to parley. Finally%comma% the exhibit also shows scenes of Apache imprisonment and exile%comma% images of artifacts including Geronimo's rifle%comma% and a copy of Geronimo's signature and maps.

%newline%

column3: 1671.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This Day In Arizona History charts some of the memorable moments in Arizona's history spanning the Territorial Days to the late 20th century. This Memory Project collection shows the breadth of history from the political to the personal%comma% noting the births and deaths of the famous and the infamous%comma% the building of key Arizona landmarks%comma% and the twists and turns of government%comma% the economy%comma% science and technology and society. The impact of Arizona's growth%comma% the Great Depression%comma% two World Wars and social revolutions in the mid-20th century can be seen throughout the collection. Also included are smaller (but just as telling) moments in history such as local dairy price wars%comma% the trial use of camels in the desert%comma% and Girl Scout cookie sales. The images corresponding to each day's event come from the more than 750%comma%000 images in the Arizona Historical Society's photographic collections.

%newline%

column3: 1672.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection of over 100 images of early Tucson and Southern Arizona pioneers is the result of a collaborative effort by the Arizona Historical Society%comma% the Arizona State Genealogical Society (ASGS) and the Afro-American Historical and Genealogical Society (AAHAS) Tucson Chapter. The three organizations teamed up for a Library Services Technology Act (LSTA) grant in 2008 to encourage collaboration between the institutions and to improve access to genealogical resources.

%newline%

column3: 1673.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Western Ways Features Company Photographs were selected from over 22%comma%000 photographic prints and negatives contained within the Western Ways Feature Manuscript and Photograph Collection%comma% ca. 1930-1970. The images include localities and landscapes throughout Arizona and Northern Mexico.

%newline%

column3: 1674.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection presents selections from an archive of over 50%comma%000 photographs depicting aspects of Jewish life in Arizona. Photographs in this collection were donated to the Arizona Jewish Historical Society by a variety of sources%comma% including photography studios%comma% newspapers%comma% local organizations%comma% and private donors. The Society is always interested in improving its archives. If you recognize an unidentified individual in one of our photographs%comma% or wish to share any information%comma% please send an email to azjhs@aol.com. Funding for this exhibit has been provided in part by grants from the Jewish Community Foundation of Greater Phoenix and the Arizona Historical Records Advisory Board.

%newline%

column3: 1675.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Arizona Adjutants General exhibit is comprised of photographs of Adjutants General in Arizona from territorial days to the present. An Adjutant General is the highest ranking officer of a state's militia or National Guard when it is not called into federal service. When called to federal service by order of the President for deployment in foreign wars or to support large scale civil disturbances%comma% the Guard personnel are answerable to the federal military chain of command all the way up to the President.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1676.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

With the Civil War still going on and Carleton still fighting the Navajos%comma% the U.S. War Department authorized Governor John Noble Goodwin of Arizona to raise five companies of Arizona Volunteers in 1864. Recruitment was delayed for a year%comma% but by the fall of 1865%comma% the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry of more than 350 men had been issued into service under the command of nine officers. According to the Third Arizona Territorial Legislature%comma% the volunteers inflicted "greater punishment on the Apaches than all other troops in the territory." After their year in service ended%comma% the War Department disbanded the Arizona Volunteers because the army did not have the authority to retain native recruits. The 1st Volunteer Infantry began the lineage of the future "Bushmasters."

%newline%

As a result of Pancho Villa and his men crossing the Mexican border and raiding Columbus%comma% New Mexico%comma% General "Black Jack" Pershing was ordered to lead a "punitive expedition" to apprehend and capture Villa and his bandits. The President called up the militias of Arizona%comma% New Mexico and Texas on May 9%comma% 1916. The Arizona militia%comma% the First Arizona Infantry%comma% was mustered in by May 19. Three weeks after the passage of the 1916 National Defense Act in late June%comma% the National Guard of all of the states (except Nevada which did not have a militia)%comma% and Alaska and the District of Columbia were called into Federal service. There were as many as 111%comma%954 guardsmen along the border at the end of August 1916. Douglas%comma% Arizona%comma% was one of the four assembly points for the guard units. The Arizona National Guard was called into active federal service with Col. Alexander McKenzie Tuthill as regimental commander. Besides units stationed at Naco%comma% there were elements at Ajo%comma% Nogales%comma% Fort Huachuca%comma% Douglas and other border outposts.

%newline%

Arizona's First Infantry Regiment was drafted into Federal Service for World War I on August 5%comma% 1917%comma% as part of the 40th Division. The Regiment was re-designated as the 158th Infantry Regiment on October 3%comma% 1917%comma% and sent overseas in July and August 1918. In France%comma% the 158th Infantry was assigned to a division that furnished replacement personnel to other units. The 158th Infantry was honored to act as guard of honor to President Wilson during his residence in France in 1918%comma% and the 158th Infantry Band was chosen as Wilson's honor band.

%newline%

On September 16%comma% 1940%comma% with the declaration of National Emergency%comma% the 158th Infantry joined its parent organization%comma% the 45th Division%comma% at Ft. Sill%comma% Oklahoma. The troops trained for five months%comma% moving to Camp Barkley at Abilene%comma% Texas%comma% on February 28%comma% 1941. Following the December 7%comma% 1941%comma% attack on Pearl Harbor%comma% the 158th Infantry Regiment was removed from the 45th Division becoming a separate Regiment. January 1942 found the Regiment embarking at the Port of New Orleans and disembarking in the Panama Canal Zone.

%newline%

In Panama%comma% they trained in jungle warfare. Becoming famous for newly acquired jungle-fighting skills%comma% the Regiment took the name of the Bushmasters after the deadly bushmaster snake%comma% which became the distinguishing shoulder patch of the fighting 158th Regimental Combat Team. The name "Bushmasters" became well-known through the nation's press.

%newline%

General Douglas MacArthur personally requested that the Bushmasters be sent to his command in the Southwest Pacific Theater. They were on their way to Australia by January 2%comma% 1943%comma% landing two weeks later at Brisbane%comma% Queensland. When General Walter Krueger's headquarters moved to Milne Bay and on to Goodenough Island%comma% the 2nd Battalion%comma% 158th Infantry became the security force for his headquarters. On Christmas Day 1943%comma% Safford's Company G embarked for Arawe. It was there that the 158th Infantry had its "baptism of fire." A short time later the remainder of the 2nd Battalion arrived under command of LTC Frederick R. Stofft of Tucson%comma% Arizona. After the landing on Wakde-Sarmi in Dutch New Guinea they fought the Japanese 6th Tiger Marine Division from May 17 to June 12%comma% 1944. The Regiment traded 77 officers and men for 3000 of the enemy. They were relieved on 12 June by the 6th Infantry Division (which spoke well for the regiment as it took an entire division to replace them). With only a brief rest on the morning of 2 July%comma% the Regiment went ashore at Noemfoor with the mission to destroy the enemy and construct an airstrip that would handle B-29 bombers. Fifteen days later the mission was accomplished and General MacArthur landed on the newly constructed B-29 airdrome.

%newline%

It was at the battle at Lingayen Gulf%comma% where the Japanese invaded the Philippines 3 years earlier%comma% where Co G from Safford%comma% Arizona was awarded the Presidential Unit Citation for their action in capturing the 14-inch coast gun which was bringing heavy fire on the invasion force. By the end of the operation on January 27%comma% 100 Japanese field pieces had been captured or destroyed. General MacArthur "had returned."

%newline%

On April 1%comma% Easter Sunday 1945%comma% the 158th Infantry invaded the Bicol Peninsula in southern Luzon. The Regiment hit the Legaspi Port in a magnificent assault landing with naval landing craft.

%newline%

General MacArthur summarized about the Bushmasters: "No greater fighting combat team has ever deployed for battle." After being relieved by divisions in campaign after campaign across the Pacific%comma% the 158th Infantry was selected to spearhead the final invasion of Japan. The Bushmasters were under orders to proceed two days ahead of America's crushing D-Day%comma% to silence Japanese air warning stations south of Kyushu. Timely capitulation of Japan saved the 158th Infantry from what many believed would have been a certain suicide mission. On October 13%comma% 1945%comma% the 158th Infantry landed in Yokohama%comma% Japan. The great odyssey was over. FROM ARIZONA TO JAPAN - IN FIVE YEARS! Members were then shipped home and the 158th was deactivated at Utsunomiya%comma% Japan on January 17%comma% 1946.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1677.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The Arizona Military Museum%comma% an Arizona Centennial Legacy Project%comma% is operated by a Historical Society whose purposes are: "To enhance the appreciation of the military history of Arizona and the contributions of the Militia of Arizona and the Arizona National Guard to the State of Arizona and to the Nation…" and "…to discover and memorialize the history of the Military of Arizona%comma% the Arizona National Guard%comma% and the general military history of Arizona%comma% and to establish and maintain a museum on land leased%comma% owned%comma% or otherwise controlled by the Society." It also portrays events%comma% persons%comma% and other historical information relating to…the military service of Arizonans in wars and other military actions in Arizona and around the world. The Arizona Military Museum is an Army Museum Activity under Army and National Guard regulations. It is located within the "old Arsenal Building" which also houses the Arizona Regional Training Institute within the confines of the Papago Park Military Reservation. Descriptive text accompanying digital objects is a result of the research done by%comma% and conclusions of Joseph Abodeely%comma% President of the Arizona National Guard Historical Society and Director of the Arizona Military Museum.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1678.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)

%newline%

Arizona Archives Historic Photographs focus upon the unique cultural heritage of the state and territory of Arizona%comma% beginning in 1863. The collection includes about 90%comma%000 images%comma% including photographs%comma% slides%comma% negatives%comma% glass plate negatives%comma% tintypes%comma% transparencies%comma% postcards and others.

%newline%

column3: 1679.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Attorney General Opinions (1892 to current%comma% in process) are issued when requested by either house of the State Legislature%comma% any public officer of the State%comma% or a county attorney%comma% on a question of law relating to their office. The Attorney General's office does not issue opinions for private citizens%comma% nor does it offer legal advice to private citizens.

%newline%

The first two digits of each opinion indicate the year the opinion was issued (I99 indicates the year the opinion was issued in 1999)%comma% and the next three digits indicate the order in which the opinion was issued. For example%comma% I99-003 is the third opinion issued in 1999. The number in parentheses (e.g.%comma% R98-025) refers to the year and request order for an opinion. Opinions and letters before 1937 are identified by a date (e.g.. 1892-JUL-31) rather than by opinion number. Certain opinions%comma% such as opinions ending with an "L" (e.g.%comma% 63-1-L) were written as "letter" opinions while opinions ending with "ESC" (e.g.%comma% 53-1-ESC) were written to the Employment Security Commission.

%newline%

Legal custody of pre-1937 Attorney General Opinions resides with History and Archives of Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records. Legal custody of Attorney General Opinions from 1937 to the present resides with the Attorney General's office. Opinions and letters from 1937-1998 were microfilmed in the condition they were received from the Attorney General's Office and saved in PDF format by Records Management of Arizona State Library Archives and Public Records. Attorney General Opinions from 1999 to present were downloaded from the Attorney General's office website. Attorney General's opinion from 2005 to present may be found on the Attorney General's website. Opinions found prior to 2005 may be found in this collection. Opinions of the Attorney General are advisory only.

%newline%

%newline%

The Arizona County and Local Publications collection has been contributed by the Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records' Law and Research Library. Digital publications produced by and for Arizona counties and cities are available from this collection%comma% which is updated on a continuing basis.

Also included are a few reports that were not published for or by a state agency. These were received from the Legislature for inclusion in the collection.

Government records protect the right of citizens%comma% promote accountability for government officials%comma% and provide continuity. Records in the Arizona State Archives were created by individuals or agencies within state or local government organizations. Agency records include those from boards%comma% commissions and departments%comma% as well as executive%comma% legislative and judicial branches. They date from 1863 to the early 1990s. Local records include those from county and city governments and date from 1863 to the 1940s.

The manuscript collections at the Arizona State Archives contain information relating to the history%comma% culture and businesses in Arizona. They document everyday life from territorial times forward.

The Arizona Women's Hall of Fame Exhibit displays custom quilts of the inductees. These quilts have been created by the Arizona Quilters Guild for the past twenty-five years and include all inductees since 2006. The exhibit is housed at the Carnegie Center%comma% a part of the Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records%comma% and is open to the public%comma% state agencies and nonprofit organizations.

Federal publications are printed by the authority of Congress or by executive or judicial agencies at taxpayer expense and are distributed to federal agencies%comma% their clientele%comma% and to depository libraries which serve the public. The Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records' Law and Research Division is the Regional Federal Depository Library for Arizona designated to receive U.S. Government Printing Office (GPO) publications distributed through the Federal Depository Library Program. This collection includes notable statistics%comma% research%comma% and reports issued by the GPO on all aspects of the state as well as federal "fugitive documents" featuring Arizona. Ultimately%comma% the Arizona-Related Federal Publications collection will be a comprehensive resource for publications relating to Arizona and her people issued in digital form by the federal government.

This collection of historic Arizona county maps includes maps of each Arizona county%comma% dating from the late 1880s to 1937. Most of the late 1880s to early 1920s maps were produced by the County Engineer or County Surveyor and published by the county Board of Supervisors. Some of the maps appear to be commercially published and a few have no publication information.

Welcome to the Maricopa County Land Ownership plat map collection. Years covered are 1903%comma% 1911%comma% 1914%comma% 1917%comma% 1923%comma% 1926 and 1929. Each map sheet depicts one township and range and shows land owners as well as railroads%comma% canals%comma% dams%comma% some major roads along section lines%comma% mountain peaks%comma% and selected surface mining claims in the mountains north of Phoenix.

column3: 1690.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

On January 20%comma% 1988%comma% the Arizona House of Representatives began hearings on Governor Evan Mecham's alleged illegal activities and on February 8 voted to impeach him. The impeachment trial commenced in the Arizona State Senate%comma% with the Senate acting as the Court of Impeachment%comma% on February 29%comma% 1988%comma% and ended on April 8 with Mecham's conviction and subsequent impeachment for obstruction of justice and misuse of government funds. The Senate failed to muster the votes necessary to bar the ex-governor from holding elected office in the future%comma% and thus the next several years saw his failed attempts to retake the governorship and win a U.S. Senate seat.

%newline%

There are approximately 5%comma%450 pages of transcripts combined into 26 volumes/PDFs representing each of the 26 days of the hearings. Video of the hearings was originally captured on 2" Quadruplex video tapes by KAET. The original tapes were transferred to U-matic tapes and then to VHS tapes. KAET transferred the original Quadruplex tapes%comma% 1 set of U-matic tapes%comma% and two sets of the VHS tapes to the Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records. Digital copies of the U-matic tapes were created in 2011 by the Arizona State Archives for preservation and continued access. Due to licensing agreement with KAET and other members of the Broadcast Pool Committee%comma% the digital videos are available for viewing at the Arizona State Archives by request only.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1691.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

From 1946 to 1960%comma% in the remote pine country of east-central Arizona%comma% the University of Arizona's Department of Anthropology%comma% under the direction of Dr. Emil W. Haury%comma% operated one of the first archaeological field schools in the nation where hundreds of students were trained in archaeological field work. The school was called the Point of Pines Field School because it was situated and surrounded by significant Mogollon pueblo ruins%comma% the largest being Point of Pines Pueblo. This collection of 39 images from the Arizona State Museum's Photograph Collection documents the daily life of the camp and the early archaeological processes used in their site excavations. Most of the photos presented here were taken during the 1946-1956 period.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1692.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%This exhibit of twenty-seven Forman Hanna photographs from the Arizona State Museum's collection showcases the tradition of pictorial photography as practiced in the early twentieth century by photographers in the American West. Native Americans%comma% cowboys and scenic landscapes were some of Forman Hanna's favorite subjects.

%newline%Hanna came to Arizona in 1904 and through a friend found a position as a pharmacist in Globe%comma% Arizona. Globe's proximity to the native people and landscapes that Hanna wanted to photograph kept him there for the remainder of his life%comma% although he traveled widely in Arizona%comma% New Mexico%comma% Utah and Texas.

%newline%Hanna's photographs of Apache%comma% Navajo%comma% Hopi and Acoma Indians%comma% as presented here%comma% are set in their villages and surroundings and document their ways of life and the native architecture of the early to mid 1900s. Many of his photographs of native peoples were candid shots where he sought to capture aspects of quotidian Native American life. This demonstrates his desire to preserve the way of life of these Native peoples as well as how interesting he found their lifestyles.

%newline%Hanna also documented the cowboy lifestyle%comma% as he feared it would soon disappear altogether. Cattle drives%comma% horsemanship and the picturesque attire of the cowboys were aspects of the cowboy of the early 20th century that Hanna strived to preserve through his photographs.

%newline%Hanna found the landscape of the Southwest fascinating. Unique rock formations made by wind and water erosion%comma% canyon walls and desert vegetation were transformed into people and human-made objects though Hanna's lens. For Hanna%comma% photography was a means of sharing the wonders of the people and landscape around him. He wanted those who viewed his photographs to share in the pleasure he felt when he took them.

%newline%At one stage in his life Hanna photographed nudes in a small canyon near Globe. His subjects were local girls and women ranging from 5 to 25 years old. He was surprised by how professional they were as models%comma% holding any pose he requested for extended periods of time.

%newline%Hanna's photographs are in numerous museum collections in the United States%comma% including the Brooklyn Museum%comma% the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry%comma% the Los Angeles Museum%comma% and the Smithsonian Institution. Photographs at the Arizona State Museum were generously donated by the late Mrs. Josephine Hanna.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1693.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

On June 2 through 6%comma% 1980%comma% Helga Teiwes visited Hickiwan Village%comma% Tohono O'odham Indian Reservation%comma% Arizona. It was there that she documented Rupert Angea creating several polychrome pots. The process was documented from the gathering of supplies for the actual pot to the gathering of the materials for the creation of the paint. The polychrome pots that were created were donated to the Arizona State Museum.

%newline%

column3: 1694.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Medallion Papers is a series of 39 publications issued between 1928-1950 by the Gila Pueblo Archaeological Foundation. Gila Pueblo%comma% as it later became known%comma% was one of the earliest Arizona institutions doing archaeological surveying and research in the Southwest. It was founded by Winifred and Harold S. Gladwin as a private foundation and employed professional archaeologists whose research was published in the Medallion Papers. Their work was instrumental in defining the Hohokam%comma% Mogollon%comma% San Simon and Cochise cultures and in describing early pottery types including Hohokam red-on-buff%comma% Salado polychrome%comma% Casas Grandes and others.

%newline%

Gila Pueblo was located in east-central Arizona%comma% several miles south of Globe%comma% Arizona. It was in operation until 1950%comma% at which time the Foundation was dissolved. The buildings were acquired by the National Park Service and became the Southwest Archaeological Center from 1950 to 1971. They are now occupied by the Gila Community College (formally the Globe Campus/Eastern Arizona College). The Foundation's artifacts%comma% photographs%comma% library and documents were donated to the Arizona State Museum%comma% University of Arizona.

%newline%

Distinguished archaeologists published in the Medallion Papers include Charles Avery Amsden%comma% Ernst Antevs%comma% Alice M. Brues%comma% Nora Gladwin%comma% Winifred and Harold Gladwin%comma% Emil W. Haury%comma% Fred Hawley%comma% M. M. Leighton%comma% Deric O'Bryan%comma% E. B. Sayles%comma% George C. Vaillant%comma% and George and Edna Woodbury.

%newline%

The Medallion Papers are digitally presented in the Arizona Memory Project in their full text. The original issues Nos. 1-3 carry the imprint "Privately printed for the Medallion%comma% Pasadena%comma% California%comma%" while issues Nos. 4-39 have the imprint "Gila Pueblo%comma% Globe%comma% Arizona." The earliest issues were not published with authors or numbering and it wasn't until they became more widely distributed that adhesive labels were prepared with this information. All print work was done by Lancaster Press%comma% Inc.%comma% Lancaster%comma% Pennsylvania. Each volume was beautifully crafted on heavy cream-colored paper stock and most issues included color plates and line art. Covers displayed a design taken from a Querino polychrome bowl as the Medallion Papers colophon. The original format was 6 5/8 by 9 3/ 4 inches until issue No. 25%comma% at which time the format changed to 8 1/2 by 11 1/8 inches. Issue No. 25%comma% Excavations at Snaketown: Material Culture%comma% which was originally printed in 1937%comma% was later reprinted in 1965 by the University of Arizona Press%comma% which retains its distribution rights.

%newline%

Also presented here are the Amsden Pottery Paintings%comma% a collection of 18 oil paintings commissioned by the Gila Pueblo Archaeological Foundation for use as illustrations in the Medallion Papers. The paintings were executed by Theodore ("Ted") Price Amsden between 1929 and 1936. The images of the paintings are presented in the order in which they appear in the Medallion Papers.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1695.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The A.P. Miller Photograph Collection was donated to the Arizona State Museum by Dr. Lorraine M. Sherer in 1979. A.P. Miller%comma% a railroad engineer from Needles%comma% CA%comma% was also an avid photographer whose favorite subjects included the Mojave Desert%comma% locomotives%comma% and the Hualapai and Mojave peoples. This selection of 25 photographs of locomotives was taken in California from 1938-1942. A.P. Miller died in 1944.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1696.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Rosamond Spicer (1913-1999) received a bachelor's degree in archaeology from Northwestern University in 1934 and a Master's degree in anthropology from the University of Chicago in 1938. She lived on the Tohono O'odham Reservation%comma% previously known as the Papago Reservation%comma% from October%comma% 1942%comma% to July%comma% 1943. The photos were taken as part of the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) and the University of Chicago Committee on Human Development Indian Education and Research Project. The results of this project were discussed in The Desert People%comma% written by Spicer%comma% Alice Joseph%comma% and Jane Chesky.

%newline%

The majority of the photos were taken by Rosamond in Topawa%comma% Arizona%comma% where Rosamond lived in the Feast House with her young son Barry. The photos are a mix of representations of everyday life on the reservation and special events such as Rodeo and religious processions. Descriptions of the photos come from an index typed up by Rosamond Spicer in 1994%comma% information she wrote on the back of prints%comma% and from Tohono O'odham members. Most dates%comma% photographers%comma% and names of subjects are listed%comma% but some are unknown. In addition to her time spent on the reservation in the early 1940s%comma% Spicer visited again in the 1950s and 1960s%comma% and continued to gather photos of the Tohono O'odham taken by others.

%newline%

According to The Desert People%comma% the Tohono O'odham reservation held about 5%comma%900 residents at the time of the study. Populations ranged from anywhere to 1%comma%200 in the Sells district to 250 in the Gu Vo district. An additional 200 lived in the Gila Bend reservation%comma% and almost 500 at the San Xavier reservation. The remaining of the almost 7%comma%000 strong population lived off-reservation. At the time Rosamond was living on the reservation%comma% many families still worked as farmers and ranchers%comma% and two villages still migrated annually from the fields to the foothills. However%comma% more and more were finding off reservation work in mines or on nearby farms%comma% or they found government employment. Most followed Roman or Sonoran Catholicism%comma% but the Presbyterian Church had a strong following as well. Schools were typically run by the BIA or Catholics. However%comma% there were no secondary schools on the reservation. Only government or Catholic boarding schools off reservation were available for higher education. English was taught in schools%comma% but it was not the predominate language on the reservation at this point%comma% with only a third of adults able to speak it. Sells%comma% as now%comma% was the seat of the government in the early 1940s. The tribal council was in charge of arts and crafts%comma% the tribal fair and rodeo%comma% loans%comma% the tribal herd%comma% and administering tribal law. However%comma% at this time the Tohono O'odham still were not allowed to vote%comma% and they did not own the rights to the minerals under their land.

%newline%

column3: 1697.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%This collection highlights select images from the Gila River Akimel O'odham%comma% San Carlos Apache%comma% and White Mountain Apache basket making process%comma% as photographed by Helga Teiwes.

%newline%On April 12%comma% 1973%comma% Helga Teiwes visited the Gila River Indian Reservation%comma% near Bapchule%comma% Arizona%comma% to document Julia Francisco's basket making processes. She photographed the gathering%comma% cleaning%comma% drying%comma% and stripping of basket making supplies%comma% such as willow%comma% devil's claw%comma% and martynia%comma% as well as the creation of a woven basket depicting a squash blossom design. Helga later returned on August 17%comma% 1973%comma% to observe the Cattail Harvest at Stanfield Ditch%comma% where she documented Julia Francisco cutting and collecting cattail%comma% a plant commonly used in her basket making.

%newline%In May 1984%comma% Helga photographed various basket making processes of the Apache culture of Whiteriver and San Carlos. During this trip%comma% she photographed the gathering locations where common plant materials are collected for use in basket making. She also documented Joanna Taylor cutting and collecting willow for use in basket weaving and Viola Taylor preparing materials and intricately weaving willow baskets.

%newline%On the same trip%comma% she highlighted the basketry of Cecilia Henry from Peridot%comma% Arizona and Minnie Narcisco%comma% from Cibecue%comma% Arizona%comma% who proudly display their burden baskets.

%newline%

column3: 1698.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Arizona State University's early research scientists were scholarly pioneers of earth%comma% ice%comma% animal%comma% mineral%comma% and space. In Arizona State's first days of transformation from a small college to a true university%comma% these scientists were already leaders in their fields%comma% asking tough questions and seeking elusive answers. Their work at ASU helped others to understand venomous animals%comma% meteorites%comma% genetics%comma% rare earth oxides%comma% frozen deserts%comma% and local geology.

%newline%

This exhibit was developed from the University Archives of Arizona State University Libraries. It features the documents%comma% notebooks%comma% images%comma% specimens%comma% and equipment of ASU researchers including Dr. Herb Stahnke of the Department of Biology%comma% Dr. Carleton Moore and H. H. Nininger of the Center for Meteorite Studies%comma% Dr. Charles Woolf of the Zoology Department%comma% Dr. LeRoy Eyring of the Eyring Center for Solid State Science%comma% and Dr. Troy Péwé of the Department of Geology.

%newline%

column3: 1699.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The John J. Rhodes Papers consist of correspondence%comma% reports%comma% financial and travel records and printed matter. The collection documents Rhodes' congressional career from 1953 1983 and significant portions of the collection concern the Central Arizona Project%comma% Indians%comma% water%comma% campaign activities%comma% legislation sponsored by Rhodes%comma% energy policy%comma% Watergate%comma% and the Barry Goldwater presidential campaign. The collection has been divided into eighteen series. The first fifteen series concern each of the US Congresses from 1953 1983. The final three series are Central Arizona Project%comma% Campaign Files and Miscellaneous Files.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1700.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The photographs of the Franciscan%comma% Augustine Schwarz%comma% O.F.M.%comma% were donated to the Anthropology Department at Arizona State University by a niece%comma% Elizabeth M. Jones%comma% in 1986%comma% and transferred to the Labriola National American Indian Data Center%comma% University Libraries%comma% Arizona State University%comma% in June of 2000. This collection reconstructs the thirty years of Father Augustine's service to his Church through his photographs. It contains 163 photographs taken between 1916 and 1940 documenting Franciscan chapels%comma% missions and religious activities at numerous American Indian villages in Arizona.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1701.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Powwow Photographs by Ann Leonard collection consists of 69 color digital photographs by Arizona State University's Labriola National American Indian Data Center's Library Aide%comma% Ann Leonard. Leonard documented the Tohono O'odham's Wa:K Pow Wow%comma% held at Tucson's San Xavier del Bac Mission in March of 2008. The images feature multiple dance competitions%comma% including shots of Fancy%comma% Grass%comma% Southern Straight%comma% Jingle%comma% and Shawl dancers. The images were displayed at Labriola Center during the Spring and Summer of 2008%comma% and at ASU's Discovery Hall in Fall 2008.

%newline%

column3: 1702.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Why Arizona? is an online collection of materials describing the history of migration to%comma% from and within Arizona. Materials are derived from special collections of Arizona State University%comma% the University of Arizona and Northern Arizona University. Why Arizona? appears with the generous support of Institute of Museum and Library Services funds distributed by the Arizona State Library Archives and Public Records%comma% and it is designated an official Arizona Centennial Legacy Project by the Arizona Historical Advisory Commission.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1703.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

In May 2011%comma% eleven CAMA museums joined the International Museum Day (IMD) celebration by offering free or reduced admissions%comma% museum store discounts%comma% and special performances. In solidarity with the 2011 IMD theme "Museum and Memory%comma%" CAMA collaborated with the Arizona Memory Project to produce a new collection of photographs%comma% documents%comma% and videos submitted by CAMA member institutions.

%newline%

column3: 1704.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection documents the growth%comma% activities and history of the Sonoran Desert Foothills spanning the time period of the 1870s to the 1920s. Within this time span military operations%comma% mining activity%comma% sheep herding%comma% pioneering and dude ranches have had a part at shaping the foothills area that brings us to our present day western flair town site offering small town hospitality. This collection of still images and documents also records the oldest original tubercular cabin in the state of Arizona -- and the last of its era.

%newline%

column3: 1705.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

In celebration of Glendale's approaching 100-year anniversary%comma% this collection of City Council minutes dating from August 1st%comma% 1910 to December 28th%comma% 1914 has been compiled electronically for the first time. Minutes include roll calls of council members in attendance%comma% agreements made with organizations outside of the city%comma% calls of election and the canvassing of votes%comma% and the adoption of ordinances and resolutions into law.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1706.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The theme of this collection is the unique history and culture of Southeastern Arizona. The centerpiece of the collection is a video created by the Cochise College Library media department that documents an archaeological dig site from the era. The dig site is located at Murray Springs in Cochise. The rest of the collection progresses through history to modern times and includes images%comma% audio files (oral histories)%comma% and text documents of historical and cultural significance to this fascinating Borderlands region.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1707.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection presents a brief introduction to the rock art of Cochise County%comma% Arizona. A wide diversity of prehistoric and historic rock art is found in the county including petroglyphs and pictographs. Petroglyphs are carved rock designs and pictographs are painted rock designs. Rock art is much more than meaningless sketches. It is a visual record from the past of various concepts%comma% such as ceremony%comma% religion%comma% life style and art. Five different cultures are represented in the collection images
column7:
Apache%comma% Hohokam%comma% Mimbres and Mogollon. Rock art is being threatened by natural deterioration%comma% vandalism and development. This collection is Cochise College Libraries effort toward its preservation.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1708.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

In February%comma% 2006 this small collection of original court documents was discovered in a locked room containing primarily court clerk exhibits in what used to be the old Cochise County Jail in Bisbee. At this time the location of the remainder of the vast collection of original Bisbee Deportation court documents is unknown although much of it had been microfilmed forty years ago.

%newline%

column3: 1709.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)

%newline%

In May of 1881%comma% just three months after Cochise County was formed out of southeastern Pima County%comma% district court sessions began in Tombstone%comma% Arizona. The 652 page collection contains brief notations by the district court clerk of matters and proceedings taken up by the judge – in the order they were presented. Aficionados of Cochise County Territorial history will enjoy "seeing" the characters of the day make their appearance in court – and getting a sense of the cadence of court business procedures from a time long past.

%newline%

%newline%

The first submission to this collection is the recently rediscovered Coroner's Inquest of the October 26%comma% 1881 incident commonly referred to as "The Gunfight at the OK Corral." On March 31%comma% 2010%comma% while reorganizing a records storage area in the old county jail%comma% two deputy clerks discovered these long-missing documents. The OK Corral documents section of this collection includes typewritten versions created in the 1960s by deputy clerks. While there are a few errors in these transcriptions%comma% they can be of help in deciphering the handwritten originals.

The Cochise County Treasurer is the fiscal custodian of the County and is responsible for the administration and control of cash and securities. The duties involved in this responsibility include tax administration
column7: receipt%comma% deposit and disbursement of cash
column11:
debt management of bond issues%comma% lines of credit and registered warrants. The County Treasurer plays a crucial role in county government administration.

This collection of photos depicts the work and lives of the men of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) at Colossal Cave in Vail%comma% AZ%comma% 1934-1937. The CCC was a federal government program designed to conserve our country's natural resources and to provide jobs and training to young%comma% unmarried men. The men of the CCC made improvements inside Colossal Cave%comma% constructed buildings%comma% and built picnic areas under the supervision of State Park Service personnel. They lived in a camp supervised by U.S. Army personnel%comma% where they engaged in educational%comma% sports%comma% and recreational activities.

%newline%

column3: 1713.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Hedgpeth Hills face east%comma% towards the rising sun. At one time%comma% the hills were next to a flowing creek that supported communities of people%comma% plants and animals. Archaic%comma% Hohokam%comma% and Patayan peoples passed through the area and left their mark by pecking over 1%comma%500 symbols into the basalt boulders. We do not know the reason they left the petroglyphs%comma% or what story the markings tell. However%comma% we do know that each generation plays a role in changing the land by communicating their traditions. Today%comma% the Deer Valley Rock Art Center protects the Hedgpeth Hills petroglyph site and offers an opportunity for interpretation and appreciation of cultural expressions.

%newline%

%newline%

The Flagstaff City Directories cover Flagstaff from the years of 1929 to 1986 (some years are missing). They present a slice of life at that time%comma% including a brief history of Flagstaff and demographics%comma% local attractions%comma% clubs and organizations. They correlate with a Street and Avenue Guide covering what business or residence is located at each address. In addition to providing phone number and street addresses for residents%comma% these unique directories can also provide marital%comma% career%comma% and educational status.

In the early 1960s%comma% ten young Asian-American women joined together to develop friendships and organized to provide community service as the Desert Jade Junior Woman's Club in Phoenix%comma% Arizona. Within a year%comma% club membership grew to 20. Today%comma% with removal of the age limitation of 35 years for junior club membership%comma% the group is known as the GFWC Desert Jade Woman' s Club. The many philanthropic and civic projects of the group have included donations of time%comma% money%comma% and energy to various local fire departments%comma% veteran's groups%comma% community%comma% service%comma% and family organizations. The Phoenix Art Museum as well as St. Vincent De Paul are just two of the many organizations who have benefitted from the club's efforts. From its inception%comma% members of the Desert Jade Woman's Club have felt the need to give back to the community in which they lived. This collection represents barely a glimpse of the past 50 years in which the club has played its part in the history of the state of Arizona.

Oral Histories of Gila County is a compilation of interviews commemorating Arizona's first 100 years of Statehood. It was made possible by partial funding by an Arizona State Library LSTA Grant. The oral historian%comma% Joyce McBride%comma% began interviewing in September 2007%comma% choosing Gila County because it uniquely represents every aspect of Arizona's culturally diverse history.

The Phoenix Girl Scouts were formed into the Maricopa Girl Scout Council in 1936. By 1968%comma% the 50th Anniversary of Girl Scouting in Arizona%comma% the Maricopa Girl Scout Council had grown into the Arizona Cactus-Pine Council (GS - ACPC) and covered the northern 2/3 of the state. In 1988%comma% Dorothy Canfield Foster compiled a history of the GS - ACPC%comma% relying on the artifacts and memory of Jean Clark%comma% leader of Girl Scout Troop 1 for 50 years. Barbara Anderson%comma% a Council staff member%comma% was inspired by this history and later used it as a foundation for creating the Historical Society after her retirement in 1985.

This collection of photographs and materials represents the founding and initial construction of Glendale Community College at 59th and Olive Avenues in Glendale%comma% AZ. The historic collection dates from initial planning (the founding of the Maricopa County Community College District in 1962 and subsequent expansion from the original Phoenix College) through the 1967 commencement%comma% the first at the new northwest college site. Materials have been selected to present a varied record of the early college years and include architectural renderings%comma% aerial views of the site%comma% construction photographs%comma% images of college life%comma% and comments extracted from early college yearbooks and the student newspaper.

This collection represents South 1st Avenue%comma% now 58th Drive and Glendale Avenue%comma% from around 1910 to 1950. It depicts early development in downtown Glendale%comma% Arizona. The collection also includes photos of the Sine Family%comma% a pioneering family to Glendale%comma% who were instrumental in the development of downtown Glendale. Most of the photos were collected by pioneering Glendale citizens and given to the Glendale Arizona Historical Society. The pictures depicting the Sine Family and their businesses were donated to the Society by Arthur Sine.

In 1937 a $6%comma%000 bond issue and a Public Works Administration grant from the government enabled the city to construct a $12%comma%000 library building in 1938. The 2%comma%200 sq. ft. building would serve a population of 3%comma%500. The Spanish-style mission library was located in the center of Murphy Park. It was built in the form of a "T"%comma% with an arched entrance in the center which led to the reading rooms. It was considered one of the most attractive buildings in the city.

Listening to Glendale's Past is a collection of oral and video histories%comma% most with transcripts%comma% of people connected with Glendale in a myriad of ways%comma% reliving life from the early 1900s to the present. These histories are presented in a series of sub-collections divided by the organizations that collected them.

Old Morenci and Metcalf mining townsites were located on the eastern border of Arizona from 1870 - 1984. Morenci was known as "Joy Camp"%comma% (named after Captain Miles Joy). In 1882%comma% "Joy Camp" was renamed "Morenci" by William Church%comma% head of the Detroit Copper Company. Metcalf was named after Robert and James Metcalf%comma% two pioneer copper miners. Through 1932 all mining was underground. Open pit mining began in 1937. The town was completely gone by 1983. New Morenci is now located where Plantsite was situated. Both old Morenci and Metcalf are now completely engulfed by the open pit.

%newline%

column3: 1725.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection is a collaboration between Jerome Historical Society and the Postal History Foundation. It includes photographs%comma% postal documents%comma% postcards%comma% postmarks%comma% and covers or cachets%comma% which are envelopes with special illustrations on them. Like many other towns in Arizona%comma% the postal history of Jerome closely reflects the boom and bust of the mining industry. As the mining operations grew and the population soared%comma% the post office also was established and expanded. Later%comma% as fires swept through the town on multiple occasions%comma% the post office also suffered. Then when the use of dynamite increased%comma% the entire town began to shift and the post office collapsed in slides that affected much of the town. But the post office also demonstrated the strength of the community. In the 1970s when it was threatened with closure%comma% a group of citizens gathered to protest. Although the population had dwindled to a handful at that point%comma% the inhabitants recognized that their survival as a town was closely linked to the survival of the post office. At its height%comma% the population of Jerome was close to 15%comma%000 and today it is 400 (with an annual visitation reportedly at close to one million people).

%newline%

%newline%

This collection of photographs%comma% 1890's through the 1940's%comma% provide a snapshot of the role transportation systems and vehicles played in the development of Mohave County. Subjects presented are: horses%comma% mules%comma% burros%comma% railroads%comma% stagecoaches%comma% freight wagons%comma% trucks%comma% buses%comma% hotels%comma% motels%comma% service stations%comma% cafes%comma% airplanes%comma% boats%comma% automobiles%comma% and the people who were a part of that time in Arizona's history.

The Day Family became known in the Colorado Plateau region for their activities as traders on the Navajo Reservation. During their time on the Reservation%comma% they served as agents%comma% and became close with the Navajo. This collection includes images of Sam Day%comma% Sr.%comma% his wife Anna%comma% and their children Sam Day%comma% Jr. and Charlie Day.

column3: 1730.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:

Forrest's original photograph collection is comprised of over 8%comma%000 unique images dating from 1898-1968. Each image is thoroughly detailed with rich descriptions that provide specific locations%comma% individuals%comma% dates%comma% and contextual information - a rarity for most Archivists working with photographic collections. Forrest provided all the descriptions%comma% switching between a first and third-person narrative voice as appropriate. As part of the selection process for putting this collection online%comma% Museum of Northern Arizona staff and volunteers selected images that were taken in the northern portion of the state of Arizona%comma% specifically the Arizona portion of the Colorado Plateau. From this selection and in consultation with appropriate liaisons within the Hopi community%comma% images deemed to be culturally-sensitive (ceremonial dances etc.) were excluded. Of the 2112 images taken by Forrest that are at the Museum of Northern Arizona%comma% 541 were selected using the afore-mentioned criteria.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1731.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Works of art were collected by Museum staff during regular collecting trips to the Hopi villages%comma% a practice which continues today. Much like in the past%comma% current festival organizers visit with individual artists and encourage submitting both utilitarian and artistic pieces (ceramics%comma% basketry%comma% katsinas%comma% textiles%comma% jewelry) for judging and potential consignment sales. Artists and demonstrators are also invited to sell and demonstrate their work directly for Museum visitors during the festival. Today's Hopi festival - the Hopi Festival of Arts & Crafts - has undergone some changes since its first incarnation%comma% but the goal of bringing increased awareness of Hopi culture through its arts and crafts remains its core intent.

The Montezuma Castle Historic Photo Archive collection represents the history of Montezuma Castle National Monument%comma% from its time before National Park Service control in the late nineteenth century%comma% through the 1960's. These images chronicle not only early interest and exploration of the site%comma% but also document efforts by the National Park Service to preserve and stabilize these prehistoric structures for the benefit of future generations. Having just celebrated its 100th anniversary as a National Monument in December of 2006%comma% the National Park Service is pleased to present these images to the public. Montezuma Castle cliff dwelling was recently named one of the top seven man-made wonders in Arizona and stands as one of the best preserved cliff dwellings in North America.

The Day Family were Anglo traders%comma% on the Navajo Reservation in eastern Arizona. The collection includes the personal and business papers of Sam Day%comma% Sr. (1845-1925) surveyor%comma% Indian trader%comma% legislator and United States Indian Commissioner
column8:
and of their children%comma% Charles L. Day (1879-1918)%comma% Samuel Day%comma% Jr. (1889-1944)%comma% United States deputy Marshall. The collection contains archaeological reports%comma% Navajo land boundary maps and notes%comma% business records%comma% as well as several documents pertaining to Navajo culture%comma% including a copy of the treaty between the U.S. Government and the Navajo nation. The Day Family Records are particularly rich in chronicling early Anglo and Navajo relations.

This collection consists primarily of documents from the Atlantic & Pacific Railroad Co.%comma% Western Division (A&PRRCo.)
column8: California%comma% Arizona & Santa Fe Ry. Co. (CA&SFRyCo.)
column9: Santa Fe Prescott & Phoenix RR Co. (SFP&PRRCo.)
column10: The Eastern Railway of New Mexico (ERyofNM) - Belen to Rio Puerco%comma% NM

and the New Mexico Division%comma% and the old El Paso District (from Albuquerque to Belen%comma% NM). In addition%comma% this collection contains a few documents from the Santa Fe's Illinois and Los Angeles Divisions%comma% and the San Francisco & San Joaquin Valley Railway%comma% as well as documents from the Southern Pacific Company and Union Pacific Railroad.

column3: 1738.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:

Fred Harvey saw a need for better food and service along the rails and in 1876 pioneered a chain of restaurants and inns known as Harvey Houses from Chicago to San Francisco. Experience soon demonstrated that women made better servers%comma% and the 'Harvey Girls' were borne. Newspaper ads read: "Wanted: Young women 18 to 30 years of age%comma% of good moral character%comma% attractive and intelligent%comma% as waitresses in Harvey Eating Houses on the Santa Fe in the West." Fred Harvey was one of the first to employ women in great numbers. Winslow's first Harvey House built in 1897 made a welcome haven for travelers%comma% as the restored second Harvey House%comma% the La Posada%comma% does today. This exhibit offers a glimpse of both to showcase just where these Girls worked%comma% pictures them in and out of uniform%comma% and includes some interesting memorabilia.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1739.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection offers snapshots%comma% some over 100 years old%comma% from Native American life in and around Winslow%comma% AZ%comma% a border town to the Navajo and Hopi Reservations. These two tribes comprise most of the native population near here%comma% but Winslow became a second home to a contingent of Laguna Indians and members of various other tribes. The Navajos are known as weavers and silversmiths%comma% the Hopis as basket makers%comma% kachina carvers%comma% and for the storied ceremonies the latter represents. Both tribes have survived in a land and climate that can be inhospitable and formidable at best. For well over one hundred years their works have been prized collections and are representations of ancient cultures still embedded in the hearts%comma% hands and traditions of artisans of today.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1740.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Collections on display bear testament to the diverse history of this area. Winslow is one of 41 recognized sites on the Colorado Plateau with fossilized remains of the Columbian Mammoth from the Pleistocene Age%comma% a small collection of which is housed here. Continuing on a prehistoric note is the large Mary Clark Collection of Anasazi pottery and implements%comma% excavated in the early 1900's. All of the items represented in this online collection are on display in the Museum.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1741.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Trading posts were not just a western phonenoma%comma% as Congress established Federal Trading Houses at the urging of George Washington in 1796. By the time posts were dotting the landscape in northern Arizona%comma% laws had changed several times%comma% but traders were still required to register in those early years. The landscape changed somewhat from post to post but constant was the isolation surrounding each site. It required stalwart pioneers to undertake a business such as this%comma% moving their families into harsh environments. Yet a look at these photographs belies the severity of daily life. You will see a range of emotions on faces that could have well been in more civilized locales.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1742.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection is a collaboration between Oracle Historical Society and the Postal History Foundation . It includes photographs%comma% postal documents%comma% postcards%comma% postmarks%comma% and covers or cachets%comma% which are envelopes with special illustrations on them. There were a number of different post office locations in the Oracle area during the territorial period%comma% including the American Flag Ranch%comma% Acadia Ranch%comma% and the Mercantile Store. The history of the town of Oracle is%comma% like many other towns in Arizona%comma% deeply intertwined with mining and ranching. As the population grew%comma% post offices would open%comma% and as mines closed and people moved away%comma% the post offices would also close. Because postal history cannot be separated from human history%comma% the items in this collection reflect various aspects of daily life from the Territorial period to recent years%comma% including settlement and ranch life.

%newline%

Included in this collection are hospitals%comma% banks%comma% shopping malls%comma% the San Carlos Hotel%comma% Maricopa County Courthouse%comma% Phoenix Little Theatre%comma% and the YMCA and YWCA buildings%comma% just to name a few. Noted architectural firms including Lescher and Mahoney%comma% Fitzhugh and Byron%comma% and Trost and Trost are represented.

The Sonoran Heritage Collection contains resources and documents developed by the Tucson Public Library%comma% in conjunction with local institutions and organizations%comma% with the intent to educate the public about the history%comma% culture%comma% and peoples of the Sonoran Desert region of Arizona and Mexico. The materials in this collection were released in packets dedicated to specific topics%comma% including "Clothes and Costumes%comma%" "Play%comma%" "Power%comma%" "Shelter%comma%" "Family%comma%" "Work%comma%" "Genius%comma%" and "Destiny." The topics of these packets were defined%comma% examined%comma% and expounded upon through articles%comma% stories and exercises for the purpose of developing a new perspective on the history and values of the Sonoran Desert region. These learning packets were augmented by lectures and public events held in the various branches of the Tucson Public Library from January 1978 to December 1980.

%newline%
