The material in the collection exists in five volumes. The first volume includes introductory and explanatory materials%comma% and four audiocassettes of readings. The remaining four volumes contain materials in four major subject areas: "Out West%comma%" "The Golden West%comma%" "Indian Country%comma%" and "Down Mexico Way." Included among the materials are posters%comma% flyers%comma% and bibliographies intended to enhance humanities programming efforts.

The Oral Histories of Pinetop-Lakeside%comma% McNary and Whiteriver project captures the cultural history of SE Navajo County from before Arizona's statehood to the turn of the 21st Century. Each of their achievements helped make Arizona the great state it has become. Among the interviews are descendants of the White Mountain Apache scouts whose origins date back to circa 1300's%comma% the progeny of Mormons farmers%comma% the freighters%comma% the sheep and cattle ranchers%comma% and others who supplied produce and comforts to Fort Apache in the 1870-early 1900s.

Each cover is postmarked at a post office in Arizona; most of these images are from Arizona Territory before statehood in 1912.

Rosa Ronquillo Rhodes (1894-1982) was the postmistress on a ranch in Redington%comma% Arizona (Pima County) from 1922 to 1936. Of Mexican descent%comma% she was the first child in her family to become literate%comma% and held a position that was central to the ranching community in which she lived. This collection of photographs%comma% postcards%comma% and postal documents portray her life as a postmistress%comma% as well as offering a glimpse into ranch life in rural Arizona during that period.

The baskets in the Museum's collection come from private donations by collectors%comma% from the basket weavers themselves%comma% and from occasional purchases by their non-profit support group%comma% the Pueblo Grande Museum Auxiliary. The baskets in this online collection date from the late 19th century to the present. In addition to archaeological materials%comma% Pueblo Grande Museum collects objects from American Indian tribes with ties to the Phoenix area and to Arizona.

column6:
%newline%

The Connell Collection of Historic Maricopa Pottery consists of pots that were collected by Eliza Ann Connell and her daughter%comma% Caroline%comma% between 1895 and 1907%comma% in Phoenix. According to documents on file at both Pueblo Grande Museum and the Arizona State Museum%comma% Burridge D. Butler purchased the collection from Caroline Connell Smurthwaite for $500%comma% at the urging of Emil Haury%comma% on behalf of the Arizona State Museum in Tucson. The collection was given to the ASM%comma% where it was cataloged%comma% and%comma% at the request of the donor%comma% 173 pieces were transferred to Pueblo Grande Museum in Phoenix. The stated intent of the donor was to have at least part of the collection close to where Maricopa people currently reside. The Connell Collection forms the core of Pueblo Grande's Maricopa pottery collection.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1753.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Pueblo Grande was a major Hohokam village on the north bank of the Salt River in what is now Phoenix%comma% Arizona. Pueblo Grande was occupied for 1000 years%comma% from about AD 500 - 1450. In addition to dwellings%comma% it contained public architecture%comma% such as the platform mound%comma% a stone reinforced adobe structure the size of a football field%comma% and a multi-storey adobe "big house" like the one at Casa Grande Ruins National Monument. The Hohokam were desert farmers who practiced irrigation agriculture%comma% and who collaboratively created a sophisticated and far-reaching canal system to bring water from the Salt River to their fields in the valley. In addition to food crops%comma% they grew cotton and may have had a monopoly on its production for several centuries. As artists%comma% they are best known for making shell jewelry and distinctive red-on-buff pottery.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1754.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Latina Americans have had a profound%comma% yet often overlooked%comma% impact throughout Arizona's history. This collection shines the spotlight on Latina pioneers in government%comma% business%comma% law%comma% politics%comma% music%comma% and arts. In this collection:

%newline%

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1755.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Latinos have contributed greatly to Arizona's heritage and history and in numerous endeavors. One of the more valiant contributions is that of risking one's life for their country. Throughout Arizona's history Latinos have been involved%comma% from Territorial days and on into the future.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1756.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Arizona Briefs Collection consists primarily of appellate briefs submitted in Civil and Criminal cases%comma% but also includes briefs submitted in Industrial Commission%comma% Corporation Commission%comma% and several other kinds of cases. Materials are arranged by case docket number (e.g.%comma% CA-CR 1234)
column7:
consolidated cases are filed under the first listed docket number. Dates correspond to the filing date of the case and not to the date of submission of a brief to the court. Multiple briefs (e.g.%comma% opening brief%comma% reply brief) may be associated with a one docket number and are combined into a single document.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1757.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection has two components. It features images from the last private owner of Sahuaro Ranch%comma% Richard S. Smith%comma% as well as photographs from the early administration of this historic site by the City of Glendale. These images show Sahuaro Ranch in the 1930s and 1940s%comma% and the transformation of the ranch into a historic site and city park in the 1980s.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1758.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Today Scottsdale is a beautiful bustling city with many attractions enjoyed by residents and tourists alike. But did you know%comma% that the town began as a little farming settlement? Many active community organizations worked to create the Scottsdale of today and as the town grew%comma% some worked to preserve its past.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1759.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

An essential portion of Scottsdale history is contained in a photograph collection located in the Scottsdale Room. This collection showcases the history and growth of what has changed from a small farming community into a world-class city. The collection's time period spans the late 1800s to the mid-twentieth century and beyond.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1760.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The "History of Sedona" is a collection of historic images presented as a series of sub-collections divided by historical theme or context. Lacking a newspaper before the 1960s and a city government before 1988%comma% these photographs come from private collections of area pioneer families who have generously shared this wealth with the Sedona Historical Society. The images reflect the rich and unique history of Oak Creek Canyon and the greater Sedona area beginning in the 1870s with the arrival of the first permanent Euroamerican settler.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1761.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The APS Childs-Irving collection contains founding documents and administrative records of the Arizona Power Company (APC)%comma% which later became Arizona Public Service Co. (APS). Such records include correspondence%comma% legal correspondence%comma% water rights records%comma% agreements%comma% and meeting minutes. It contains correspondence and records of F.S. Vielé%comma% serving as President of the Arizona Power Company%comma% as well as maps%comma% plans%comma% and drawings used in the construction and operation of the plant.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1762.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Sharlot Hall Museum Oral History collection represents a cross-section of our larger collection of interviews%comma% presentations%comma% speeches and radio programs conducted mainly in Prescott%comma% Arizona from 1939-present. Collections include the Westerner's Collection%comma% a collection of historical presentations given by authors%comma% academics%comma% historians%comma% and colorful figures of Arizona history to the Prescott Corral of Westerner's International during the 1960s and 70s.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1763.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Sharlot Hall Museum Map Collection consists of approximately 5%comma%000 maps relating to Prescott%comma% Arizona%comma% Yavapai County%comma% and Arizona and the west in general%comma% 1850-present. Mining%comma% railroad%comma% and survey maps make up the bulk of the collection and are supplemented by aeronautical charts%comma% military maps%comma% blueprints%comma% engineering drawings%comma% and recreation maps. Within the larger collection%comma% you will find%comma% among others%comma% the William Waara Collection of mining and engineering maps and the APS Childs/Irving Collection%comma% an engineering collection of maps%comma% drawings and blueprints pertaining to Arizona's first hydroelectric power plant.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1764.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection of still images represent military activity in Arizona%comma% specifically Yavapai County and Northern Arizona%comma% 1864-Present. Subjects included in the collection are Ft. Whipple%comma% Camp Verde%comma% Ft. Apache%comma% Ft. Grant%comma% San Carlos%comma% Ft. McDowell%comma% Camp Huachuca%comma% Ft. Bowie%comma% Camp Hualipai%comma% the Rough Riders and general Arizona military history.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1765.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection of still images is related to mining activities in Yavapai County and Northern Arizona(1864-1975). Gold%comma% copper%comma% iron%comma% onyx%comma% and silver mining are represented%comma% as well as placer%comma% hydraulic%comma% underground%comma% and open pit mining.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1766.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The images%comma% documents%comma% letters%comma% newspaper clippings%comma% and ephemera (some rare and rarely seen) were selected from a collection encompassing over eight (8) cubic feet of materials held at Sharlot Hall Museum Archives. The resources chosen document two of the many roles Sharlot played in her diversified%comma% singular life
column7:
those of historian and museum curator. They also reflect upon her personal life%comma% illuminating Sharlot as a woman%comma% a daughter%comma% a sister%comma% a friend%comma% a writer%comma% an activist%comma% and a politician.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1767.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The William P. Jones collection is a small series letters dating from 1860 to 1867. He was born to Porter Jones and Elizabeth Jenkins Pendleton in 1837%comma% and was listed in the Arizona census of 1864. As a young man%comma% Jones traveled first to Virginia%comma% California%comma% then to Aurora%comma% Nevada Territory%comma% and finally to the Hassayampa%comma% Arizona Territory%comma% where he worked in the mining industry. The letters home to his family in the east detail Jones' travels%comma% work%comma% and day-to-day existence. Jones' letters to his family end in 1864%comma% and are picked up in 1866 by J.T. Alsap (a member of the Masons with William P. Jones)%comma% informing Mr. and Mrs. Porter Jones that their son was killed in a conflict with local Native Americans. Jones passed away at the age of 27%comma% and is buried in plot 56 at the Masonic Cemetery in Prescott.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1768.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)

%newline%

This audio collection consists of snippets from interviews with residents who lived in and around the White Mountains area. The 1977 interviews were part of a Northland Pioneer College project to document the history of the Northeastern Arizona region. Complete interviews can be obtained from the Show Low Historical Society Museum. RSS Logo subscribe | what is rss?

%newline%

The Show Low Historical Museum at 561 E. Deuce of Clubs opened its door in 1995. The museum is open to the public Monday through Thursday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. and on Friday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. There is no admission fee. However%comma% donations are accepted. The Show Low Historical Museum consists of more than fifteen rooms of historic material. This collection features highlights from these rooms.

%newline%

%newline%

Most of the photos in this collection are from the book "Sun City West: Silver Celebration%comma%" edited by Edson Allen and published by the Sun Cities Area Historical Society on the occasion of Sun City West's 25th Anniversary. The book is available for purchase from the Del Webb Sun Cities Museum.

%newline%

%newline%

The artifacts and historic sites that are included in this collection not only serve as examples of daily pioneer living in Taylor%comma% Arizona%comma% but also provide insight into the changes which occurred as the citizens of Taylor adjusted to world%comma% national and community development. This collection has images of items from each of the below historic sites and organizations.

%newline%

The Courtship%comma% Wedding and Marriage Beads exhibit is a traveling exhibit presented by The Bead Museum. It shows beads and beaded objects that are important in courtship%comma% wedding and marriage practices of twenty two different cultures from eight geographic regions from around the world.

%newline%

column3: 1773.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

A selection of beads and beaded objects showcasing the wide range of beads and cultures displayed at The Bead Museum. There are over 100%comma%000 beads in The Bead Museum's collection. These intriguing examples illustrate pieces from ancient times to contemporary glass beads and native cultures around the world.

%newline%

column3: 1774.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection depicts the story of Thunderbird Field I%comma% a vital World War II air training base at which more than 10%comma%000 pilots learned to fly. The collection then shows the early years of the school%comma% known as American Institute for Foreign Trade. Thanks to the vision of retired Lt. General Barton Kyle Yount and his colleagues%comma% the postwar property was transformed into a school that would become the world's leading international school of management.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1775.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This is a collection of photos and oral histories that represent Marana from the 1930s to the present. The images represent the agricultural significance and community efforts that provided an exceptional quality of life. The oral histories describe cotton farming%comma% the Marana Unified School District%comma% and the 1977 incorporation%comma% among many wonderful stories about growing up and raising a family in Marana.

%newline%

column3: 1776.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Tucsonian annuals%comma% 1906-1939%comma% are important to Tucson's history because THS was the city's only high school for 50 years (1906-1956). The vast majority of schools in the Tucson Unified School District are named for Tucson High faculty and graduates from this era. The yearbooks provide insight into the community's cultural heritage.

%newline%

%newline%

This archive consists of photographs and research into the 5 historic homes that comprise the block%comma% and the families that lived in them: La Casa Cordova (Gabino Ortega and Navarrete Cordova families)%comma% the Edward Nye Fish House%comma% the Leonard Romero House (Romero and Rambaud families)%comma% the Hiram Stevens House (Stevens and Duffield families)%comma% and the J. Knox Corbett House. The archive was created in the 1970s and early 1980s by Museum Curator Bettina Lyons O'Neill
column7:
the documents here are a small selection of what is available at the Tucson Museum of Art Research Library.

column3: 1778.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

LaVerne Harrell Clark%comma% the first director of the University of Arizona Poetry Center%comma% was also a writer of fiction and nonfiction%comma% an expert on Southwestern folklore and mythology%comma% and an accomplished photographer. During her tenure%comma% and for many years after her retirement%comma% Clark created photographic portraits of the poets who read at the Poetry Center. She photographed many of the great writers of the twentieth century%comma% including W.S. Merwin%comma% Donald Justice%comma% Leslie Marmon Silko%comma% Lucille Clifton%comma% and Alice Walker. Her photos are characterized by their natural%comma% unstudied quality: Clark was particularly gifted in capturing her subjects at their most expressive moments%comma% revealing the personalities behind the poems.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1779.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Throughout the 1960s and 1970s%comma% University of Arizona visual art students collaborated with the Poetry Center to create silkscreen publicity posters for Poetry Center readings. Former Poetry Center Director Richard Shelton initiated a student competition to produce designs for these posters
column7:
the winning design for each reading was selected by the Poetry Center staff%comma% produced by a professional lithographer%comma% and distributed widely. The resulting posters are colorful%comma% exuberant%comma% and frequently emblematic of the times. Designs range from an op art-inspired poster for Lawrence Ferlinghetti to a poster incorporating the red sun of the Japanese national flag for a reading by Gary Snyder (who spent a number of years in Japan). The posters present a stunning array of famous names from the period%comma% including Ferlinghetti%comma% Snyder%comma% Ai%comma% James Tate%comma% and Elizabeth Bishop.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1780.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This digital collection contains photographic images and documents from the Morris K. Udall Collection at the University of Arizona Libraries%comma% Special Collections. The photographic images and documents showcase Morris K. Udall's lifetime service and achievements in Arizona and the United States. Morris was born and raised in St Johns%comma% Arizona to a well-known family. As a child%comma% Morris attended school and partook in farm work. Between 1930s and 1940s%comma% Udall was very involved with athletics and academics at St Johns High School and at the University of Arizona.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1781.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This digital collection serves to highlight some of the images and text documents within the Stewart L. Udall Collection at the University of Arizona Libraries%comma% Special Collections. The material in this exhibit will provide the user with an introduction to the manuscript collection%comma% including selected photographic images documenting Stewart Udall's public career and private interests. The collection spans the course of Stewart Udall's life%comma% including his time as Secretary of the Interior%comma% under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson%comma% 1961-1969.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1782.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection of photographs%comma% documents%comma% postal covers and oral histories tells the story of Vail%comma% Arizona. It is often called the "Town Between the Tracks" because of its location between the east and west bound tracks of first%comma% the Southern Pacific Railroad%comma% and later the Union Pacific. Since 1908 the adobe post office has been a focal point for government%comma% communication and commerce in Vail and the surrounding region. All other traces of Vail's railroad%comma% mining and ranching roots are gone%comma% erased by time%comma% population growth%comma% and development. The post office characterizes the connections between the economic and cultural forces that converged at Vail in the late 19th and early 20th century.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1783.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

This collection captures what it was like to be a student at Yavapai College when it was a small%comma% rural community college in the late 1960's - early 1980's. It includes the first published College Catalog%comma% class schedule%comma% and Student Handbook (be sure to read the sections on the dress code and standards for women students). Also included are yearbooks and publications written by journalism students%comma% which highlight college departments and campus activities during the early years.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1784.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

Since 1979 Yavapai College has produced an annual publication which highlights the creative efforts of its students' writings (stories%comma% poems%comma% and essays)%comma% photography%comma% paintings%comma% illustrations%comma% ceramics and sculptures. Yavapai College's student population covers a broad age group from teenagers to senior citizens. A variety of topics and themes are covered some of which include Arizona%comma% Yavapai County%comma% family%comma% relationships%comma% and more. Also included is a 1977 creative arts publication from the Verde Valley Campus%comma% Clarkdale%comma% Arizona.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1785.php has been marked for review (Null image description)
column4: Beat Poetry%comma% Broadsides%comma% and Little Magazines
column6:
%newline%

Beat Movement broadsides and posters in this collection were part of a revolution in self-publishing as artists and poets seized control over the dissemination of their work and took it directly to the people and the streets%comma% dodging the strong forces of censorship that permeated 1950s America. Diverse in size%comma% quality%comma% and quantity – from mimeographs to fine letterpress print – broadsides have been important vehicles for political%comma% social%comma% and cultural commentary on a profusion of subjects including politics%comma% free love%comma% the anti-war movement%comma% environmental consciousness%comma% civil rights%comma% free speech%comma% and more. The broadsides are critical primary research materials%comma% artfully documenting the dynamic social movements of the 1950s and 1960s.

%newline%

column3: 1786.php has been marked for review (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

The Cache Valley Diaries digital collection brings a sampling of these firsthand accounts from the Merrill-Cazier Library's Special Collections and Archives to your computer screen. More than just lists of daily reflections by Cache Valley residents%comma% these volumes also contain biographies and correspondence related to the individuals who wrote them. Some are typescript copies while others are the original narratives handwritten by the author. Each contributes to understanding 150+ years of Cache Valley experience.

%newline%

column3: 1787.php has been marked for review (Null image description)
column4: Collecting Memories: Oral Histories of American Folklorists
column6:
%newline%

Collecting Memories features the voices of American folklorists and aims to document the development and change in the field of folklore since the mid-twentieth century. A joint project of the American Folklore Society (AFS) and Utah State University (USU) (official repository of the AFS archives)%comma% this collection offers a descriptive listing of interviews held at USU and at other institutions. The USU interviews include transcript%comma% sound%comma% photographs and more. Interviews housed at other institutions are mostly analog and not available online
column7:
however%comma% links lead users to descriptive records at the owning institutions where in some cases transcripts are available.

%newline%

column3: 1788.php has been marked for review (Null Browse Link)
column6:
%newline%Images in this digital collection represent just a fraction of the many thousands of portraits and other photographs taken by the Compton Studio in Brigham City%comma% Utah from 1884 to 1994. Three generations of Comptons operated the Compton Studio%comma% creating a remarkable visual record of business%comma% agriculture%comma% education%comma% and social activities in Box Elder County spanning almost century.

%newline%

column4: Forest Ranger Daybooks of Aaron P. Christiansen
column6:
The fifteen daybooks in this collection describe the daily activities of a Forest Service Ranger in the early twentieth century. Written by Aaron Parley Christiansen when he was assistant Forest Ranger for the Uintah Forest%comma% the daybooks cover 1915-1921 and describe his work activities in both the field and the office. Working in the Uintah National Forest%comma% Christiansen was required to keep a daily log of his activities%comma% these books represent that record. Subjects mentioned include timber sales%comma% grazing leases%comma% road building%comma% forest fires and reseeding projects. Christiansen spent a great deal of his time in the field primarily working out of the Salt Creek Ranger Station%comma% many of the entries concern the Salt Creek area. Of particular interest are the comments concerning Forest Service philosophy and Christiansen's philosophy about conservation.

%newline%
column10: Aaron P. Christiansen Daybook 6%comma% November%comma% 1916 and January%comma% 1917

column4: J. Bracken Lee: Selections from Archive held at USU Eastern Campus
column6:
%newline%

The J. Bracken Lee collection contains photographs%comma% newspaper articles%comma% campaign ephemera%comma% transcripts%comma% correspondence%comma% and audio recordings that span Lee's entire life%comma% from birth to retirement. While these papers are physically housed at the Utah State University-Eastern in Price%comma% Utah%comma% you can sample some of the most significant documents and recordings from the former governor's remarkable career in this online J. Bracken Lee digital exhibit.

%newline%
column10: Transcript of Mayor J. Bracken Lee's testimonial dinner%comma% Hotel Utah%comma% January 7%comma% 1972

column6:
%newline%

Listen to people who have worked or played in Logan Canyon during the last century talk about what the canyon has meant to them. Ranchers%comma% scientists%comma% activists%comma% scholars%comma% foresters%comma% sheepherders%comma% hikers%comma% fishermen%comma% and nearby residents tell their canyon stories%comma% adding a social and cultural perspective to scientific studies of Logan Canyon. Interviews with key land managers and users of Logan Canyon originate from the Logan Canyon Land Use Management Oral Histories project (2008-2009). The project's three partners were: Utah State University's Merrill-Cazier Library%comma% College of Natural Resources%comma% and Maintain West Center for Regional Studies. Generous funding came from the LIbrary's Special Collections and Archives%comma% the Mountain West Center%comma% the Utah Humanities Council%comma% and the Utah Division of State History.

%newline%
column10: Lodge at Camp Lomia%comma% summer home of the Boy Scouts

column6:
%newline%

In the 1860s and 1870s the Intermountain West for most Easterners was an exotic%comma% interesting%comma% and potentially dangerous place. Eager to see images%comma% but distrusting the accuracy of artists%comma% they clamored for the realism that photography could provide. William Henry Jackson%comma% A.J. Russell%comma% C.R. Savage%comma% Jack Hillers%comma% Carleton Watkins%comma% and others used the transcontinental railroad to transport the bulky equipment needed for collodion%comma% wet-plate negatives that brought top dollar in the form of stereo-views or "large-format" prints. The twenty years from 1860 to 1880 was the golden age of Western photography because quality images were in high demand. Every government survey and all the major railroads had official photographers. Interest would wane%comma% however%comma% in the 1880s as the general public started to want cheap%comma% low quality shots of popular tourist destinations. Furthermore%comma% as the West became mundane%comma% the more evocative%comma% romantic recreations of the "Old West" found in dime novels and Wild West shows became more popular.

%newline%

%newline%

Frances Winton Champ lived and breathed music. A resident of Cache Valley%comma% Utah%comma% this accomplished pianist performed as a solist with the Boston%comma% Chicago%comma% and Utah Symphonies
column7:
she also composed and taught music. Serving as a musical snapshot of Cache Valley history%comma% this collection includes not only popular music anthologies and sheet music%comma% but also numerous printed programs detailing Champ's piano recitals and performances as well as cultural artifacts offering a glimpse into the rich artistic life of Logan during the late 1920s through the 1940s. Many of the vintage scores are beautifully printed with several important music publishers in both Europe and the United States represented. Some handwritten pieces are illustrated by former USU professor and artist Everett Thorpe. One%comma% published for the beginning piano student%comma% uses themes from Western Native American culture.

%newline%
column11: Franz Liszt : 3 Etudes de Concert : Piano Solo

column4: Idaho State Historical Society Browsing Photographs
column6:
%newline%

The Browsing Photographs Collection is comprised of a vast array of subjects and locations from across Idaho. Biographies%comma% general subjects%comma% Native American groups%comma% Idaho towns and Boise subjects come together to collectively form the Browsing Collection.

%newline%
column10: Fourth of July parade down Main Street in Hailey%comma% headed by Miners Union%comma% 1883

column3: 1795.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was a public works relief program that operated from 1933 to 1942 in the United States for unemployed%comma% unmarried men from relief families%comma% ages 17 to 23. A part of the New Deal of President Franklin D. Roosevelt%comma% it provided unskilled manual labor jobs related to the conservation and development of natural resources in rural lands owned by federal%comma% state and local governments. The CCC was designed to provide employment for young men in relief families who had difficulty finding jobs during the Great Depression while at the same time implementing a general natural resource conservation program in every state and territory. Maximum enrollment at any one time was 300%comma%000
column7:
in nine years 2.5 million young men participated.

%newline%
column11: Logging at Camp Brown Creek%comma% Idaho%comma% 1930s

column3: 1804.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%

Leo “Scoop” Leeburn was a famous Boise-area photographer who captured many iconic Boise images. His photojournalism career started in 1943%comma% and he took photographs up until his death in 2002 at the age of 81. His photos appeared in The Idaho Statesman. Leeburn has been labeled "the unofficial photographer-at-large%comma%" and "a Boise institution." His photographs show life in Boise in the 1940s from work to a variety of activities.

%newline%

column3: 1807.php has been marked for review (Null partner)

column4: Utah Department of Transportation Official Photographs Index
column6:
%newline%The Community Relations Office of the Department of Transportation created an index to their official photographs. The office assigned a job number to each set of photographs taken or adopted by the office as official photographs. The job number provides access to all photographic material in the official photographs collection. Job numbers include a three part number series. For each job number the index minimally identifies the subject of the photos and the date or dates on which they were taken.

%newline%

%newline%On July 1894%comma% the U.S. Congress enacted a law to enable the territory of Utah to be admitted into the Union as a state. The act spelled out the calling of a convention composed of 107 delegates to meet beginning in March 1895 to draw up a state constitution. These records are the papers of that convention. They include a copy of the federal enabling act
column8: transcripts%comma% published and unpublished%comma% of the proceedings
column9: files of proposals%comma% petitions%comma% and other recommendations for inclusion in the state constitution
column10:
and a limited number of committee reports%comma% minutes and notes.

%newline%

column4: Dreaming the Skyline: Resort Architecture and the New Urban Space
column5: University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
column6:
%newline%From the El Rancho to CityCenter%comma% the Las Vegas Strip with its mega-resort hotel/casinos has developed a distinctive architectural style and type%comma% which has now been copied and exported to other gaming and resort cities throughout the world. Not only has this architecture transformed the physical environment of Las Vegas%comma% it has become a leitmotif for post-modern architecture. Aesthetically eclectic%comma% it has become a hallmark of the themed amusement park that characterizes the new urban entertainment and recreational space.

%newline%

Saladino II was a highly respected landscape architect who worked on several public service projects while also leading the fight to gain professional recognition for landscape architects. Saladino designed many notable projects%comma% including Floyd Lamb Park (one of the largest state parks in Southern Nevada)%comma% for which he was awarded the Elmer H. Anderson Parks Excellence Award and the historic mall and Arboretum at the University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas.

column3: 1838.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null browse link)
column5: Harold Mace was born and raised in Kanab%comma% UT. He was the only professional photographer in the greater Kanab area in the 1940s and 1950s. He was very civic-minded and recorded on film many of the events that happened in Kanab%comma% Kane County%comma% and the Fredonia%comma% Arizona area. He took the children's school pictures and his camera was at many school sports events. He photographed many weddings and family portraits. He also photographed documents for people to be preserved since copy machines were not available. Before he passed away%comma% he donated hundreds of photographs%comma% negatives and his early equipment to the Kanab Heritage Museum so that they could be preserved.
column6:
%newline%Harold loved gardening%comma% hunting%comma% fishing and camping with his family. He loved music and played several instruments%comma% including the harmonica and mandolin. He played with a small band for 20 years%comma% and played often at senior citizen homes in the Kanab and Hurricane%comma% Utah area. He passed away in 2008 but left a monumental legacy in photographs for others to enjoy today.

%newline%This collection is currently unavailable.

This collection consists of the annual catalogs issued by Weber through six different name changes. The first catalog was issued in 1897 for the Weber Stake Academy when the academy was affiliated with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. In 1908 the school became known as the Weber Academy%comma% and changing its name again to Weber Normal College in 1918. By 1922 the institution had changed its name to Weber College and in 1935
column7:
the church transferred the institution to the State of Utah. As the school continued to evolve%comma% it became known as Weber State College in 1963%comma% and finally in 1991 it gained university status and became known as Weber State University. The catalogs in this collection provide a rich history of the evolution of courses being taught throughout the progression of the institution.

%newline%

Focusing on ranch life in the Intermountain West%comma% this digital collection of oral histories and photographs features 61 interviews with 78 ranchers from Elko County%comma% Nevada and Utah's Box Elder%comma% Cache and Rich counties. The physical elements of this collection are housed in the Ranch Family Documentation Project (Folk Coll 49)%comma% for which folklorists and archivists from USU's Special Collections and Archives interviewed ranchers and collected photographs to document and preserve the history and heritage of their unique way of life.

%newline%

column3: 1869.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

In 1899%comma% Edward Curtis joined The Harriman Expedition to Alaska as the official photographer. On the expedition Curtis met George Bird Grinnell%comma% an expert on the Plains Indians. Grinnell shared Curtis's ideas concerning the conservation of American Indian traditions. Curtis accompanied Grinnell on a similar trip to Montana in 1900; this time to document the cultures of the Blackfoot%comma% Algonquin%comma% and Blood tribes. While viewing the Sun Dance of the Blackfoot Indians%comma% Grinnell told Curtis%comma% "Take a good look. We're not going to see this kind of thing much longer. It already belongs to the past." Curtis was so moved by his experiences with the American Indians of Alaska and Montana that he vowed to create a multi-volume encyclopedic reference on all of the American Indian Tribes which he would eventually title%comma% The North American Indian%comma% A Series of Volumes Picturing and Describing the Indians of the United States and Alaska.

%newline%

Curtis began his work with the Apache%comma% Jicarilla%comma% and Navajo tribes. The Navajo tribe he worked with was located in Canyon de Chelly in Arizona. Curtis wanted a more immersive experience than the typical tourist. So he hired an interpreter and a Navajo informant to communicate through and form relationships with the Navajo people. Instead of simply viewing the ceremonies%comma% Curtis now had insight into the meaning of each ceremony. For the second volume of the work%comma% Curtis documented the cultures of the Pima%comma% Papago%comma% Qahatika%comma% Mohave%comma% Yuma%comma% Maricopa%comma% Walapai%comma% Havasupai%comma% and Apache-Mohave or Yavapai tribes. Curtis returned to Arizona to work with the Hopi tribes of the Arizona for the twelfth volume.

%newline%

Altogether%comma% the twenty volumes produced by Edward Curtis represent a grand attempt to represent the various cultures of the American Indians. The twenty volume set%comma% with the twenty accompanying portfolios%comma% containing over 1%comma%500 photograph plates%comma% was not obtainable at an affordable price for most people. The volumes were sold mostly to institutions and private collectors.

%newline%

The description element of many of these objects comes directly from Curtis. The archaic spellings and awkward grammar are authentically Curtis's. In cases where Curtis did not supply captions to a plate%comma% corresponding sections of his writing from The North American Indian were used.

%newline%

Building upon a partnership established in 2011%comma% the Arizona Capitol Museum and the Arizona Memory Project have partnered to create this exhibit to celebrate International Council of Museums' "International Museum Day." Images of the Arizona Capitol Museum is a virtual tour of the permanent exhibits at the Arizona Capitol Museum. IMD projects created by the Central Arizona Museum Association members are registered with the ICOM. For more information about IMD%comma% visit ICOM's Museum Day website.

%newline%

Welcome to a virtual tour of the Arizona Capitol Museum. Beginning at the main entrance of the Museum's historic Greek Revival exterior and continuing through each exhibit to the fourth floor where life-size figures from Arizona's past reside%comma% this virtual tour attempts to capture the basic elements of the Museum. Also included in this virtual tour are Arizona's Great Seal%comma% a 17-foot tall Greek goddess atop a copper dome%comma% and exhibits explaining Arizona's history%comma% water rights%comma% government structure and process%comma% and statehood. The Arizona Capitol Museum also has many traveling exhibits that are not included in this virtual tour. Visit the majestic Arizona Capitol Museum%comma% the building with the giant copper dome%comma% to really experience the history of Arizona.

%newline%

Murray on November 18%comma% 1884 in response to custom and in obedience to the proclamation of the President of the United States setting aside Thursday November 27 as a day of public thanksgiving and prayer. The proclamations were apparently stamped with the state seal and distributed widely by Arthur L. Thomas%comma% Territorial Secretary. This example was transferred back to Utah from South Dakota.

column4: Utah Convention to Ratify the 21st Amendment (1933) Administrative Records
column6:
%newline%

The 72nd Congress of the United States proposed the 21st amendment to the U.S. Constitution%comma% repealing the 18th amendment and once again legalizing the manufacture and use of liquor. On October 10%comma% 1933%comma% Governor Henry H. Blood called for the election of delegates to a constitutional convention for the purpose of ratifying or rejecting the 21st amendment. The election was held on November 7%comma% and the elected delegates met December 5. The amendment became effective with the ratification of 36 states
column7:
Utah was the 36th state to ratify. These records document the activities of the convention.

column3: 1888.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%

In 1930%comma% the first Southwest All-Indian Pow-Wow came to Flagstaff. This event%comma% centered around the Fourth of July%comma% featured rodeos%comma% parades%comma% authentic ceremonials%comma% and the sale of arts and crafts. It quickly became an occasion for celebration and attracted members of tribes from all over America. It was Flagstaff's primary festival for many years%comma% but the size of the crowds became unmanageable for Flagstaff residents. In 1980 Flagstaff decided to cancel the Pow-Wow permanently. This collection of historic powwow programs captures many of the images and stories behind this old tradition.

%newline%

column3: 1889.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%

Prompted by her interest in Hopi arts and crafts%comma% Helga Teiwes%comma% photographer for the Arizona State Museum%comma% documented Hopi basket weavers over the course of three years in the early 1990's. Her efforts culminated into the book%comma% Hopi Basket Weaving%comma% Artistry in Natural Fibers. She captured the three styles of basketry woven at Hopi: the wicker basketry of Third Mesa%comma% the coiled basketry of Second Mesa and plaited basketry from all of the Mesas. In addition she documented the women who created these works of art and photographed the materials including siváapi (rabbitbrush)%comma% siwi (dune broom) suuvi (sumac) and mooho (yucca). Her photographs illustrate how the materials were gathered and prepared and show the weaving techniques used. This collection of photographs is a representative sample of Ms. Teiwes's work.

%newline%

This collection includes postcards which represent Arizona subjects or were posted from Arizona post offices up until the year 1920. They are a visual demonstration of how Arizona has changed since the territorial period and many of the cards show towns%comma% buildings%comma% and ways of life which no longer exist. Messages on the reverse of these postcards comment on the experiences of inhabitants and visitors%comma% and as a whole%comma% this collection demonstrates how the postal service provided a vital means of communication for those wanting to stay in touch with people "back home."

%newline%This collection traces the story of the University of Arizona Poetry Center from its modest beginnings in two Highland Avenue cottages to its permanent home in the award-winning Helen S. Schaefer Building. As the Poetry Center celebrated its 50th anniversary%comma% its current and former leaders looked back at the Center's history in a series of essays collected in The University of Arizona Poetry Center: Celebrating 50 Years. That volume is reproduced here%comma% together with photographs and reproductions of artifacts from the Poetry Center's institutional archives.

%newline%The Poetry Center was founded in 1960 by writer%comma% editor%comma% and philanthropist Ruth Stephan%comma% who envisioned a space where the public could "encounter poetry without intermediaries." Since that time%comma% the Poetry Center has expanded to become one of the premiere institutions of its kind in North America%comma% offering a world-class%comma% open-access special-collections poetry library and a wide variety of educational and outreach programming for writers%comma% readers%comma% and artists of all ages.

The Webb Construction Company%comma% to ramp up publicity%comma% had sponsored a nationwide contest to name the community. An ad was placed in the Saturday Evening Post%comma% awarding a new home to the winner. More than 100%comma%000 people came to see Sun City during its three-day weekend opening%comma% which began on January 1%comma% 1960. Del Webb%comma% the owner of Webb Construction Company was featured on the cover of the Time magazine on August 3%comma% 1962. A five page article on Del Webb%comma% his company and Sun City were in the magazine.

column3: 1942.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
column6:
%newline%

In April 1881%comma% the Helena City Council began meeting after the public approval of a charter incorporating the City of Helena. Minutes were created after each meeting and they detailed the actions of the mayor and aldermen in establishing the framework and continuance of their municipal government. The information typically captured in these minutes included the date%comma% time and location of the meeting%comma% the elected officials present%comma% members of the public who offered business for the council to consider%comma% and any action taken by the council. These minutes were handwritten in a bound volume. When a volume%comma% or minute book%comma% was filled%comma% a new one was started and this process continued. Handwritten minutes were kept in this fashion until October 1910%comma% when minutes were then typewritten. Each successive volume was continuously and carefully maintained in secure storage by the Helena City Clerk%comma% such that today a complete history of the activity of Helena's governing body exists. These bound volumes are carefully secured and maintained by the City Clerk and staff to the present day.

%newline%

%newline%

column3: 1958.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The Butte-Silver Bow Public Archives collections are comprehensive and interrelated and provide dynamic insights into the second Industrial revolution -the electrification of America-the history of copper mining and the rise of the Gibraltar of the labor movement in the American West. Butte%comma% Montana is home of the world's largest copper deposit%comma% once one of the most radically and ethnically diverse settlements of the West. The Butte-Silver Bow Public Archives actively collects manuscripts%comma% documents%comma% photographs%comma% and maps pertaining to Butte-Silver Bow. The Archives holds some 2%comma%000 collections in its state-of-the-art building. The records and manuscripts provide essential information on a number of subjects including the history of technology%comma% environmental history%comma% the history of women and minority groups and industrial and labor history.

%newline%
column10: Montana Schools for Deaf%comma% Blind and Backward Children : 1921-1922 Annual Report

column3: 1959.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Charles Hauswirth was born in Butte%comma% Montana in 1882 to Simon and Mary Hauswirth. In 1906 Hauswirth was a grocer at Forrest and Hauswirth Grocer%comma% and later he owned the Western Fuel Company. In 1932 Hauswirth started the "Eye Opener%comma%" a self-published newspaper%comma% which served as a venue for him to voice his thoughts on the economic troubles of the 1930s. After two unsuccessful campaigns for commissioner and sheriff%comma% he was nominated for mayor in 1935 as a Republican. He was the first mayor in Butte to serve more than two terms%comma% serving four terms. Hauswirth was a member of the Butte Exchange Club%comma% Butte Lodge No. 240%comma% BPOE%comma% and the Masonic Fraternity. Hauswirth died at his home on April 11%comma% 1941%comma% shortly after winning his fourth re-election.

%newline%

column3: 1960.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Mines and immigrant neighborhoods%comma% labor unions and socialism%comma% progressive schools and thriving theaters%comma% saloons and brothels%comma% the Columbia Gardens and the Berkeley Pit—all of these contribute to the historical legacy of Butte%comma% Montana. The landscape of Butte today is filled with historic buildings and headframes%comma% along with outdoor areas like the Highland Mountains and the nearby Boulder River. This collection contains books%comma% pamphlets%comma% scrapbooks%comma% articles%comma% and photographs exploring and showcasing the Butte area's rich history%comma% including privately held items contributed by community members.

%newline%

column3: 1961.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The town of Big Timber was settled in south central Montana when the Northern Pacific Railroad arrived in 1882. By 1892%comma% Big Timber was one of the world's largest exporters of wool%comma% shipping out as much as 2 million pounds a year.The Big Timber Pioneer newspaper started in 1889 and is still in print today.This collection of newspapers begins with 1893 when Big Timber had a population of 500 and follows the community through its colorful history - including adventures with Native Americans%comma% the arrival of Chinese and Norwegian immigrants%comma% the big fire on Friday the 13th (March 1908)%comma% the decline of the wool industry%comma% the rise of cattle and cowboys%comma% and lots more.

%newline%

This collection of newspapers begins in 1912 and follows the community through its history.

%newline%The Natives of Montana Archival Project (NOMAP) collects primary source documents related to the various tribes of Montana. Documents have been collected from the National Archives%comma% National Museum of Natural History%comma% and the Smithsonian Institution in Washington%comma% DC.

column3: 1979.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%During World War II%comma% Fort Missoula in Missoula%comma% Montana%comma% was turned over to the Department of Justice%comma% Immigration and Naturalization Service for use as an Alien Detention Center (ADC) to hold foreign nationals and resident aliens. This collection includes correspondence%comma% telegrams%comma% memoranda and maps documenting the creation of the Fort Missoula Detention Camp between 1941 and 1942. The majority of the records originate from Willard F. Kelly%comma% Chief Supervisor of Border Patrol%comma% Immigration and Naturalization Service. Details are provided about the construction of new facilities; the renovation of existing facilities; the securing of supplies including vaccinations%comma% clothing and food; and other logistics such as sanitation and entertainment. Some documents include personal information about the detainees including name%comma% rank%comma% age%comma% hometown%comma% and marital status. Some of the documents also relate to provisioning Fort Lincoln just south of Bismarck%comma% North Dakota. Between 1941 and 1944%comma% the ADC held 1%comma%200 non-military Italian men%comma% 1%comma%000 Japanese resident aliens%comma% 23 German resident aliens%comma% and 123 Japanese Latin and South Americans. The 1%comma%200 Italian men were merchant seamen%comma% World's Fair employees and the crew of an Italian luxury liner seized in the Panama Canal. Many of the Italians%comma% who referred to the Fort as "Bella Vista%comma%" spent the war as paid laborers replacing American men working in forestry%comma% farms%comma% the sugar beet industry and constructing Highway 12. Following the bombing of Pearl Harbor on December 7%comma% 1941%comma% the FBI arrested more than a 1%comma%000 of the most prominent Japanese leaders on the west coast as potential security risks. Ultimately%comma% over 1%comma%000 Japanese men -- all resident aliens barred by law from American citizenship -- were held at Fort Missoula for loyalty hearings. None was ever charged with any act of disloyalty but all were held at Fort Missoula or other camps for the duration of the war. A handful of German resident aliens were held for short periods at Fort Missoula%comma% although most were held at Fort Lincoln in Bismarck%comma% North Dakota. The 123 men of Japanese ancestry from Latin and South America%comma% mostly Peru%comma% were a very small part of several thousand held primarily at the Santa Fe camp or at Crystal City%comma% Texas. The documents in this collection were scanned from notebooks maintained by the Historical Museum at Fort Missoula. These notebooks contain only photocopies. Documents which include medical or case file information about detainees have not been made available. There are indications that the original documents were held at one time in the record vault of the Missoula County Records office. Official records of internment camps%comma% including those of Fort Missoula%comma% are held by the National Archives and Records Administration in RG 85.

%newline%

column3: 1980.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The Boone and Crockett Club was the United States' first hunting and big game conservation organization. It was founded by Theodore Roosevelt in 1887 and continues to this day. Its mission is "to promote the conservation and management of wildlife%comma% especially big game and its habitat%comma% to preserve and encourage hunting%comma% and to maintain the highest ethical standards of fair chase and sportsmanship in North America."

%newline%Among its many activities%comma% the Club advocated for passage of conservation laws and policies such as the Alaska Game Law%comma% the establishment of Glacier and Mt. McKinley (now Denali) National Parks%comma% a bill to enlarge Yellowstone National Park%comma% and many forest reserve and game refuge bills. The Club was able to lend effective support to conservation efforts due to its notable members%comma% including Aldo Leopold%comma% Gifford Pinchot%comma% Theodore Roosevelt%comma% George Bird Grinnell%comma% Charles Sheldon%comma% John F. Lacey%comma% Stephen Mather%comma% Jay N. "Ding" Darling%comma% and many other prominent conservationists.

%newline%
column10: Letter from George Bird Grinnell to Alden Sampson

column3: 1982.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6: %newline%Evelyn J. Cameron was a pioneer photographer and rancher in eastern Montana. Originally from England%comma% she moved to Montana with her husband Ewen in 1893. Evelyn kept extensive diaries from 1893 until her death in 1928. The diaries (35 in total) presented here chronicle her daily life including books she read%comma% chores%comma% lists of letters written and received%comma% local and national events%comma% photographs taken%comma% social activities%comma% verbatim copies of special letters%comma% and weather. The diaries also include innumerable tidbits of information that reveal the fabric of her life and by extension that of many women in eastern Montana at the time. For instance%comma% her diaries include the number of eggs gathered and chickens killed per month
column7: notes on the amount of butter she churned
column8: methods of skinning a coyote and breaking a horse
column9: accounts of money made from her photos and garden produce
column11:
and Evelyn's favorite poems and quotes. In order to make ends meet%comma% Evelyn also became an accomplished photographer%comma% working for hire for local families wanting to record special events. Her images capture the surprising ethnic and cultural diversity that marked life in the Terry%comma% Montana area in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The diaries record when and where she took images%comma% for whom%comma% why and on what occasions%comma% and what her thoughts were at the time. Taken together the images and diaries provide wonderful insights into the life of early eastern Montana ranch families.

%newline%

column3: 1983.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%These locally produced books of 100-1000 pages contain the rich%comma% detailed stories of small Montana communities from the homestead era and beyond. Fully searchable by keyword%comma% the books include family histories%comma% photographs%comma% maps%comma% diary excerpts%comma% letters%comma% and first-hand recollections of significant events. This growing collection currently covers 29 of Montana's 56 counties.

%newline%

column3: 1984.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Rosetta Kamlowsky was one of the first female broadcasters in Montana. She hosted the Scooter radio show on KBLL Radio beginning in 1968. Over the course of her broadcasting career she interviewed everyone from her local friends and neighbors to Montana governors and Hollywood celebrities. This is a collection of those interviews dating from the 1960s to the 1980s.

%newline%

column3: 1985.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Research Montana's rich history using materials from the collections of the Archives at the Montana Historical Society. This collection includes digitized manuscript materials like diaries and letters%comma% as well as the records of government agencies%comma% corporations and organizations. Collection strengths include documentation of state and local government%comma% 19th century businesses%comma% overland journeys%comma% mines and mining%comma% political figures%comma% national parks%comma% wilderness and environmental issues%comma% fraternal and/or service clubs%comma% and women's history. Check back regularly for new materials being added to this collection.

%newline%

%newline%A 40%comma%000-page collection of historical livestock brands encompassing the beginning of brand registrations in Montana in 1873 and including new brand assignments%comma% transfers%comma% and re-registrations through 1980. The records were compiled by the Brands Enforcement Division of the Montana Department of Livestock. Brands were registered for a ten-year time period and had to be re-registered - starting in 1911 - at the start of each decade (1921%comma%1931%comma% etc.).

%newline%

This card file is part of the Montana Adjutant General's Office Records 1889-1959 (RS 223).

column3: 1995.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Thomas Brown Brook (1890-1966) was the son of a Nevada City gold miner who came to Montana in 1863. His father%comma% John Brook%comma% established a ranch on the Beaverhead River eight miles south of Twin Bridges%comma% Montana in 1870%comma% and Thomas grew up on the ranch and attended local schools. He graduated from Gallatin County High School in Bozeman and in 1913 earned a degree in Civil Engineering from Montana State College. After working on a ranch and serving in France during World War I%comma% Brook returned to Twin Bridges%comma% where he worked as an electrician. As a hobby%comma% Brook began taking photographs of various locations in and around Twin Bridges. Eventually%comma% he engaged in copying historical photographs brought to him by various individuals. Before his death in 1966%comma% Brook had compiled a substantial collection of both original and copied photographs. The Thomas Brook Photograph Collection consists of nature landscapes and town views of southwest Montana%comma% particularly in the Twin Bridges area of Madison and Beaverhead Counties. Subjects include natural history%comma% ranch and farming operations%comma% bridges and bridge construction%comma% mining and timber outfits%comma% schools and school groups%comma% and early settlers of the Twin Bridges area.

%newline%

column3: 1996.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%August "Gus" Ludwig Hormay (1907-1999) developed the rest-rotation grazing management system of the Western United States rangelands and spent more than seventy years working in natural resource conservation. In 1931%comma% after he completed his academic studies at the University of California%comma% Berkeley%comma% Hormay started working for the United States Department of Agriculture Forest Service. For the next thirty-six years%comma% Hormay worked out of the Pacific Southwest Forest and Range Experiment Station in Berkeley%comma% California and developed the theory of rest-rotation. In 1966%comma% Hormay transferred to the Bureau of Land Management and spearheaded the education of government officials%comma% land stewards%comma% and livestock holders in rest-rotation grazing techniques. The Hormay Collection of his personal and professional papers includes daily activities during 1930-1999; numerous publications; research files on Modoc National Forest%comma% Lassen National Forest%comma% and Plumas National Forest; experimental forests and ranges of Blacks Mountain Experimental Forest%comma% Burgess Spring Experimental Range%comma% and Harvey Valley Grazing Allotment; grazing allotments and rangelands throughout the intermountain and Trans-Mississippi West 1965-1977; and Hormay's experiments with reproduction and germination of bitterbrush (Purshia tridentata) 1942-1979.

%newline%

column3: 1997.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%James Willard Schultz (1859-1947) lived in and wrote about the northwestern portion of Montana which now includes the Blackfeet Reservation and Glacier National Park. In 1877%comma% at the age of 18%comma% he traveled from his birthplace in Boonville%comma% New York to Fort Benton%comma% Montana Territory. He became interested in American Indians%comma% and lived for many years with the Blackfeet Indians as an accepted member of their nation. Drawing upon his experiences on the western frontier%comma% he wrote books and articles to make a living as an author. The Schultz Collection includes photographs of Blackfeet%comma% Blood%comma% Kutenai%comma% Shoshoni and Arapaho Native Americans%comma% Glacier and Waterton Lakes National Parks%comma% and historic views of Montana%comma% Wyoming%comma% and Arizona.

%newline%
column10: Blackfoot Native North American%comma% Mrs. Little Dog (Imitaikwan)

column3: 2000.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Early day Polson%comma% Montana%comma% located on the beautiful shores of Flathead Lake%comma% boasted two weekly newspapers%comma% The Flathead Courier and The Lake Shore Sentinel. Their small-town stories and articles%comma% pictures%comma% and ads for long-ago products and businesses give a clear glimpse into Polson/Lake County life during the early years of the twentieth century. Both newspapers show the vibrant history of this prospering Montana location. In 1911%comma% The Lake Shore Sentinel consolidated with The Flathead Courier. World news continued to mingle with local editorial comments%comma% homestead news%comma% school happenings%comma% births and deaths%comma% and farm and ranch news%comma% along with details like stage coach and ferry schedules.

%newline%

Genealogists as well as local historians will find much of interest here.

%newline%

%newline%The World Museum of Mining Photo Archives has a vast collection of photographs of the history of mining and the historical and cultural aspects of Butte and the surrounding area. The collection spans the timeframe from the 1880s to the 1950s. It contains over 14%comma%000 photographs%comma% negatives and glass plates. Browse this sampling of mine photographs found in the collection Mining in Butte. Most of these mines and mining activities are long gone%comma% but their legacy lives on in this photograph collection. This project was made possible in memory of Donald F. Cooney%comma% a lover of Butte and its history.

%newline%

The Sax and Fryer Store museum began with Frank Fryer's personal collecting in the 1940s. The collection does not document the daily operations of the Sax and Fryer Store or the Fryer family.

column3: 2013.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Arizona Highways magazine was born in the early 1920s. As automobiles emerged as the preferred mode of transportation in the U.S.%comma% a handful of states throughout the country developed magazines to entice motorists to travel newly developed roads. Sponsored by the states' departments of transportation%comma% these magazines provide a unique resource for examining how the automobile changed the history of travel and helped to shape identities of place in America. Of these magazines%comma% none date as far back or have featured the iconic photography that has made Arizona Highways a national treasure.

%newline%

%newline%This collection contains images of businesses and homes in the Ogden area. The photographs were taken by the Weber County Assessor's Office for tax purposes. The photographs range in date from the 1920s to the 1970s. The photographs are organized by city and then plot number leading to an address. Not all streets or buildings are included.

%newline%This selective small digital collection highlights his will%comma% letters%comma% and book inscriptions that offer insights into his complex relationships with the important women in his life: first wife Bessie%comma% second wife Charmian%comma% daughters Joan and Bess%comma% mother Flora%comma% "mammy" Jennie%comma% and friend/collaborator Anna Strunsky. Other items in the digital collection include photographs and book covers. For more details about London's life as well as a full inventory of USU's larger print collection of Jack and Charmian London materials%comma% please visit this link.

%newline%Jack London Portrait

%newline%

"

%newline%Cache Valley native Alfred Gordon Erickson attended Utah State Agricultural College in the second half of the 1940s following his service in the Army Air Force during World War II. The 255 black and white photographs in this digital collection were taken by Erickson between 1940 and 1950 while he was with the Army in California and a college student at USAC in Logan%comma% Utah. Of particular interest are several views of Jack London's ranch%comma% visited by Erickson while he was based in California.

%newline%
column10: Erickson walking in cap and gown

column4: Utah Legislature. House of Representatives Working Bills%comma% 1896-1989
column6:
%newline%This series documents the legislative process in the House of Representatives. The series contains the working copies of House bills%comma% claims (through 1915)%comma% petitions (until 1921)%comma% memorials%comma% reports (1897 only) and resolutions. The working copy includes the bill as introduced and any amendments made to it. The final official version of the bill is not part of this series unless it was vetoed by the Governor%comma% returned to the Legislature while still in session%comma% and the Legislature failed to override the veto.

%newline%

column3: 2037.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%There was a time when the small town of Aguila%comma% Arizona wasn't such a nice place to be. After a few years of being plagued by crime%comma% community members decided to make a change. They got the town's issues in the press%comma% which set off a chain reaction of events that resulted in a local cultural shift. Within months%comma% most of Aguila's problems faded into history. This collection features photographs depicting the town as it exists today.

%newline%

column3: 2067.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6: %newline%James T. Annin%comma% eldest son of Senator Joseph (J. B.) and Janet (Haldine) Annin%comma% was born in Livingston%comma% MT%comma% and moved with his family to Columbus in 1892. After graduating with the first senior class of Columbus in 1906%comma% he then graduated from Montana State College (Bozeman) and became the publisher for the Columbus News until 1932. He went on to become a rancher%comma% forester%comma% and state representative%comma% as well as secretary and finance officer of the state Republican party. In 1960 he began the collection and copying of photographs of Stillwater families%comma% which%comma% along with text%comma% became the three-part county history mentioned in the cross-reference above. Originally intended as something less comprehensive than the ultimate end product%comma% the photograph collection grew to over 2%comma%300 8 x 10 inch prints before the history was published in 1964. Many of the photographs are composites of several smaller snapshots
column7: some were not included in They Gazed upon the Beartooths
column8:
others were included without explanation as to their subjects' significance in the settling of Stillwater County.

The bequest of Virginia Snook to the Yellowstone Art Museum comprises the largest collection of Will James-related material in any public collection. Nearly 4%comma%000 works of art%comma% books%comma% and archival items support research and exhibitions about this cowboy author and illustrator from the early twentieth-century West%comma% including Montana.

%newline%

%newline%Lewis and Clark County Archive collections include materials of historical interest and research value from the earliest days of governmental operations within historic Edgerton and its successor Lewis and Clark County. Papers dating from the early 1860s to present times are represented in the collections along with maps and photographs%comma% ephemera%comma% real estate and property documents%comma% election materials%comma% official declarations and findings%comma% court documents%comma% road and bridge plans%comma% correspondence relating to various county offices%comma% plans and mining records.

%newline%
column10: Election Notice for French Bar Station Precinct

column3: 2070.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Eureka%comma% Montana didn't always have a newspaper. For many years the Lincoln County High School student newspapers served as the community paper with their biweekly publication during the school year. The Evergreen and Ksanka carried stories%comma% articles and ads for the community in addition to school news. The paper had student editorials on local happenings%comma% and farm%comma% ranch and logging reports along with Libby Dam preconstruction articles. Some local births and deaths were news items%comma% along with club meeting%comma% accidents%comma% weddings%comma% and hunting successes. These newspapers were vital to the Tobacco Valley of Northwest Montana and today much of the history of the region is preserved through the papers.

%newline%

column3: 2072.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The photos of Armstead%comma% Montana depict a town that disappeared beneath Happy Hawkins lake behind the Clark Canyon Dam in the early 1960's. It was important because it was the site of Camp Fortunate where the Lewis and Clark Expedition met the Shoshone Indians and Sacajawea recognized her brother. Both the Union Pacific Train that ran from Salt Lake City to Butte and the Gilmore and Pittsburg Railroad had depots there. The collection was housed in the archives of the Beaverhead County Museum where the originals continue to be held.

%newline%

column3: 2073.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Images in this collection include University of Montana campus students%comma% buildings and events%comma% and scenes from around Missoula%comma% Montana%comma% and the region. They were selected from Archives & Special Collections at the Mansfield Library%comma% University of Montana and represent only a fraction of what is available onsite. The digitization and addition of images to this collection is ongoing.

%newline%

column3: 2074.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%This digital collection consists of speeches by%comma% statements of%comma% and interviews with Mike Mansfield drawn from the extensive Mike Mansfield Papers held at The University of Montana's Mansfield Library. Mike Mansfield was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1942 and served five terms as representative of Montana's 1st District. He was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1952 and reelected in 1958%comma% 1964 and 1970. He became Assistant Majority Leader (Majority Whip) of the Senate in January 1957%comma% and served in that capacity until 1961%comma% when he was elected Majority Leader of the Senate. He held that position until he retired from the Senate in 1977 - longer than any other Majority Leader in the history of the U.S. Senate.

%newline%

%newline%Monument Valley%comma% with skyward reaching red rock monuments%comma% has long been symbolic of the rugged deserts of the American West. However%comma% before Western films%comma% television shows%comma% and commercials established its fame%comma% Monument Valley was virtually inaccessible for locals and tourists. Even after the invention of the automobile%comma% the absence of an effective road system in the harsh terrain did little to heighten its accessibility. Dolph Andrus%comma% of Bluff%comma% Utah%comma% set out to change that and was convinced that he could open Monument Valley to automobile tourism.

%newline%In the Spring of 1917%comma% Andrus left Bluff%comma% Utah with William H. Hopkins%comma% a dentist and enthusiastic photographer%comma% to complete an automobile journey through Monument Valley%comma% on to Kayenta%comma% Tuba City%comma% and Lee’s Ferry%comma% Arizona. Later that summer%comma% Andrus set off again with photographer%comma% L. W. Clement with the intent to photograph the natural bridges and monuments of the valley. Andrus’s wife%comma% Irene%comma% and daughter%comma% Torma%comma% accompanied them on this trip in which burros were used for transportation.

%newline%The bulk of this collection consists of the photographs taken during these tours of Monument Valley%comma% Natural Bridges National Monuments%comma% Zion National Park%comma% the Colorado River%comma% and the San Juan River. Andrus's Maxwell automobile is featured in many of the images. Also in the collection is the personal history of Dolph and Irene Andrus and log of these trips. The Monumental Highway Digital Collection is comprised of the Dolph Andrus Monumental Highway Photograph Collection (P0360) and the Dr. William H. Hopkins Addendum Collection (P0542).

%newline%Please visit the Dolph Andrus's Monumental Highway Expeditions Digital Exhibit for more information.

%newline%Torma at the wheel of her first car

%newline%

"
column10: Dolph Andrus's Monumental Highway Expeditions Digital Exhibit

Many directories contain a history of the city%comma% state and region%comma% information on the climate%comma% topography and natural resources of the area%comma% and in some instances photographs.

Some pieces in our poster and print collection date back to World War II%comma% however%comma% so our collection covers a significant portion of the 20th century.

column5: University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
column6:
%newline%This collection consists of historical materials collected by the Foundation. Included are letters%comma% articles%comma% family histories%comma% town and county histories%comma% biographies%comma% and miscellaneous materials on Utah cultural history. Business correspondence relates to the publication of the Utah (later Western) Humanities Review%comma% including Dale Morgan's bibliographies of the lesser Mormon churches. Correspondents also include Bernard De Voto and Wallace Stegner. Also included are a small quantity of business records of the Foundation%comma% a manuscript and galley proofs of the first issue of the Utah Humanities Review%comma% and records of the Warshaw Essay Contest.

%newline%
column10: Pen sketches of University of Utah Presidents

column5: University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
column6:
%newline%The purpose of the Utah Pioneer Costume Research Project was to photograph%comma% record and annotate historic dress and define the relation of Utah pioneer dress to the general development of costume in the United States. It attempts to find similarities between Utah pioneer dress and the characteristics of the fashion of 1977%comma% to find in what ways Utah pioneer dress differed from these%comma% and to find what additions were made to the fashion of 1977 by Utah pioneer dress. The conclusions reached were that Utah pioneer dress%comma% from 1847-1875%comma% followed the general characteristics of 1977 fashion because the women had an interest in dress. But pioneer dress differed in certain details from 1977 fashion too.

%newline%
column10: Utah Pioneer Costume and Manners Research Project: index of counties and towns
