%newline%Montana State Library provides descriptions of more than 14%comma%000 contemporary and historic Montana state agency publications from the 1870s to the present. You will find annual reports%comma% environmental impact statements%comma% financial audits%comma% and other informational treasures about Montana’s infrastructure—its highways%comma% airports%comma% railroads%comma% banks%comma% businesses%comma% mines%comma% schools%comma% prisons%comma% hospitals%comma% recreation areas and more. This collection is contains links directly to each digital document at The Internet Archive.

%newline%

column3: 2083.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%There are at least 482 works of art in the Pueblo Grande Museum's archive. Most can be traced to the Federal Art Project%comma% during 1940 - 1941. Prehistoric pottery designs are particularly well represented%comma% with a series of silk screens and color drawings of sherds from the Museum's collection. Historic native cultures are well represented%comma% with black-and-white as well as color drawings of Maricopa%comma% Pima%comma% Mohave%comma% and Yuman objects; especially numerous are examples of Pima baskets. There are detailed architectural drawings%comma% floor plans%comma% and color renditions of native houses. There are also examples of the use of the "swastika" motif in art%comma% throughout time and around the world.

%newline%

column3: 2084.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Commissioned by the Arizona House Joint Resolution from 2008%comma% the Senator Barry Goldwater statue was created to replace one of the existing statues dedicated to Arizona in the National Statuary Hall in Washington D.C. The bronze statue was created by Deborah Copenhaver Fellows and is 8 feet tall featuring Senator Goldwater gesturing as if speaking. This collection features photographs from the statue's beginning as a clay model to its unveiling and temporary placement within the rotunda of the Arizona State Capital Museum.

%newline%

column3: 2085.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%This collection documents the restoration of Phoenix's Block 14. Located at the heart of downtown Phoenix%comma% Block 14 is the only remaining residential block from the original Phoenix townsite. As the city grew over time%comma% Block 14 and other residential areas were encompassed by commercial development. Over the years%comma% many homes fell into disrepair and were demolished.

In the early 1970s%comma% Phoenix's urban renewal campaigns targeted Block 14 for razing. A community effort spearheaded by former Phoenix Mayor%comma% John Driggs%comma% resulted in the City of Phoenix purchasing the Rosson House and the remainder of the homes in Block 14. This highly successful community and governmental partnership led to the creation of a park which was named Heritage Square.

At the center of the project was the restoration of the Rosson House. A group of dedicated volunteers meticulously restored this Phoenix landmark to its 1895 condition. Originally intended to be a meeting house%comma% the Rosson House soon morphed into a museum. During the restoration of Heritage Square%comma% other buildings were also restored and infrastructure was added to the park.

Our physical collection consists of 4 linear feet of documents and approximately 2%comma%000 photographs. In 2011%comma% this collection received a grant from the Historical Records Advisory Board to aid with its preservation.

%newline%
column10: View of the Rosson House%comma% North Side

column6:
%newline%The Al W. Morton collection documents scenic Utah. Morton photographed and filmed many of Utah's natural beauties%comma% including rivers%comma% landscapes%comma% and the National Parks in Utah%comma% helping the tourist industry. He also documented recreational activities such as river trips. His films were shown in schools as tourist promotions.

%newline%

column5: University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
column6:
%newline%Prior to 1970%comma% few Utah Chicanos had attended the University of Utah and even fewer had graduated. Low educational attainment and financial hardship were some of the factors which prevented Utah's Chicano population from pursuing higher education. As a result%comma% a group of University Chicano faculty%comma% community representatives and students felt a need to recognize and encourage those outstanding Chicano students who were willing to provide quality service to the community while maintaining academic excellence. This collection contains videos and images of Chicano scholars at the University of Utah.

%newline%

column3: 2092.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The Merci Train Collection contains a sampling of items from the 1949 Merci (Gratitude) Train. "Merci" means thank you in French. Each boxcar was filled with gifts from the people of France showing their gratitude to the American people for sending food and other supplies on the Friendship Train and for liberating France from the invading German army during World War II. The Merci Train Collection contains various objects%comma% such as paper stars%comma% photographs%comma% clothing%comma% tablecloths%comma% pillows%comma% toys%comma% paintings%comma% books%comma% trench art%comma% glassware%comma% and lovely dolls showing the traditional dress of several French provinces. A Peugeot bicycle and a wedding dress grace the Merci Train Exhibit in the Arizona Capitol Museum. The following items also can be seen in the exhibit: a crystal ashtray%comma% paintings%comma% a commemorative medal%comma% a glass hand mirror%comma% handmade stars%comma% tourist publications%comma% books%comma% souvenir postcards%comma% hand-painted postcards%comma% a religious medal%comma% a Napoleon Medal%comma% and children's clothing and toys.

%newline%

column3: 2093.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The Area that is now Petrified Forest National Park has been attracting people to its unique resources for at least 13%comma%000 years. Because of the many fossils of Triassic animals and plants which include everything from the bones of early dinosaurs and crocodile like animals%comma% to fossil leaves%comma% pollen%comma% and large deposits of petrified trees that all lived between 225 and 208 million years ago%comma% this place could be called Petrified Ecosystem National Park. In addition to tourists the park currently attracts geologists%comma% paleontologists%comma% historians%comma% and also artists who come to capture the beautiful and scenic landscape.

%newline%Hundreds of archaeological sites have been discovered in this area. These include everything from some of the earliest North American spear points to Pueblo IV age habitations which date to about the time of European settlement. This incredible diversity of natural and cultural resources makes the park a research hotbed with dozens of academic partners and a strong record of publications. As an example%comma% in early 2014 a geologic core (a thin tube of rock) taller than the Empire State Building was extracted from the park by an international team of geologists seeking to learn about climate change and extinctions during the Triassic time period.

%newline%Many years of southwestern history and culture are represented within Petrified Forest National Park and some have been captured in this collection of photographs. From prehistoric peoples to early explorers%comma% from the Civilian Conservation Corps to Historic Route 66%comma% the park has many stories to tell.

%newline%

The images span the years 1934 to 1965 and depict the dam as well as the planning%comma% construction%comma% equipment%comma% and people that made the project possible.

%newline%

%newline%A digital collection comprised of historical photographs of Moscow%comma% Idaho and the surrounding Latah County. The photos were collected by Clifford M. Ott and donated to the University of Idaho Library in 1992. Mr. Ott was an avid amateur photographer who amassed over 10%comma%000 slides%comma% prints%comma% and negatives spanning the years from 1883 to 1990. Ott compiled a selection from his collection into eleven albums containing a total of over 1%comma%800 images of Moscow%comma% Idaho and surrounding Latah County. These scrap books contain photos as well as newspaper clippings%comma% and historic footnotes. Clifford Ott used these scrapbooks%comma% and other slides and negatives%comma% to give talks to senior groups about Latah County history.

%newline%

column3: 2102.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6: %newline%Jazz journalist Leonard Geoffrey Feather was born in Hampstead%comma% England on September 13%comma% 1914. In the 1930s%comma% he arranged%comma% composed%comma% and produced jazz sessions%comma% and began to write about jazz for print media.
column7: After moving to <acronym>New York he</acronym> worked with such greats as Louis Armstrong%comma% Dizzy Gillespie%comma% and Duke Ellington%comma% establishing his reputation in various fields of jazz.&nbsp
column8: Writing for famous jazz journals and authoring several books%comma% he was particularly influential in promoting Bebop.&nbsp
column9:
Moving to Los Angeles in 1960%comma% he became the chief jazz critic for the Los Angeles Times. Leonard Feather died on September 22%comma% 1994.

%newline%The Leonard Feather Papers span the years 1900–1999%comma% with the bulk of the materials dating 1935–1990%comma% approximately. Included among the papers are photographs%comma% negatives%comma% scrapbooks and photo albums%comma% pamphlets%comma% notebooks%comma% sketches%comma% scores%comma% soundsheets%comma% correspondence%comma% clippings%comma% manuscripts (including those for books%comma% articles%comma% liner notes%comma% and radio and television productions)%comma% promotional materials%comma% research materials%comma% travel and teaching notes%comma% royalty statements and other financial papers%comma% lists of Mr. Feather's personal collections (audio cassettes%comma% records%comma% and video tapes)%comma% ephemera%comma% and papers related to Mr. Feather's last illness and documents gathered after his death.

%newline%
column13: Duke Ellington%comma% Leonard Feather%comma% Nat "King" Cole%comma% and Johnny Hodges

column4: Stacks: Idaho's Digital Repository - Additional State Agencies
column6:
%newline%[Stacks]%comma% the Idaho Digital Repository%comma% is a cooperative project of the Idaho Commission for Libraries and all state agencies. It is a searchable centralized collection of digital publications that are created by state agencies for the purpose of public information.

%newline% It was created by state statute 33-2505 which reads in part%comma% "Recognizing that an informed citizenry is a cornerstone of effective democracy%comma% and in order to provide free and continuous access to state publications%comma% it shall be the duty of the state librarian to establish and maintain a publicly accessible repository of publications prepared by state agencies. The digital repository is intended to collect state publications and make them readily available to all Idaho citizens."

%newline%

column3: 2108.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%This photo collection represents some of the most noteworthy Civilian Conservation Corps work in the Patagonia%comma% Arizona area. Often overlooked%comma% the CCC dam at the mouth of the CCC Canyon is a centerpiece for the history of the CCC in Patagonia. A nearby walking path provides a space for appreciating some of Patagonia's world-renowned beauty. This collection illustrates the long-lasting quality of some of the many projects completed by the CCC in the 1930s and 1940s.

%newline%

column3: 2109.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The site of Thunderbird School of Global Management has its origins as a primary flight training school during World War II. In the late 1930's%comma% with war looming on the horizon%comma% General "Hap" Arnold%comma% who authorized civilian training bases for World War II%comma% recognized a need to train more pilots for combat. However%comma% Congress disagreed%comma% and only allowed the expansion of one training base%comma% Randolph Field. Arnold circumvented Congress and sent out a call for civilian flight operators to gamble their dollars building training fields to teach Air Corps cadets how to fly. Out of this need%comma% Thunderbird Field was established.

%newline%Featured in the online collection are photographs of all of the Thunderbird Fields%comma% letters from cadets to their former instructors%comma% yearbooks%comma% company handbooks and other publications. Materials will be added to the online collection regularly.

%newline%

column3: 2110.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Marshall Trimble is considered the "Dean of Arizona Historians" and has taught Arizona history at Scottsdale Community College for 40 years. His first book was published in 1977 by Doubleday & Company%comma% New York. Since then he's written more than twenty books on Arizona and the West. Trimble is one of the state's most popular speakers and performers. He's also an educator%comma% lecturer%comma% folk singer and stage performer.

%newline%He was inducted into the Arizona Music and Entertainment Hall of Fame in February 2011. In March%comma% Marshall was the Grand Marshal in the Phoenix St. Patrick's Day Parade. That same year the Arizona Historical Society presented him their distinguished Al Merito Award in recognition of his lifetime service in promoting Arizona history. The Arizona Centennial Commission honored him in December 2011 as "One of Arizona's Most Inspiring Leaders."

%newline%

You can also listen to advertisements%comma% talk radio shows%comma% graduation ceremonies%comma% convocations%comma% special guest speakers%comma% and other intriguing audio recordings about social concerns.

column3: 2114.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6: %newline%This collection consists of 540 photographs from the William Allen Stonebraker Collection%comma% which was donated to the University of Idaho Library in 2003. Stonebraker took photographs in Central Idaho's remote Salmon River and Frank Church-River of No Return wilderness at the turn of the twentieth century between 1900 and 1931. The collection contains images of the Stonebraker Ranch and homestead in the Chamberlain Basin%comma% his businesses (dude ranch%comma% pack train and dogsled operations%comma% mining%comma% big game hunting) as well as wildlife%comma% scenic views%comma% and early aircraft operation.

%newline%Featuring half a century (1954-2002) of folklore fieldwork%comma% the images in this digital collection were created by noted folklorist Barre Toelken and cover a range of folklore topics such as cemeteries%comma% Native Americans (mostly Navajo)%comma% folk art%comma% vernacular architecture%comma% and customs of Austria%comma% Germany%comma% Japan%comma% and the United States. The Barre Toelken Fieldwork Image Collection (Folk Coll 35a) is a donation from Barre Toelken%comma% emeritus Utah State University English (folklore) professor
column7:
originals are housed in the Fife Folklore Archives in Utah State University’s Merrill-Cazier Library%comma% Special Collections and Archives

%newline%
column11: Barre Toelken playing a guitar and singing%comma% Salzburg%comma% Austria%comma% 2001 (1 of 2).

column4: Central Utah Project: Capturing Utah's Share of the Colorado River
column6:
%newline%In this digital collection of 71 oral histories%comma% stakeholders from the Central Utah Water Conservancy District (CUWCD)%comma% Central Utah Project Completion Act (CUPCA)%comma% the Bureau of Reclamation (BOR) and the Ute Nation%comma% join with Utah water users%comma% members of the environmental community and Utah’s political establishment to tell the complex and oftentimes controversial story of the Central Utah Project (CUP). The CUP captures the excess flow of the Duchesne River and its tributaries in the Colorado River Basin of eastern Utah and transfers it to the Wasatch Front through a trans-mountain diversion consisting of pipelines%comma% tunnels and reservoirs. Originally under the purview of the BOR%comma% Congress transferred authority to complete the project to the CUWCD when it passed the unprecedented Central Utah Project Completion Act (P.L. 102-575) on 30 October 1992%comma% which created the Utah Reclamation Mitigation & Conservation Commission to assure environmental compliance. As a result of this legislation the Interior Department created the CUPCA office for oversight.

%newline%Commissioned by the CUWCD and CUPCA%comma% the oral history project is an effort by Utah State University Library’s Special Collections & Archives to preserve and present this fascinating story and to augment research for the forthcoming book on the CUP by Utah historians Craig Fuller%comma% Robert Parson and Ross Peterson. Randy Williams%comma% USU Fife Folklore Archives Curator and oral history specialist%comma% conducted the interviews (June 2012 - September 2013).

%newline%
column10: Frances Poowegup and Phillip Chimburas interview%comma% September 12%comma% 2012

column4: Veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan Oral History Collection
column6:
%newline%The Veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan Oral History Collection is comprised of interviews conducted by the George Sutherland Archives at Utah Valley University with veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan%comma% from the years between 2003 and 2011. The collection%comma% which focuses primarily on veterans currently living in Utah County%comma% will continue to grow over the coming years.

%newline%

Each item is full-text searchable. The digitization and addition of items to this collection is ongoing.

column3: 2120.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%William Robert "Bud" Moore (1917-2010) was a well-known Montana forester%comma% trapper%comma% conservationist%comma% and author of 'The Lochsa Story: Land Ethics in the Bitterroot Mountains.' This collection contains photographs Moore took and stories he recorded about those photos. Photo descriptions and dates were provided by Moore; the online collection was transferred by the University of Montana from a spreadsheet Moore maintained at his home. Today the original files are housed at UM as part of the Bud Moore Papers.

%newline%

With the exception of a ten-year hiatus from December 1961 through May 1971%comma% the paper continues to publish a weekly issue.

column3: 2122.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%This collection includes files used by the Chippewa Cree Tribe%comma% and in particular the Tribal Water Resources Department%comma% during their negotiations with the Montana Reserved Water Rights Compact Commission and the Federal Negotiating Team for the Rocky Boy's Reservation to settle the Tribe's water rights claims. The records include information about the history of the area that is now Rocky Boy's Reservation in north central Montana%comma% the history of water system development in the region%comma% and legal files related to Rocky Boy's case for water rights.

%newline%

column6:

%newline%

column3: 2124.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%James Brownlee Rankin--a New York and San Bernadino%comma% California%comma% teacher and historian--collected information concerning Montana artist Charles M. Russell in preparation for a Russell biography and an illustrated catalog of his work. The collection consists primarily of correspondence concerning Russell's life and work as remembered by his friends%comma% acquaintances%comma% and art owners. This series%comma% constituting eighty percent of the collection%comma% is the most valuable for research on Russell and on ranching and cowboy life in the open range era. Many friends and acquaintances of Russell corresponded extensively with Rankin%comma% and their reminiscences would have been the basis of his book. Other correspondents discussed the Russell paintings and sculpture in their collections. The letters also reflect the provenance of much of the artist's work%comma% kinds of shows that it appeared in%comma% and methods by which it was acquired. The collection also contains photographs%comma% clippings%comma% and research notes. The Research Notes series of the collection contains listings of paintings%comma% notes on interviews%comma% and transcriptions of letters of Russell and others. Also%comma% there are several photographs of pieces of Russell's work owned by various institutions and individuals at that time. The collection is completed by a series of Clippings gathered by Rankin which generally concern Russell's life.

%newline%
column10: James Brownlee Rankin Box 1: Correspondence A-E

column3: 2125.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The State Law Library of Montana’s Justice Under the Big Sky collection pulls together a number of facets of the Montana legal system in a never-seen-before photo ensemble. Included in the collection are group photos of the Montana Supreme Court%comma% individual portraits of Montana Supreme Court Justices and Montana district court judges%comma% as well as Montana Judges Association group photos and historic photos of the State Law Library. Of particular interest in the collection are photos memorializing the groundbreaking of the current Montana Justice Building. The State Law Library strives to provide access to legal information for Montana's judges and court personnel%comma% members of the State Bar of Montana%comma% state officers and employees%comma% and members of the general public.

%newline%

column3: 2126.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The World Museum of Mining currently houses over 200 of John J. Powers’ screen prints. These screen prints were developed as safety posters for the Anaconda Copper Mining Company (ACM) in Butte%comma% Montana throughout the 1960s and 1970s. John Powers was a well-known cartoonist for the company’s safety department and also worked as a miner. This collection of prints is a stunning representation of safety procedures and examples%comma% both of men’s actions mining underground and taking part in everyday life above. The safety posters were designed and printed specifically for the safety department of the ACM. Unique by creator and location%comma% the posters are a treasure to the city of Butte and the state of Montana.

%newline%
column10: ALL SET FOR FRIGID WEATHER AND SAFETY%comma% TOO!

column3: 2127.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The Bozeman and Gallatin Valley History Collection is largely made up of three collections that provide a glimpse of the area and its inhabitants during the early part of the twentieth century. The life of a cowboy on the famous Flying D Ranch is conveyed by photographs taken during the 1930-1940s by Jim Pratt and Bill Shunk. Early colorized photos of the Bozeman Pass and Gallatin Canyon are the work of Wyoming photographer Jessamine Spear Johnson during a visit in 1927. The excitement of Bozeman’s own first wildwest show and rodeo%comma% the 1920 Bozeman Roundup%comma% appears in images captured by an unknown photographer.

%newline%

column3: 2135.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Carefree has been home to the famous sundial since 1959 and continues to attract tourists from around the world with its charm. With nearly four-thousand residents%comma% Carefree boasts a beautiful mountain landscape and a rich Sonoran culture.

%newline%This collection documents the creation of the town of Carefree%comma% the business lives of its founders (K.T. Palmer and Tom Darlington)%comma% its battle for incorporation%comma% and the everyday activities of its residents from inception to the present day.

%newline%
column10: Carefree Sundial with Sunburst: Where the Sun Marks Time

column6:
%newline%A few minutes after five o'clock in the morning on April 18%comma% 1906%comma% huge shockwaves began wreaking havoc on the city of San Francisco%comma% California%comma% and in the immediate aftermath%comma% fires spread across the area. The combination of the earthquake and the fires destroyed over 80 percent of the city.

%newline% At the time of the earthquake%comma% John Lorin Taylor%comma% a native of Ogden%comma% Utah%comma% was traveling in San Francisco (possibly as a missionary for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints) and witnessed the incident.This digital collection contains the 25 photographs that Taylor took on the day of the earthquake and the two days following. The images portray the devastating toll that the earthquake and subsequent fires took on the city and its inhabitants%comma% over 3%comma%000 of whom were killed%comma% and more than 225%comma%000 left homeless. The photographs include images of refugees as well as several notable buildings such as the Emporium%comma% James Flood%comma% the Examiner%comma% the Call%comma% Merchant’s Exchange building%comma% Hibernia Bank%comma% City Hall%comma%and the Central Bank – all of which were destroyed during the disaster.

%newline%
column10: View of ruins from O'Farrell and Larkin Streets after the San Francisco Fire and Earthquake%comma% San Francisco%comma% California%comma% April 20%comma% 1906

column6: %newline%Explore the origins of the Bear Lake Monster legend in this digital collection featuring folklore items%comma% newspaper articles%comma% interviews and other materials from Utah State University’s Special Collections and Archives. The Bear Lake Monster is a regional legend from the Bear Lake Valley (Utah and Idaho)%comma% home to a large%comma% deep lake where the monster purportedly resides. Many believe the legend originated in 1896 with Joseph Rich%comma% an early Mormon settler and developer of the area who used the legend as a marketing ploy to get visitors to Rich County%comma% Utah (named for his family)
column7:
he later said it was a joke. Joke or no%comma% the legend persists to date and has grown to include a connection to the Loch Ness Monster in Scotland. For many locals%comma% the legend serves as a cautionary water tale and well-known local joke.

Folklorist Elaine Thatcher notes: “My research in the Bear Lake Valley shows that the monster story has now evolved into self-parody%comma% as locals play with the story%comma% for themselves and for tourists” (Between Pulpit and Pew%comma% ix).

%newline%

%newline%This collection features a selection of art and archives from the Masterworks Arts and Artists Series. The Masterworks Arts and Artists Series is an online project launched by an ArtWorks grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.

%newline%The Selections from the Masterworks Arts and Artists Series features art by five Arizona artists which are linked with companion documentary resources. The artists included are Narciso Platero Abeyta%comma% Rena Begay%comma% Charles Loloma%comma% Alfred H. Qöyawayma%comma% and Alberta Susunkewa.

%newline%The Heard Museum Digital Library%comma% of which the Masterworks Arts and Artists Series is one portion%comma% represents a virtual selection from the Heard Museum archives and art collection. The full Heard Museum Digital Library can be found here.

column3: 2151.php has been marked for review (Null partner)

%newline%A contributor from the Arizona Memory Project

%newline%The Arizona Heritage Commemorative Portrait Collection was generously donated to the Arizona State Capitol Museum in October 1982 by the Chris-Town Chamber of Commerce and the merchants of the Chris-Town Shopping Center. This collection was commissioned by the merchants of the Chris-Town Shopping Center for the enjoyment of all Arizonans.

%newline%These 24 original oil-pencil portraits by Roger Whitney honor people who contributed to the growth and development of Arizona. Each picture reflects the person's major area of interest and influence on our state's heritage. Chris-Town gratefully acknowledged research assistance from the Central Arizona Museum of History%comma% the Arizona State Capitol Museum and the Arizona Department of Education. The research helped determine the interests and contributions of each of the subjects. Whitney%comma% a well-known Phoenix artist%comma% often worked from photos to portray both Arizonan and national sports figures in his work.

%newline% Portrait of Estevan Ochoa

%newline%

%newline%The Cache County Aerial Photograph Collection consists of high altitude images probably taken in 1952 and 1959 by the Aerial Photography Field Office in Salt Lake City. Before 1978 a number of federal agencies conducted high altitude surveys. In 1978 the National High Altitude Photography program was created to consolidate federal high altitude photography activities to save money. The images in this collection were probably used as part of the Soil Conservation Survey.

%newline%The collection also includes images of Cache County%comma% as well as images along the Cache/Box Elder County and the Cache/Weber County boundaries in Utah and from Oneida and Franklin County on the Utah/Idaho border. These images are from 9" x 9" negatives and taken at 1:20%comma%000. The date the image was taken is usually in the upper left-hand corner.

%newline%

column3: 2169.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%The Robert Lenon Map Collection consists of maps from the collection of Patagonia%comma% Arizona-based mining engineer Robert Lenon. The majority of these maps depict ore and mineral mining in the Sonoran desert region of southern Arizona and northern Mexico%comma% spanning the Arizona territorial period of the 1800s up to the 1960s. Additional selections include historical maps of the region%comma% including an 1880 Nogales city block map by Henry Flipper%comma% and maps drawn by Lenon tracing Father Eusebio Kino's route through Pimeria Alta in the 17th century. This digital collection represents just a small sample of the 9000 maps collected or created by Lenon over the course of his long and varied career.

%newline%A 1930 graduate of the Department of Mining and Geological Engineering at the University of Arizona%comma% Robert Lenon practiced as a mining engineer and surveyor for more than forty years%comma% retiring in 1975. His career in mining was interrupted by a five-year stint in the US Armed Forces during WWII%comma% where he served in both the European and Pacific theaters. In later years%comma% Lenon was an active supporter of the Arizona Historical Society and published two volumes of memoirs documenting his years in the Arizona mining industry. He died at the age of 99 in 2008.

%newline%This project was made possible through the generous support of The Walton Family Foundation.

%newline%

%newline%

The Montana State University Archives holds over 34%comma%000 volumes and 1%comma%200 linear feet of archive manuscript materials. In addition to the manuscript materials%comma% there are also archived microforms%comma% sound recordings%comma% film and video recordings%comma% unique maps and historical photographs. Over 4%comma%000 of these historical photographs are of Montana State University from 1893 through the 1960s. These unique MSU historical photos include early 20th century campus student activities and clubs%comma% campus grounds and buildings%comma% historical events%comma% and prominent alumni%comma% faculty%comma% and administrators.

%newline%

In 2012%comma% Montana State University Archives and Montana State University Library Digital Initiatives launched the Montana State University (MSU) Historical Photographs Database Project%comma% an on-going%comma% long-term project focused on providing Montana State University historical photographs online and in easily accessible downloadable JPEG format.

%newline%Brian Head Ski Resort was established in 1964%comma% and opened as a one chairlift resort. Currently the resort has 8 chairlifts%comma% 71 runs%comma% and over 650 skiable acres. Brian Head is located 2.5 hours north of Las Vegas%comma% Nevada and four hours south of Salt Lake City%comma% Utah. The resort is Utah's highest elevation ski resort. Photographs from this collection show the ski resort as it was expanding and developing in the 1970's. Also included in the collection are photographs from the community of Parowan%comma% Utah%comma% gateway city to Brian Head Ski Resort.

%newline%

Boise State University's rich history is documented in the thousands of photographs%comma% slides%comma% and negatives that comprise the University Archives photo collection. From as far back as the school's opening day as Boise Junior College on September 6%comma% 1932%comma% photographers have captured on film the buildings%comma% people%comma% events%comma% and academic endeavors that have made Boise State University such an important part of the city of Boise and state of Idaho.

%newline%

Historic Boise State presents several hundred images that document the university's history. Most come from the print collection in the Archives and are concentrated in the decades from the 1930s to 2000s.

Grant Ivins papers (1897-1973) contain diaries%comma% correspondence%comma% memoirs%comma% unpublished manuscripts%comma% and articles on subjects relating to religion and the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church). This collection documents one man's transition from a devout believer in the divine authority of the members of the LDS Church hierarchy to an outspoken critic of those he later described to Heber Holt as "mere men who make mistakes and who should be willing to admit these mistakes."

%newline%

%newline%The interviews with Jews in Utah collection (1982-1988) is part of a project funded by the Utah Endowment for the Humanities and undertaken by the Oral History Institute of Salt Lake City%comma% Utah. Events recalled by the interviewees span the time period from the 1880s to 1986. Common themes include family life%comma% immigration%comma% relations with the LDS community%comma% religious activity%comma% the unification of the congregations Montefiore and B'nai Israel%comma% Jewish businesses and organizations%comma% and World War II.

%newline%

column4: Telling Our Story: An Oral History of Utah Valley University
column6:
%newline%Telling Our Story-An Oral History of Utah Valley University is a growing collection of oral history interviews with long-time or retired employees of Utah Valley University. Interviewees in this collection include those who have worked at all of the different iterations of our school%comma% from the Central Utah Vocational School in 1942%comma% the Utah Trade Technical Institute%comma% Utah Technical College%comma% Utah Valley Community College%comma% Utah Valley State College%comma% and Utah Valley University.

%newline%This oral history%comma% which commemorates the 75th Anniversary of Utah Valley University in 2015%comma% will continue to grow with the addition of more interviews.

%newline%

The Doc Roach Collection consists mostly of photographs that reflect his long career with the Boise Fire Department. Doc was one of the few firemen who worked from the days of horse-drawn fire engines%comma% witnessed the introduction of motorized equipment in 1912%comma% and also used gasoline pump trucks. Doc collected photographs which document the fire fighters%comma% equipment%comma% major fires%comma% and fire prevention education in Boise from 1911-1965. These photographs also document the growth of Boise from a small town to a city in the first half of the 20th century%comma% including shots taken of the greater downtown area%comma% capturing changes in transportation and buildings. Many of the photographs in the Doc Roach collection were used in a book on the history of fire departments in Boise by Arthur Hart (Fighting Fire on the Frontier%comma% 1976).

Two collections relating to the life and career of U.S. Senator William E. Borah of Idaho: The William E. Borah Papers%comma% consisting primarily of his published speeches%comma% photographs%comma% notebooks and other campaign items
column7: and the C.P. Connolly Correspondence with William E. Borah and Albert E. Horsley (Harry Orchard) consisting of 36 letters (1907-1930) to Christopher Powell Connolly (1863-1935) from Borah and 4 letters (1908-1920) to Connolly from Albert E. Horsley (Harry Orchard)%comma% convicted assassin of Idaho Governor Frank Steunenberg. C.P. Connolly was a Journalist%comma% mainly with Collier?s Weekly

column6: The Idaho Wilderness collection commemorates the 50th anniversary of the signing of the U.S. Wilderness Act with primary source material documenting the political issues surrounding the management of public lands in Idaho. The Wilderness Act of 1964 created a system for the United States government to designate specific wild areas of America as wilderness areas. The Wilderness Act was signed into law by President Lyndon B. Johnson on September 3%comma% 1964. ?A wilderness%comma% in contrast with those areas where man and his own works dominate the landscape%comma% is hereby recognized as an area where the earth and community of life are untrammeled by man%comma% where man himself is a visitor who does not remain.?

Kathleen W. (Kitty) Gurnsey represented the North and East ends of Boise in the Idaho legislature for twenty-two years. First elected to the state House of Representatives in 1974%comma% she was reelected ten more times before retiring in 1996. Mrs. Gurnsey made her mark in the legislature as co-chair of the Joint Finance-Appropriations Committee%comma% the House-Senate panel that serves as the state budget-writing committee. Appointed to JFAC in 1976%comma% she became co-chair in 1980 and served in that capacity for sixteen years. "In her role as budget co-chairwoman%comma% she brought a flair for numbers and an institutional memory that outlasted three governors and five speakers%comma%" wrote the Idaho Statesman in 1996. The newspaper called her "the most powerful woman in state government." House Speaker Mike Simpson commented%comma% "She runs the state budget like it's her own checkbook." Her papers do%comma% indeed%comma% reflect the close scrutiny she applied to the details of state spending and to state government operations.
column10: Idaho State Representative Kathleen "Kitty" Gurnsey%comma% ca 1980

column6: Len B. Jordan (Leonard Beck Jordan) served as Governor of Idaho from 1951 to 1955 and United States Senator from 1962 to 1973. This collection features photographic images and objects documenting highlights of Len Jordan?s political career as Idaho governor and a United States senator. The digital collection contains 75 images selected from the Len B. Jordan Papers (MSS 6) located at Boise State University in the Special Collections department.
column10: Republican candidates Len Jordan and Herman Welker campaigning%comma% 1950

column6: Lyman D. Wilbur's slides from his visits to Afghanistan in 1957 and 1958 are part of a larger collection of his papers (MSS 205) donated to Boise State University by his daughter%comma% Olive G. Waugh%comma% in 2001. The collection as a whole documents Wilbur's career as an engineer%comma% including his four decades with the Boise%comma% Idaho-based international engineering and construction firm Morrison-Knudsen

A mixture of newspaper clippings and personal photographs reflecting the events surrounding Proposition One (1992-1994)%comma% an anti-homosexual special rights referendum that appeared on the Idaho general election ballot in November 1994. The articles concern the campaigns for and against Proposition 1 and gay rights in general while the personal photographs document Don?t Sign On/No on One?s campaign against Idaho Citizens Alliance (the organization supporting the initiative) and their anti-gay initiative. The chosen articles were clipped from newspapers within and without Idaho and serve to provide a greater context for No on One?s campaign against the anti-gay initiative in Idaho. The Idaho Citizens Alliance began the drive for the initiative in January 1992 which would eventually become Proposition 1 on the general ballot. The purpose of the initiative which eventually came to be known as the ?Anti-gay Initiative? was meant to block any Idaho legislation that would grant homosexual persons minority rights. The referendum was defeated by a majority vote in the polls in November 1994. Deborah Graham?s photographs follow No on One?s (originally named Don?t Sign On) protests%comma% rallies%comma% and eventual victory against Proposition 1.
column10: No on One rally on Boise Capital building's steps displaying sign saying "Idaho too great for hate."

column6: Of more than one hundred sixty titles published since 1972%comma% the majority the Western Writers titles focus on the life and work of individual writers who have made significant contributions to western American literature. These booklets provide biography%comma% critical interpretation%comma% and discussion of the full range of an author's work. In recent years%comma% we have expanded the scope of the Series to include booklet-length studies of "classic" texts in the literature of the American west. These titles offer close readings of important western literary works. Cover art for the titles by Arny Skov. Since its inception in 1971%comma% the Western Writers Series has been a publishing venture of Boise State University%comma% edited by members of the Boise State University English faculty. The 23 full-text searchable titles include authors like Mary Hallock Foote%comma% Jack Kerouac%comma% Ken Kesey%comma% Sam Shepar%comma% and John Wesley Powell. Recent titles are available for purchase on the Western Writers website.

column4: Everett L. Cooley Oral History Project
column5: University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
column6:
%newline%The Everett L. Cooley oral history project serves as a Who's Who in Utah. It features interviews with many who have played significant roles in Utah's history%comma% as well as others whose viewpoints and memories are important to understanding the history and the people of Utah.

%newline%A wide range of topics are discussed in the interviews%comma% including politics%comma% religion%comma% history%comma% education%comma% the University of Utah%comma% medicine%comma% art%comma% theater%comma% midwifery%comma% radio and television broadcasting%comma% sports%comma% entertainment%comma% genealogy%comma% dancing%comma% science%comma% women's issues%comma% polio%comma% skiing%comma% nuclear power%comma% the environment%comma% and athletics. The interviews were mostly conducted in the mid 1980s%comma% but range from 1960 to 2014. Time periods discussed in the interviews begin with the end of the 19th century.

%newline%

column5: University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
column6:
%newline%The Joseph Ellis Johnson papers (1831-1964) consist of the personal and family papers of Joseph E. Johnson (1817-1882). Johnson was a prolific writer%comma% leaving a legacy of seven original diaries written%comma% at broken intervals%comma% between 1850 and 1876. The diaries give detailed accounts of his various travels. The collection also contains his daybooks%comma% account books%comma% and record books.

%newline%Correspondence between members of the Johnson family makes up a great part of the collection. From his travels%comma% Johnson wrote many letters%comma% sending his love and instructions to his wives and children%comma% and also wrote to his hired help who were running his business establishments. Johnson and his third wife%comma% Eliza%comma% corresponded most frequently as conditions prevented them from living in the same locality until they arrived in Utah.

%newline%

column5: University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
column6:
%newline% The Thomas Jefferson O'Brien journals were kept during his mission to Australasia for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints at the end of the nineteenth century. His journal relates his activities with the Maori on the Northern Island of New Zealand. The first volume covers the period from November 1893 to early February 1895. The second volume covers the period from February 1895 to January 1896.

column5: Buffalo Bill Center of the West - McCracken Research Library

%newline%This collection consists of a series of original letters written by Victor Arland (c. 1848- 1890) of Arland%comma% Wyoming to Mr. C.P. Dadant of Hamilton%comma% IL%comma% a beekeeper and manufacturer of bee supplies and distributor of honey. The letters are handwritten in French%comma% dated between 1872 and 1889%comma% and for the most part are in good to excellent condition. The letters have been flattened%comma% separated by acid-free%comma% lignin-free paper in archival folders and housed in Box 1%comma% organized as Series 1. Included in Series 2 are excerpts of essays that have resulted from research with this collection.

%newline%

column5: Buffalo Bill Center of the West - McCracken Research Library
column6:
%newline%This collection contains various documents concerning the Battle of the Little Big Horn. Most prominent are two original reports of General Alfred H. Terry to General George Crook%comma% the first official reports of the defeat of Custer at the Little Big Horn battlefield. Other documents in the collection include reminiscences of Wilmot Sanford on the battle%comma% a letter from General E. S. Godfrey to E.S. Paxson about the battle%comma% as well as a letter from William F. Cody to Elizabeth Custer regarding a statue of her husband.

%newline%
column10: General Terry's second report to General George Crook on the Battle of the Little Bighorn

column4: MS 010 Count Otto Franc Von Lichtenstein Collection
column5: Buffalo Bill Center of the West - McCracken Research Library
column6:
%newline%Collection consists of four journals by Count Otto Franc von Liechtenstein relating daily activities as he ran the Pitchfork Ranch on the upper Greybull River west of present day Meeteetse%comma% Wyoming. Typed transcripts are present for the first two journals.

%newline%Born in Germany in 1846%comma% Count Otto Franc von Liechtenstein came to America in 1866. He first traveled to Wyoming in 1878. In 1879 he set up his first cattle operation in the Meeteetse area with cattle that he brought in from Montana. Pitchfork Ranch was the first cattle ranch in the Greybull River valley%comma% and its success led Franc to become a major Wyoming cattle baron.

%newline%Later in life%comma% in the 1890s Franc served as a Big Horn County justice of the peace. He is remembered for sentencing Butch Cassidy to the Wyoming state prison for two years for horse theft. Franc died in 1903.

%newline%
column10: Journal #1 of Count Otto Franc von Lichtenstein from the Pitchfork Ranch

column5: Buffalo Bill Center of the West - McCracken Research Library
column6:
%newline%This collection consists of the 15 letters from Charles Rapp to Eva Shepard written from various locations in Wyoming Territory. Mr. Rapp%comma% of New York%comma% discusses gold mining%comma% women homesteaders on the frontier%comma% Mormon immigration%comma% Shoshone and Sioux Indians%comma% and a description of a visit to the Little Big Horn battlefield three days after the battle.

%newline%Charles Rapp was a New Yorker who came to Wyoming during the short-lived gold rush period. The collection contains 15 letters%comma% written to a friend back home%comma% that describe life in early Wyoming and in the mining camps. Among the topics discussed are relations with the Indians%comma% the Battle of Little Big Horn%comma% and his feelings of home sickness.

%newline%
column10: Letter from Charles Rapp to Libbia Shepard

column5: Buffalo Bill Center of the West - McCracken Research Library

White Military Goods%comma% correspondence from individuals and companies offering goods and services%comma% business records such as bills%comma% receipts%comma% calling cards%comma% etc.%comma% bound memo books%comma% ledger books%comma% inventory books%comma% etc.%comma% and a large collection of advertisement materials. Supported by funding from the American Society of Arms Collectors.

column3: 2278.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
column6:
%newline%Maya Miller was as an inspiration and mentor to an entire generation of political activists%comma% progressive thinkers%comma% feminists%comma% and those interested in social justice. Her papers are a representation of her commitment to the rights and well-being of the disadvantaged and disenfranchised in her home state of Nevada and abroad. %newline%To pursue the legislative mandate to "erect a suitable building" to serve as the Utah state capitol%comma% the Capitol Commission issued a call for construction bids to contractors and artisans. This series contains the bids submitted to the commission by those seeking employment. The collection includes bids for furnishings%comma% heating and ventilating systems%comma% elevators%comma% vaults%comma% cuspidors%comma% lighting%comma% and numerous others. The series also documents inquiries from contractors to the Capitol Commission regarding the bidding process%comma% contracts%comma% operational budgets%comma% and contract decisions. The bids include information on Utah craftsmen%comma% architects%comma% and contractors%comma% and significant information about construction techniques%comma% planning%comma% bidding processes%comma% and labor and material costs from the period.

%newline%The records of the Western Shoshone Defense Project were maintained by sisters Carrie and Mary Dann%comma% two traditional Western Shoshone ranchers living in northeastern Nevada. The Defense Project's mission was to affirm Western Shoshone jurisdiction over Western Shoshone ancestral homelands by protecting%comma% preserving%comma% and restoring Shoshone rights and lands for present and future generations based on cultural and spiritual traditions. It was established in 1991 by the Western Shoshone National Council to provide support to Mary and Carrie Dann as they faced confiscation of their livestock which they grazed on Western Shoshone homelands without paying grazing fees to the Bureau of Land Management.

%newline%Paul Laxalt was a longtime public figure in Nevada and beginning in the mid-1970s%comma% he became a notable and highly visible player on the national political stage. Part of Laxalt’s appeal to both his colleagues and his constituents was his pragmatic and unapologetic approach to lawmaking. The son of Basque immigrants%comma% Laxalt rose through the local political ranks before becoming the first Basque-American ever elected to the U.S. Senate and “the First Friend” of Ronald Reagan.

%newline%The Ronald Reagan materials within the Paul Laxalt U.S. Senatorial Papers cover the years 1975 through 1987. They consist of a variety of personal papers%comma% scrapbooks%comma% audio/visual resources%comma% and photographs from Reagan’s three presidential campaigns in which Laxalt served as the national chairman. Presented here is a small selection of these items that have been digitized and organized according to themes that reflect both Laxalt’s political career and his relationship with Ronald Reagan.

%newline%
column10: Photograph of Paul Laxalt and Ronald Reagan%comma% 1979

%newline%The Ellis Reynolds Shipp papers came to the Historical Society in two installments (1967 and 1973) as a gift of the children of Joseph White and Ellis Shipp Musser. Besides the Shipp material%comma% a quantity of Musser family material was also donated. The Shipp papers are completely open to researchers. Dr. Shipp's papers contain a great deal of correspondence%comma% all original holographs. It has been arranged according to writer%comma% then chronologically. The biggest division is%comma% of course%comma% that of Ellis Shipp herself. There are smaller groups of letters written by her children%comma% husband%comma% and his other wives.

%newline% Another major part of the collection is the poetry of Dr. Shipp. She wrote verses continually for most of her life and published a volume of her poetry in 1910%comma% titled Life Lines. She also wrote a poem for Christmas each year as a Christmas card. Besides poetry and correspondence%comma% the collection includes a great deal of biographical material on the Shipps and Hawleys. There are also examples of diaries kept by Dr. Shipp%comma% as well as several editions of her autobiography which was compiled and published by Ellis Shipp Musser in 1962.

%newline%Subjects covered%comma% at varying depths%comma% by the Shipp papers include early medical practice%comma% genealogy and family history%comma% polygamy%comma% and life in nineteenth and early twentieth century Utah.

%newline%

Letters and other documents received by Henry K. Doll%comma% of Scranton%comma% Pennsylvania%comma% from officers of the Banner Mining and Milling Company relating to his investment in and operations of the Banner Mine in Silver City%comma% Idaho. The majority of the letters are written from Peter Steele%comma% president of Banner. In his letters Steele details the challenges of operating a mine and mill in Silver City. From 1912 to 1923%comma% the mine experiences a list of problems and catastrophes that stop work%comma% and the miners rarely find a significant deposit of silver ore. Steele spends most of his time seeking investors to buy stock and bonds to finance mining operations. This timeline demonstrates the ups and downs the mining company experienced from 1912 to 1923.

column4: Ogden Stockyards Photographs%comma% Memorabilia and Oral HIstories
column6: The Ogden Union Stockyard was a key fixture in the largest livestock market west of Denver during its heyday from 1916 to 1971. The activities at the yard brought Ogden national attention as a livestock center. The rise of the livestock shows%comma% auctions%comma% etc. at the site spurred the local and regional livestock industry%comma% thereby physically shaping the development of the agricultural landscape both near and far.

The Polk Directories for Ogden Utah span from 1870 to 2016. The city directory will contain an alphabetical list of citizens%comma% listing the names of the heads of households%comma% their addresses%comma% and occupational information. Sometimes a wife's name will be listed in parentheses or italics following the husband's. Other helpful information might include death dates for individuals who had been listed in the previous year's directory%comma% names of partners in firms%comma% and forwarding addresses or post offices for people who had moved to another town.

Democrat Cecil D. Andrus (1931- ) served as U.S. Secretary of the Interior from 1977 until 1981 during the Carter administration. He was also elected to the Idaho Senate (1960%comma% 1964%comma% and 1964) and as Governor of Idaho (1970%comma% 1974%comma% 1986%comma% and 1990)%comma% becoming the longest-serving governor in Idaho's history. This collection includes 2%comma%000 photographs from the Cecil D. Andrus Papers (MSS 140) which span his personal and professional life%comma% including his two terms as Governor of Idaho and his term as Secretary of the Interior under President Carter.
Gracie Bowers Pfost's entire collection of materials relating to her service as an Idaho Democratic congressional representative from 1952 to 1962.

column6: The Edward Rhodenbaugh collection contains many photos of scenic Idaho%comma% lantern slides with teaching aids%comma% journals about field trips to geological sites in Idaho and Oregon%comma% and correspondence and manuscripts relating to geology and education.

This collection features historical documents belonging to residents in the Weber%comma% Davis%comma% and Morgan Communities. The items were digitized by Weber State University Stewart Library in support of the "History in Your Attic" project.
A collection of photographic exhibits depicting the historical development of Weber State through student and campus activities.

column4: Roots of Knowledge: Behind the Scenes
column6: On November 18%comma% 2016%comma% in the Bingham Gallery of UVU's Fulton Library%comma% an amazing stained glass windows project was unveiled. Called Roots of Knowledge%comma% it consists of 80 individual stained glass windowpanes%comma% spanning 10 feet in height and 200 feet in length. The project was created by Tom Holdman and the creative artists at the Holdman Studios in Lehi%comma% Utah%comma% and aims to trace%comma% in glass%comma% the development of human knowledge%comma% from the genesis of life on Earth to hope for the future. This digital collection%comma% called The Roots of Knowledge Project: Behind the Scenes%comma% is comprised of photographs taken by staff of the Fulton Library's George Sutherland Archives of the creative process and painstaking work that went on at the Holdman Studios during the construction of these beautiful windows. The steps from start to finish are documented.
column10: Step 01: artist Cameron Oscarson drawing concept art at Holdman Studio.

column6: Mapleton%comma% Utah was founded in conjunction with Springville%comma% Utah on September 18%comma% 1850. It was officially settled in 1856%comma% charting its own course in 1901%comma% and officially incorporated on April 1%comma% 1948. Mapleton%comma% previously known as 'Union Bench' was so-named after the Maple trees in the area. The historical photograph collection showcases the city's growth. From the beginning the land was used for growing grains and crops%comma% and fences kept the animals corralled here. Community members use the nearby cities of Springville and Spanish Fork for their shopping needs. The town finally grew%comma% and the images showcase the strength of those families who persevered and developed the city into what it is today%comma% with its several educational venues%comma% parks%comma% and its stunning agricultural beauty. The area strives to maintain its rural charm. Only one restaurant is located within the city%comma% along with two gas stations. The city currently boasts two stoplights. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the only religious institution in the city.

column4: Cache County Plat Map Photograph Collection
column6: This collection consists of reproductions of 49 original plat maps in Cache and Franklin counties%comma% showing city lots as well as property boundaries for agricultural land. The plats were drawn by Cache County surveyor James Henry (J.H.) Martineau in the 1860s and 1870s. James Henry Martineau (1828-1921) was a Mormon convert who is perhaps best known as a territorial%comma% federal%comma% and railroad (Union Pacific) surveyor. In addition%comma% he was a settler%comma% clerk%comma% cartographer%comma% photographer%comma% and engineer. He completed a variety of surveys in southern Utah before serving as an officer in the Nauvoo legion during the Utah War of 1857-58. In 1860 he settled in Cache Valley%comma% working as the county surveyor and the U.S. deputy internal revenue collector. In 1888 he moved his families to Colonia Juarez in Mexico%comma% although in 1903 he moved back to Salt Lake City. He died on June 24%comma% 1921 in Salt Lake City at the age of ninety-three.
column10: Plat map of Clarkston including Plats A%comma% B and farms. Created by county surveyor James H. Martineau in 1864 and 1874.

column4: Cache Valley Refugee Oral History Project
column6: Cache Valley%comma% Utah is the home of Burmese Muslim%comma% Karen%comma% and Eritrean refugees. Documenting and preserving their stories is an important goal of Utah State University?s Fife Folklore Archives (FFA). In May 2015%comma% USU?s FFA and Folklore Program%comma% with help from the Karen community%comma% hosted a Library of Congress Field School for Cultural Documentation: ?Voices: Refugees in Cache Valley.? Field school students worked to document Cache Valley?s recent refugee communities. This collection%comma% Folk Coll 58: Cache Valley Refugee Oral History Project%comma% houses the physical recordings and associated materials of the interviews which took place during this field school.
column10: Afeworki Woldemichael signing the release form with Berhane Debesai Abraha%comma% May 17%comma% 2015

column4: Agricultural College of Utah Cyanotype Collection
column6: The Agricultural College of Utah Cyanotypes Collection is made up of more than 2%comma%000 cyanotypes (a paper based%comma% bluish colored print) dating from 1896 to 1916. These images document the Agricultural College of Utah (now Utah State University) and show students%comma% faculty%comma% class-room scenes%comma% buildings and grounds%comma% events%comma% experiment stations%comma% athletics%comma% student projects%comma% agriculture%comma% and scenes from around Logan. Because of preservation concerns they were removed from their original USU Agricultural Extension Service scrapbooks. The photographs were taken for documentation and publicity purposes. Many are found in the Experiment Station bulletins%comma% the ACU Catalogs%comma% and other publications. Many of the photographs were taken by George M. Turpin%comma% an professor of Poultry Husbandry from 1909 to 1913. Who took the remainder of the images is unknown.

column4: Von Del Chamberlain Cultural Astronomy Collection
column6: This collection of photographs%comma% slides and diagrams is from Mr. Von Del Chamberlain%comma% whose career has focused on cultural astronomy--a field of study that focuses on the investigation of astronomy from cultures around the world%comma% past and present. The collection includes many rare images of Native American star ceilings%comma% petroglyphs%comma% and structures that reflect their interest in and knowledge of astronomy%comma% as well as those from Egypt%comma% Central America%comma% and the British Isles. Mr. Chamberlain worked at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington%comma% D.C. (1978-84)%comma% where he was chief of the Education and Presentations Division at the National Air and Space Museum. He then returned to his home state of Utah%comma% becoming the director of the Hansen Planetarium in Salt Lake City (1984-96). After retiring from his duties there%comma% he taught classes at Utah Valley State College (1996-2004). He was appointed Scholar in Residence there in 1998%comma% granting him the rank of Associate Professor. Many of these images were used in his classes and feature highlights of his own work and that of his colleagues. Mr. Chamberlain is currently retired and living in Kanab%comma% Utah where he continues to work on publishing articles and books in the field of cultural astronomy.

The first non-Mormon Churches opened in Cache Valley in 1873. They were financed by Protestant faiths that desired to send É??missionariesÉ?ù to Utah%comma% but they found success by exploiting a rift within the Mormon community and because they filled an educational need. Education was barely functional in Cache Valley and these churches created schools with regular hours and even college-educated teachers (a rarity). The story of these early churches was told by former Special CollectionÉ??s Director A.J. Simmonds in The Gentile Comes to Cache Valley (BX 8611 .S5). What is not as well known is that the gentile%comma% in fact%comma% stayed in Cache Valley as many of these churches are still around today. Cache Valley has a surprisingly diverse group of non-Mormon churches. This collection features items concerning the rich and interesting history of these sometimes overlooked religious denominations.
column10: Holy Trinity Lutheran Church%comma% Logan%comma% Utah%comma% 1970

column4: Cache Valley Drug Court Oral History Project
column6: In 2000%comma% Judge Thomas Willmore of Utah?s First District Court%comma% with help from Brock Alder at Bear River Health Department%comma% established a drug court for Cache County: the fifth in Utah. In 2001 they established the drug court in Box Elder County. The concept of drug courts began in 1989 in Miami-Dade County%comma% Florida%comma% in a response to the growing crack cocaine drug problem plaguing Miami. Today there are approximately 1%comma%561 drug courts in the United States. These specialized courts are problem-solving courts bringing together the judiciary%comma% prosecution%comma% defense%comma% adult parole and probation%comma% law enforcement%comma% mental health%comma% social services%comma% treatment communities (like 12-step programs)%comma% and the greater community (including former drug court participants) to aid addicted offenders with long-term recovery as opposed to incarceration. In May 2016%comma% Andrew Dupree%comma% a Cache Valley Drug Court participant (and now graduate)%comma% approached USU Folklore Curator Randy Williams with the idea of partnering on an oral history effort to capture the voices of people involved in the drug court experience. Andrew Dupree attended a May 2015 presentation Williams hosted with students from the USU/Library of Congress Cache Valley Refugee Oral History Project. He wanted people in the drug court community (addicts%comma% Cache Valley Drug Court Committee members%comma% and family members) to have a similar public voice. Together with Jennifer Duncan%comma% Special Collections Librarian%comma% Alder%comma% Andrew Dupree and Williams%comma% launched the Cache Valley Utah Drug Court Oral History Project in November 2016. The project ran from November to May 2017. This collection is the outgrowth of the project and includes 26 interviews%comma% both audio and transcript%comma% with 28 people. Each participant had the opportunity to review their interview transcript. The interviews include the voices of drug court participants and graduates%comma% family members%comma% and professionals associated with drug court. The majority of the interviews were conducted at the Logan Library%comma% the host for the 24 May evening event: ?Voices from Drug Court? that highlighted the project. This project received a grant to support transcription from the Utah Humanities & Utah Division of State History.

column4: Utah Third District Court Salt Lake County Criminal Case Index
column6: This series functions as an index to access the criminal case files and registers of actions. Individual entries record the name of defendants involved in criminal actions and provide the following information: name of the defendant%comma% assigned case number%comma% page number for the corresponding criminal register%comma% and the date of filing with the Court Clerk.

column4: Utah Third District: Salt Lake County Probate Case Files
column6: Case files for Third District Court (Salt Lake County) probate division primarily involve the probate of estates for deceased persons and guardianship for minors and incompetent persons. Probate is judicial oversight of property in transition. Probate of estates is the process by which a deceased person's property is identified and maintained%comma% his debts and taxes paid%comma% and then remaining property distributed to beneficiaries as specified in a will or as required by law for persons who die intestate (without a will). In guardianship cases probate is the establishment of a guardian for minors or incompetent adults who hold property that needs management. In addition to probate these case files also include name changes and some adoptions.

column4: Utah State Historical Society World War Military Listings
column6: The Utah State Historical Society collected and compiled information on Utahns serving in the World Wars. These records consist primarily of lists of Utah men and women killed%comma% wounded%comma% missing%comma% and discharged with overseas service. Assorted correspondence%comma% newspaper clippings%comma% veteran ceremony programs%comma% service questionnaires%comma% and tributes to the dead also are included. The majority of the material pertains to World War II.
column10: Partial list of Utah Army Boys killed in World War 2 up to and including November 19%comma% 1942.

column6: These records contain birth registers recorded during the years 1898 through 1904. Each entry has an assigned number%comma% name of father%comma% name of mother%comma% date of birth%comma% name of child%comma% sex%comma% race%comma% color%comma% residence of parents%comma% and name of informant making the report. Beginning in 1898%comma% physicians and midwives were required to keep record of each birth at which they assisted professionally. In their absence%comma% parents were required to make a report. They then reported quarterly to the county clerk or in the case of incorporated cities%comma% to the local board of health and they would report to the county clerk. (Revised Statutes of Utah 1898%comma% Title 57%comma% p. 474-475) In 1905%comma% the state passed a law requiring each county to file a uniform certificate with the State Bureau of Vital Statistics.
column10: Partial of Register of Births for Cache County Pg.1

column4: Utah State Historical Society Organizational History
column6: Among the most important records in this series are those original documents organizing the Historical Society and defining its purpose. Using this series one can trace the organizational history of the society from its beginning with a "Call to Organize" in 1897%comma% to its designation as a state government agency in 1917%comma% and its continued growth to include the large number of programs it currently supports. Important records of this variety include the original "Call to Organize" printed on July 15%comma% 1897%comma% the original Historical Society charter filed in Salt Lake City on December 31%comma% 1897%comma% and a copy of the Society's original Articles of Incorporation and By-laws from December 28%comma% 1897 which set up the earliest parameters for how the Society would operate.

Butch Cassidy%comma% real name Robert Leroy Parker%comma% was a well-known bank and train robber in the late 1800s. He was born in Beaver%comma% Utah on April 13%comma% 1866. Along with a gang of outlaws known as the "Wild Bunch" he participated in criminal activity all over the American West. This case file represents a Grand Jury indictment for robbery in Castle Gate%comma% Utah in April 1897.

column4: Weber County (Utah) Court Clerk 1850 Census Population Schedule
column6: This series contains a copy of the 1850 United States Census for Weber County on original federal forms%comma% comprised of 28 pages. This census represents the first time that Weber County and the rest of Utah Territory was enumerated by the federal government. The series is significant%comma% in part%comma% because it was previously believed by many that the 1850 census for Utah was only taken on handmade forms and that Utah did not have access to the federal forms. However%comma% these records make it clear that federal forms were available and raise the question of why Utah Territory submitted handmade forms to the Census Bureau.
column10: Weber County (Utah) Court Clerk 1850 Census Population Schedule

column6: These records contain birth registers recorded during the years 1892 through 1897. Each entry has an assigned number%comma% name of father%comma% name of mother%comma% date of birth%comma% name of child%comma% sex%comma% race%comma% color%comma% residence of parents%comma% and name of informant making the report.
column10: Partial Image of Park City (Utah) Birth Register

column4: Second District Court Weber County Index to Civil Actions
column6: This series contains civil case alphabetic indexes created by the Second District Court in Weber County to record the names of the parties involved in civil actions and provide assigned case numbers%comma% facilitating clerical management of and access to the case files. Volumes in the series alternate listings on each page%comma% with the left page listing entries by surname of the plaintiff and the right page by surname of the defendant. Specific information recorded for each case includes the docket number (case number) as well as the corresponding register of action book.
column10: Second District Court Weber County Index to Civil Actions

column6: These are the original building plans created by the capitol architect%comma% Richard Kletting%comma% for the construction of the Capitol Building. The series includes plans for framing%comma% various construction details%comma% columns and stone work%comma% dome framing%comma% foundation and footings%comma% cross sections%comma% and building elevations from various angles. The originals are blueprints%comma% blueprints on linen%comma% and tracings.
column10: Capitol Commission Capitol Building Plans: First Floor Framing Plans

column4: Capitol Commission Capitol Design Competition Renderings
column6: In order to select an architect to design Utah's State Capitol building%comma% the Capitol Commission sponsored a design competition. Architects who wished to participate were required to demonstrate that they possessed the necessary expertise by submitting examples of their work. Those that were approved to participate received a Program of Competition outlining the rules of the competition and the design program for the proposed capitol.
column10: Capitol Commission Capitol Design Competition Rendering

column6: This series documents public relations efforts by the Capitol Commission and public opinion regarding the building of the state capitol. It contains newspaper clippings collected by the Capitol Commission with the bulk of the series focusing on articles addressing the design competition for the capitol building%comma% arguments for and against construction%comma% location issues%comma% calls for voter participation%comma% messages from Governor Spry%comma% and highlights from the construction process such as the laying of the cornerstone.
column10: Capitol Commission Newspaper Clippings%comma% "What Governor Spry Says about the Proposition to Build a Capitol

column6: This series contains the minutes of the Utah Capitol Commission's formal meetings and function as a record of members present at meetings%comma% outside consultants%comma% expenses incurred by commission members%comma% rules for the design competition%comma% discussions about bids and the issuing of contracts%comma% agreements for expenditures%comma% and a list of the original cornerstone contents.

This series contains photographs which functioned as documentation of the construction of the State Capitol. The majority of the series contains pictures of the finished capitol building%comma% ground breaking ceremony%comma% initial excavation of the construction site%comma% and individuals involved in the construction process. The collection also holds a unique commemorative photograph album produced by Shipler's Commercial Photographs of Salt Lake City which was presented to commission members.

This report is an account of the monies used to build the State Capitol Complex. The report contains specific construction details and land procurement operations. The 1915-1916 edition includes more specific design expenditures and a small history of the construction. Pictures of various stages are also included.

column4: Utah Department of Health Sheep Radiation Studies
column6: The records in this series include correspondence%comma% memorandum%comma% meeting minutes%comma% photographs%comma% and reports from the various investigators and agencies involved with the sheep death investigations that took place in Cedar City in 1953 and 1954. The study papers and compiled reports found here were collected by the Utah Department of Health%comma% and highlight the questions surrounding radioactive fallout from the Nevada Test Site and its contributing role in the heavy losses of sheep in 1953 among herds that were wintered in areas downwind of the site.
column10: Utah Department of Health Sheep Radiation Studies

column4: Ogden (Utah) Police Arrest and Jail Record Books
column6: This series contains various record books documenting arrests made%comma% and prisoners held%comma% by the Ogden City Police Department. Arrest Record Books and Record of Prisoners Books include: name of person arrested%comma% name of arresting officer%comma% time and place of arrest%comma% charge%comma% and fine or punishment given. The Criminal Record Books and Prisoner Identification Records document individuals held by the police department and may include a prisoner number%comma% mug shot%comma% and the prisoner's physical description.
column10: Ogden (Utah) Police Arrest and Jail Record Books

column4: Salt Lake City (Utah) School Children's Constitution and Flag Monument Books
column6: This series contains two books compiled by the school district to document and commemorate the erection of the School Children's Constitution and Flag Monument on the west side of Washington Square in front of the Salt Lake City and County Building. The monument was completed in 1937 and included a flag pole with a sculpture of two children with the United States Constitution standing at the base%comma% and one of the children pointing up toward the flag. School children donated money to fund the monument and local children acted as models for the sculpture. In 1936 each school in the city compiled a list of students and what occupation each aspired to when they grew up. These lists were sealed in a time capsule in the monument when it was dedicated in 1937.%newline%The books in this series were compiled after the time capsule was opened in 1952. They include copies of newspaper articles about the erection of the monument and photographs of the dedication in 1937 and the opening of the time capsule in 1952. They also contain documentation of efforts to erect a flag pole not only at the City and County Building%comma% but at each school in the district as well.
column10: Salt Lake City (Utah) School Children's Constitution and Flag Monument Books

column4: Utah Second District Court John D. Lee Criminal Case File
column6: Case files document criminal cases as they proceed through the court system and subsequently become the official files of individual cases. Case 31 is the John D. Lee trial concerning his involvement in the 1857 Mountain Meadows Massacre.
column10: Utah Second District Court John D. Lee Criminal Case File

column6: These are phonetic (Soundex) indices to birth certificates used to locate the records. The indices were compiled by the Works Projects Administration in the 1930s. Arrangement is by Soundex code number. Within an individual code number%comma% volumes are indexed by the father's first given name. The information includes the child's name%comma% the mother's maiden name%comma% the child's sex and birth date%comma% the county of birth%comma% the file number%comma% the cross index name%comma% and the father's name.
