column6: These are phonetic (Soundex) indices to birth certificates used to locate the records. The indices were compiled by the Works Projects Administration in the 1930s. Arrangement is by Soundex code number. Within an individual code number%comma% volumes are indexed by the father's first given name. The information includes the child's name%comma% the mother's maiden name%comma% the child's sex and birth date%comma% the county of birth%comma% the file number%comma% the cross index name%comma% and the father's name.
column10: Weber County (Utah) Clerk Dentistry and Optometry Board Certificates

column6: These papers document the administration and activities of various segments of the territorial militia%comma% also known as the Nauvoo Legion. They were brought together by archives staff in the late 1950s and early 1960s in an effort to collect all documents about Utah veterans from any source and to serve as a state repository for those documents.%newline%The Military Records Center acquired the documents from the late 1950s into the early 1960s%comma% rearranging and grouping them by document type%comma% date%comma% and/or military district. Indexes were prepared for most of the correspondence%comma% but plans to index all documents were never completed.

column4: Cache Valley Drug Court Oral History Project
column6: In 2000%comma% Judge Thomas Willmore of Utah's First District Court%comma% with help from Brock Alder at Bear River Health Department%comma% established a drug court for Cache County: the fifth in Utah. In 2001 they established the drug court in Box Elder County. The concept of drug courts began in 1989 in Miami-Dade County%comma% Florida%comma% in a response to the growing crack cocaine drug problem plaguing Miami. Today there are approximately 1%comma%561 drug courts in the United States. These specialized courts are problem-solving courts bringing together the judiciary%comma% prosecution%comma% defense%comma% adult parole and probation%comma% law enforcement%comma% mental health%comma% social services%comma% treatment communities (like 12-step programs)%comma% and the greater community (including former drug court participants) to aid addicted offenders with long-term recovery as opposed to incarceration.%newline%In May 2016%comma% Andrew Dupree%comma% a Cache Valley Drug Court participant (and now graduate)%comma% approached USU Folklore Curator Randy Williams with the idea of partnering on an oral history effort to capture the voices of people involved in the drug court experience. Andrew Dupree attended a May 2015 presentation Williams hosted with students from the USU/Library of Congress Cache Valley Refugee Oral History Project. He wanted people in the drug court community (addicts%comma% Cache Valley Drug Court Committee members%comma% and family members) to have a similar public voice. Together with Jennifer Duncan%comma% Special Collections Librarian%comma% Alder%comma% Andrew Dupree and Williams%comma% launched the Cache Valley Utah Drug Court Oral History Project in November 2016.%newline%The project ran from November to May 2017. This collection is the outgrowth of the project and includes 26 interviews%comma% both audio and transcript%comma% with 28 people. Each participant had the opportunity to review their interview transcript. The interviews include the voices of drug court participants and graduates%comma% family members%comma% and professionals associated with drug court. The majority of the interviews were conducted at the Logan Library%comma% the host for the 24 May evening event: "Voices from Drug Court" that highlighted the project.%newline%This project received a grant to support transcription from the Utah Humanities & Utah Division of State History.
column10: Cache Valley Drug Court Oral History Project

column6: The American Folklore Society (AFS) is a scholarly association that exists to further the discipline of folklore studies. The society was founded in Boston in 1888 by such luminaries as Francis James Child%comma% William Wells Newell%comma% Daniel Garrison Brinton%comma% and Franz Boas%comma% with its principal emphasis directed toward the publication of a scientific journal and the convening of an annual meeting.%newline%Generations of scholarly theories and approaches are reflected in the society's publications%comma% including the Journal of American Folklore (JAF)%comma% which has been published quarterly since 1888. It includes articles%comma% notes%comma% and commentaries; reviews of publications%comma% films and videotapes%comma% audio recordings%comma% and exhibitions and events; and obituaries. The society has also published bimonthly newsletter since 1971. This publication carries official news and reports of the society's business%comma% as well as a wide range of information relevant to the field generally. Regular features include listings of academic meetings%comma% publication news%comma% job notices%comma% grant announcements%comma% a cooperation column%comma% prizes%comma% and information on electronic media. Since 2009 these functions have been carried out by the AFS Review%comma% an electronic newsletter distributed via email and hosted on the AFS website.%newline%The society's annual meeting takes place in October in cities throughout the continental United States and occasionally Canada. The five-day gathering offers panels%comma% forums and workshops%comma% film and video screenings%comma% book exhibitions%comma% special events%comma% and tours of folklorist interest. The society offers several prizes to honor outstanding work in African American folklore studies%comma% public folklore%comma% and Francophone folklore studies.%newline%Additionally%comma% sections of the AFS%comma% which are interest groups of society members%comma% offer separate prizes. In 1995%comma% there were approximately thirty such sections%comma% addressing folklore genres (such as dance%comma% folk arts%comma% folk belief%comma% folk narrative%comma% foodways%comma% and music)%comma% folklore of particular folk groups (such as African%comma% American Indian%comma% Baltic%comma% British%comma% Catholic%comma% children%comma% gay and lesbian%comma% Italian%comma% Jewish%comma% Latino%comma% occupational%comma% and women)%comma% and professional issues (such as computer applications%comma% graduate students%comma% journals%comma% social justice%comma% and public programs). Sections meet at the annual meeting. Many of them sponsor sessions%comma% offer prizes%comma% and issue newsletters or journals of their own.%newline%AFS is governed by an executive board composed of nine members plus the president and the president-elect%comma% as set forth in the society�s by-laws. An executive secretary-treasurer is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the society's business. The society's papers and records are archived at Utah State University's Special Collections & Archives (USU SCA). As records become inactive%comma% AFS will transfer them to USU SCA. These materials are then indexed and made available for research. Included in the collection are correspondence%comma% memorandums%comma% financial records%comma% membership records%comma% meeting agendas%comma% conferences%comma% notes%comma% questionnaires%comma% surveys%comma% election records%comma% by-laws%comma% applications%comma% grants%comma% committee records%comma% and affiliate records. With the increased use of electronic communication at the turn of the 21st century%comma% many of these records have transitioned from paper-based to born-digital. USU SCA continues to host the paper materials in onsite archival storage while this digital collection serves as the access point for born-digital materials.

column4: Cache Daughters of Utah Pioneers Museum Collection
column6: The Cache Daughters of Utah Pioneers Museum honors the pioneers who came to Utah and settled Cache Valley before 1869. It is the Museum's mission to honor that legacy by sharing the artifacts%comma% histories and photos of those pioneers. The Museum operates under the direction of the International Society Daughters of Utah Pioneers.%newline%The portraits in this digital collection represent pioneers from around the world who came to Utah. The portraits depict early settlers of Cache Valley%comma% Utah%comma% prominent business leaders in Cache County%comma% and early leaders of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. They also depict community organizations in Cache Valley%comma% including local bands%comma% fire departments%comma% the Cache Stake/Logan Tabernacle Choir%comma% and Logan Temple workers. %newline%Funding for the digitization of these materials was provided%comma% in part%comma% by a grant from the Utah State Historical Records Advisory Board (USHRAB).
column10: Cache Daughters of Utah Pioneers Museum Collection

column6: The U.S. Presidential Election Reflections collection launched on 20 January 2017%comma% just in time for the United States presidential inauguration. This social media collecting project boasts 233 reflections about the 2016 presidential election results. The collection project began the day after the election and ran for one month. The respondents are from 27 U.S. states and four foreign countries.%newline%The 2016 presidential election exposed the depths of a political divide for much of the country and the world was watching. Whether people were encouraged or discouraged by the election results%comma% USU Special Collections (SCA) curators wanted to collect the reflections of this momentous national event. It is important for future generations to know what people were thinking and feeling.%newline%The social media collecting project is a first for the USU Library. It was conceived and created the day after the election as the world watched social media "blow up" with personal reflections on the election results. It seemed important to collect and preserve these reflections%comma% and fast.%newline%Using social media to promote the project%comma% SCA curators and USU librarians used Qualtrics software to create a survey that would allow interested participants to add their social media reflection to the project. The survey was open from 9 November to 9 December 2016. Those who contributed to the project were able to do so quickly and all online. Survey respondents were asked to share their thoughts on the election and had the option to provide additional information about themselves.%newline%Information provided in the survey results helped USU librarians organize the collection and will allow others to be able to study how reactions varied in different locations or between men and women%comma% etc.%newline%Although the project received responses from around the world%comma% the Library collected the reflections as a part of its mission to gather the voices and perspectives of members of Northern Utah communities. SCA hopes to do this for coming presidential elections%comma% and possibly state elections. Future researchers seeking to understand the diversity of the political culture of Utah will require more than vote counts. Like tiles in a mosaic%comma% each voice adds shape and dimension to our national identity.

column4: Jackson Hole Dude Ranching Tradition: Triangle X 2017
column6: In 1926%comma% John S. "Dad" and Maytie Turner relocated from Utah to Wyoming and purchased the Triangle X Ranch%comma% becoming the first generation of Turners on the ranch. Located in the eastern part of the Valley (near Moose)%comma% the ranch boasts sweeping views of the Grand Teton mountain range. The Turners welcomed their first guest on the Triangle X the next spring. In 1930%comma% the Turners (along with many others in the Jackson Hole area) sold their property to the Snake River Land Company and leased back the ranch. In 1950%comma% the ranch was incorporated into Grand Teton National Park (GTNP) when Laurence Rockefeller donated his Snake River holdings to the existing park.%newline%Dad and Maytie Turner's oldest son%comma% John Charles Turner (second generation)%comma% took over the ranch when other family members moved to the Buffalo River to begin new dude ranching ventures. A skilled marksman%comma% John introduced hunting camps to the Triangle X. He married the dynamic Louise Mapes and together they grew the Triangle X into a thriving dude ranch. Their three sons Harold Mapes Turner%comma% John Freeland Turner%comma% and Donald Mapes Turner (third generation) inherited the ranch. They grew up on the ranch%comma% learning the impressive �Turner hospitality� from their parents%comma% and with their wives%comma% Berniece%comma% Mary Kay and Anne%comma% they expertly stewarded the ranch and the land.%newline%Today%comma% Robert Turner (Harold's son) and Lucas Turner (Don's son)%comma% the fourth generation%comma% manage the ranch (with support from Harold and John F.). Along with their wives%comma% Amanda and Lauren%comma% and children (fifth generation)%comma% and during the summers some of their siblings%comma% cousins%comma% and nieces and nephews%comma% Robert and Lucas continue the tradition of welcoming guests at the Triangle X for trail rides%comma% pack trips%comma% hunting trips%comma% and float trips. As managers of the oldest and only operating dude ranch in the GTNP%comma% the Turner family has hosted guests (some for over forty years!) at the Triangle X for more than ninety years.%newline%In the summer of 2017%comma% the Turners graciously welcomed eight Utah State University and three University of Wyoming students to document the historic Triangle X as part of a Library of Congress Field School for Cultural Documentation. The Field School is a collaboration between Utah State University (USU)%comma% the University of Wyoming%comma% and the American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress (LOC). In 2015%comma% USU partnered with the LOC to host a field school to collect the oral histories of Cache Valley Utah refugee community members. %newline%This collection houses the products from the Triangle X fieldwork%comma% including 23 interviews (audio%comma% full transcripts%comma% and photographs) with members of the Turner family (third%comma% fourth%comma% and fifth generations)%comma% Triangle X employees%comma% and guests. Also included are photographs from events%comma% buildings at the ranch%comma% and the field school.
column10: Jackson Hole Dude Ranching Tradition: Triangle X 2017

column4: Logan Public Library - Logan%comma% Utah Digital Collection
column6: The Logan Public Library has spent considerable amount of time collecting images related to the architectural landscape of the city over time. We are proud to offer a collection of some of these photographs combined with other materials related to the history of Logan%comma% Utah. %newline%This digital collection begun with a grant from the Digital Public Library of America's Public Library Partnership Project and the Mountain West Library Digital Services grants.
column10: Logan Public Library - Logan%comma% Utah Digital Collection

column6: Orson Ferguson Whitney was born in Salt Lake City%comma% Utah%comma% on Sunday%comma% July 1%comma% 1855. His father%comma% Horace Kimball Whitney was the eldest son of Newel Kimball Whitney%comma% the second Presiding Bishop of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. His mother%comma% Helen Mar Whitney%comma% was the eldest daughter of Heber Chase Kimball%comma% one of the original Twelve Apostles and later a member of the First Presidency of the LDS Church.%newline%Early in Orson F. Whitney's life%comma% he was educated in the common schools of Salt Lake City and worked for the Union Pacific Railroad. Thereafter he attended the University of Deseret%comma% now the University of Utah. His final year at the University (1873-1874) was followed by a one-year mission for the LDS Church in October of 1876. During the spring of 1877%comma% Elder Whitney went alone to Northern Ohio%comma% preaching%comma% baptizing%comma% studying the gospel%comma% and writing for the Salt Lake Herald. Whitney returned to Utah in the spring of 1878%comma% arriving home on the first day of April. Two weeks later he was employed by the Deseret News. In August of 1878 he was promoted to city editor of the Deseret News.%newline%On July 14%comma% 1878%comma% Orson F. Whitney was made bishop of the Salt Lake City 18th ward. During that winter (1878-1879) Bishop Whitney went on a preaching tour of Cache Valley%comma% Utah. In the fall of the following year%comma% on December 18%comma% 1879%comma% Whitney married Miss Zine Beal Smoot of Provo%comma% Utah. Over the course of their twenty-year marriage Zine bore Orson nine children; Horace Newel (1880)%comma% Emily (1885)%comma% Helen Margaret (1887)%comma% Margaret (1889)%comma% Charles Byron (1891)%comma% Albert Owen (1893)%comma% the twins'vPaul Van Cott and Virginia Clayton (1899)%comma% and Heber Kimball (1899).%newline%In February of 1880%comma% a year-and-a half after their marriage%comma% Orson F. Whitney was called on a LDS mission to Europe to labor in the editorial department of the Millennial Star in Liverpool. While on this mission%comma% Whitney's second son Heber Kimball died%comma% whom he had never seen. Whitney labored in England for three-and-a-half years%comma% until his return home to Salt Lake City on July 7%comma% 1883.%newline%Upon his return%comma% Whitney resumed his position at the Desert News%comma% but later resigned in December of 1884 to become the city treasurer. He was reelected every two years until 1890. During this time%comma% and perhaps in secret%comma% on July 24%comma% 1888%comma% in Colonia Diaz%comma% Mexico%comma% Orson took a second wife by marrying Mary Minerva Wells of Salt Lake City. Residing together at various time in Logan%comma% Utah%comma% they had two children; Murray Wells (1892) and Wendell Webb (1895). In 1896 Whitney accepted the chair of philosophy at Brigham Young College in Logan were he resided until July of 1897.%newline%On May 20%comma% 1900%comma% at the age of 41%comma% Zine Beal Smoot Whitney died%comma% leaving eight children in the care of her husband and his second wife Mary. Later that year%comma% on October 11%comma% 1900%comma% Orson and Mary were remarried in the Salt Lake Temple. In 1901 Orson served in the state legislature pushing for the adoption of the Evan's Bill%comma% a bill that sought to grant legal protection for plural marriages that occurred before statehood. In 1907 Orson was ordained a member of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles%comma% a high calling within the LDS church. Thereafter%comma% his spiritual profession required him to travel a great deal%comma% often to various towns and cities across the United States.%newline%Over the course of Orson's public career he published many articles and books%comma% among them; Baptism- The Birth of Water and of Spirit%comma% The Strength of the Mormon Position%comma% Voices From the Mountains%comma% Gospel Themes: a Treatise on Salient Features of Mormons%comma% Popular History of Utah%comma% History of Utah%comma% The Life of Heber C. Kimball%comma% and Through Memory' Halls; The Life Story of Orson F. Whitney. In addition to publishing%comma% during the 1920s Orson delivered spiritual lectures that were broadcasted live on Sunday evenings over KSL radio%comma% Salt Lake City.%newline%On May 16%comma% 1931%comma% Orson F. Whitney died at the age of 76. Mary M. Whitney died four years later on January 25%comma% 1935.%newline%This six box collection consists of photocopies of Orson F. Whitney's diaries from 1877-1931%comma% a handwritten autobiography%comma% a notebook%comma% and an account book. An inventory of this collection and further information can be found at : http://nwda.orbiscascade.org/ark:/80444/xv04257.

In 2010 the Swaner Preserve and EcoCenter (Snyderville Basin%comma% Park City%comma% Utah) was donated to Utah State University%comma% making it the largest gift in USU history. Known to native peoples as the "Hole in the Sky%comma%" the preserve encompasses a 1%comma%200-acre wildlife preserve and state of the art environmental education facility. The dream of the preserve started in 1992%comma% when Dr. Paula Swaner and her children pursued a way to honor their late husband and father Leland Swaner; ; and culminated in the impressive, one-of-a-kind preserve in the high desert. In 2015, USU Special Collections was given the opportunity to document the family�s legacy story. This collection comprises of five interviews with Swaner family members. The finding aid for this collection is found at http://archiveswest.orbiscascade.org/ark:/80444/xv46444. Visit the Swaner Preserve and EcoCenter website http://www.swanerecocenter.org/.

column4: Utah Federal Resettlement Project Oral Histories
column6: These oral histories are related to the Federal Resettlement Project in Utah%comma% which was part of a broader New Deal resettlement project in the United States during the Great Depression. The program sought to make better use of the nation's natural resources by reassigning poor farmers from marginal to productive land. The undertaking was supervised by various governmental departments including the Federal Emergency Relief Administration%comma% the Resettlement Administration%comma% and the Farms Security Administration from the 1930s until the early 1940s.%newline%This collection contains 11 oral histories pertaining to the Federal Resettlement Project and the Great Depression in Utah. Brian Q. Cannon conducted these oral histories for his 1986 master's thesis%comma% Remaking the Agrarian Dream: The New Deal's Rural Resettlement Program in the Mountain West. These recordings include interviews about the Green River Drought Pumping Project; resettlement in Benmore%comma% Utah; resettlement in Widtsoe%comma% Utah; and the Leota Bottoms Drought Pumping Project. There is a finding aid for this collection.%newline%Funding for the digitization of these materials was provided%comma% in part%comma% by the Utah Department of Heritage and Arts.
column10: Utah Federal Resettlement Project Oral Histories

column4: Utah State University Statesman Photograph Collection
column6: The USU Statesman is a student-run campus newspaper. The USU Statesman Photograph Collection consists of mostly black and white prints and 35mm negatives of various activities relating to Utah State University. Included are images of sports%comma% student activities%comma% buildings%comma% ROTC%comma% and USU faculty and staff. The photographs in this collection were taken between 1975 and 1999 for the USU Statesman by student photographers such as Mike Slade%comma% Eli Lucero%comma% and Darin Oswald.
column10: Utah State University Statesman Photograph Collection

column6: Willie Ottogary was a farmer and performed many duties as a Shoshone chief%comma% but he is most well known in the "white world" for his letters which appeared regularly in The Journal (a Logan%comma% Utah Newspaper) from 1909-1929. According to historian Matthew Kreitzer:%newline%"He [Ottogary] wrote over 400 letters during a literary career spanning 23 years. His letters appeared most often in The Journal%comma% but he also was published in the Tremont Times%comma% Oneida County Enterprise%comma% and the Box Elder Journal. Willie's columns reflected a wide range of topics such as agriculture%comma% the LDS Church [Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints]%comma% his travels%comma% the comings and goings of his people%comma% land issues%comma% hunting and gathering%comma% Sun Dances%comma% social activities%comma% sports%comma% special occasions%comma% economic development%comma% life-cycle events%comma% and new technological innovations. He kept the pulse of Washakie and accurately reported his perceptions of the things that%comma% he believed%comma% mattered most. (Kreitzer 57)"%newline%Willie was the son of O-Ti-Cot-i%comma% who later changed his name to Peter Otahgary after his conversion to the LDS Church. Though his birth date is uncertain%comma% he was baptized a member of the LDS Church on August 1%comma% 1875. He married twice and fathered three children who survived to adulthood. Beginning as early as 1915%comma% Ottogary was chief of the Shoshone at Washakie%comma% the name of the land in Box Elder County%comma% Utah%comma% allotted by the LDS Church for the settling of the converted Shoshone. Ottogary died in March of 1929.%newline%The Willie Ottogary Collection includes copies of newspaper articles from the The Journal (1909-1929)%comma% Box Elder Journal (1925)%comma% and the Oneida County Enterprise (1924). These articles are letters written by Willie Ottogary to the various newspapers describing the events and well-being of the Shoshone people in Washakie. Also included in this collection are some copies of later correspondence (1929-1959) dealing with efforts to establish a reservation for the Shoshone in Idaho. In addition to the digital collection%comma% there is a finding aid available online.

The Ken Gray Insect Image Collection consists of prints and negatives depicting various types of insects at their larval and adult stages.%newline%In his capacity as a pest specialist with the Pacific Supply Cooperative of Portland%comma% Ken Gray photographed insects as part of a project to create a library of images. Assisted by OSU entomologists in the identification of insects%comma% Gray donated these images to the OSU Extension Service in the mid-1970s. In a project funded by the Environmental Protection Agency%comma% the OSU Extension Service generated slides from 4300 of the Gray insect images and marketed them as aids in the certification of pesticide applicators to university entomology departments.

The Illustrated Booklets were published by Oregon Agricultural College (OAC) during the 1910s and 1920s to promote and publicize the College to potential students and Oregon residents%comma% and to provide vocational guidance to youth and young adults. This digital collection includes 29 booklets.

The Oregon State University Yearbooks digital collection includes 111 yearbooks published by the students of Oregon State University%comma% beginning with the 1894 Hayseed. This keyword-searchable digital collection is a major resource for study of Oregon State�s campus history and culture in the twentieth century.

The Angelus Studio was a professional photographic company located in Portland%comma% Oregon. The collection includes works by George M. Weister (1862�1922) and Arthur M. Prentiss (dates undetermined) among the studio photographers
column7: owner Fred Clark also acquired images by previous local photographers including Partridge. The Angelus Studio collection provides extraordinary documentation of the city of Portland%comma% the Lewis & Clark Exposition of 1905%comma% Oregon landmarks%comma% and commercial operations including logging and fish packing.

column6: Trained as a pictorialist by Clarence White%comma% Doris Ulmann�s early work includes a series of photograph portraits of prominent intellectuals%comma% artists and writers: William Butler Yeats%comma% John Dewey%comma% Max Eastman%comma% Sinclair Lewis%comma% Lewis Mumford%comma% Joseph Wood Krutch%comma% Martha Graham%comma% Anna Pavlova%comma% Paul Robeson%comma% and Lillian Gish. In 1932 Ulmann began her most important series%comma% assembling documentation of Appalachian folk arts and crafts for Allen Eaton�s 1937 book%comma% Handicrafts of the Southern Highlands. From 1927%comma% Ulmann was assisted on her rural travels by John Jacob Niles%comma% a musician and folklorist who collected ballads while Ulmann photographed. Doris Ulmann died August 28%comma% 1934.

column6: Major Lee Moorhouse of Pendleton%comma% Oregon was an Indian Agent for the Umatilla Indian Reservation and a photographer. From 1888 to 1916 he produced over 9%comma%000 images which document urban%comma% rural%comma% and Native American life in the Columbia Basin%comma% and particularly Umatilla County%comma% Oregon. So extensive and revealing are Moorhouse�s images that his collection is one of the preeminent social history collections for Oregon. Special Collections & University Archives of the University of Oregon Libraries has a collection of 7000 images by Major Moorhouse.
column10: A black-and-white photograph of a Native American man%comma% identified as Alexander%comma% Yakima Indian

column6: The entire photograph collection of Frank and Bethine Church%comma% spanning their young adult years in Boise%comma% Idaho%comma% 1940-1943%comma% the early political career of Frank as Idaho Legislature%comma% 1952-1956%comma% and U.S. Senator%comma% 1958-1980%comma% and Bethine's involvement in social and environmental issue in the 1990s to 2010. The majority of the photographs document the many campaigns%comma% political events in Washington D.C. and around the world%comma% and daily work as a U.S. Senator. Church's involvment in foreign relations is well documented in photographs%comma% as well as his work with other various Senate committees.
column10: Frank Church%comma% Bethine Church%comma% Forrest in Sun Valley%comma% Idaho with Chase and Jean Clark.

column6: Pete Cenarrusa was born in Carey, Idaho, on December 16, 1917. His parents, Jose (Joe) Marie Zenarruzabeitia and Ramona Gardoqui, were immigrants from the Basque Country. They met and were married in Shoshone, Idaho, and established a successful sheep business based in Carey. They had five children all of whom were raised speaking Basque, later learning English in public school. Upon graduation from high school, Pete Cenarrusa attended to the University of Idaho, where he was a member of the University�s boxing team. He graduated with a bachelor�s degree in agriculture in 1940 and then moved to Cambridge, Idaho where he taught agricultural sciences and coached various sports. After the bombing of Pearl Harbor, Pete enlisted in the Navy, eventually becoming a Marine naval aviator and training other enlistees during World War II. He retired from the reserves as a major in 1963.%newline%After the war Cenarrusa returned to his native south central Idaho and taught farming methods throughout Blaine County. During this time he was also a key figure in the building of Carey�s airport, which was dedicated by President Truman, who happened to be in Idaho at the time. Cenarrusa married Freda Coates in October 1947. They had one son, Joe. In 1949 he was persuaded to run for the House of Representatives, and won in 1950 running on the Republican ticket. While working as a legislator, Cenarrusa also helped operate his family�s sheep business in Carey. He was elected to his seat in the House for nine consecutive terms, and served as Speaker of the House from 1963-1967. In 1967, Governor Samuelson nominated Cenarrusa to finish the term of Secretary of State Edison Deal, who had died in office. Then Cenarrusa ran for and successfully won the position in the general election in 1970. He was reelected seven times, retiring in 2002. Among his many duties as Secretary of State, Cenarrusa served as a member of the State Land Board and was chief elections officer for the state of Idaho. Cenarrusa�s fifty-two years of service as legislator and Secretary of State makes him one of the longest-serving public officials in the United States.%newline%Throughout his life Pete Cenarrusa was dedicated to promoting the Basque cause and helping Basque communities and immigrants. In 1970 he was influential in getting Generalissimo Francisco Franco to commute the death sentences of 16 Basque citizens accused of murdering a Spanish government official. Cenarrusa initiated three memorials in the Idaho State Legislature in support of Basque rights and autonomy, the first in 1972, with two others following in 2002 and 2006. Cenarrusa also worked to promote an end to all political violence within the Basque Country, as well as Basque education, helping in the establishment ikastolas, Basque preschools. In 2001, the Sabino Arana Foundation in the Basque Country honored Cenarrusa as a �Basque of the World.� Cenarrusa has promoted Basque culture within his home state, contributing both time and money to the various institutions, such as the Basque Museum and Cultural Center in Boise. In 2005, Cenarrusa formed the Cenarrusa Center for Basque Studies (now the Cenarrusa Foundation for Basque Culture). The Center has a program at Boise State University, where students can earn a Basque Studies minor. Pete Cenarrusa continues to work as a spokesperson for the Basque people and to end violence within the Basque Country.%newline%Sketch by Olivia Umphrey, 2007%newline%Photos, clippings, articles and some emphemera from the life and career of Pete T. Cenarrusa, Idaho�s longest serving public official.
column10: Pete Cenarrusa%comma% right%comma% at a Basque festival in Boise's Basque Block with Alan Virta and Jim Duran from the Boise State University Library%comma% Special Collections and Archives.

column6: Florence M. Hartshorn (1869-1943) was a photographer who lived in the Yukon during the gold rush. The collection consists of an album and loose prints made by Mrs. Hartshorn and her husband%comma% documenting the landscape of the region%comma% entrepreneurs and residents.
column10: Mr. Hartshorn%comma% Hazel Hartshorn%comma% and another child at the entrance of a mine.

column6: Clarence L. Andrews (1862-1948) documented and collected documentation on native life%comma% natural resources%comma% and exploration of Alaska and the Yukon. The collection (1805-1948) consists of approximately 1600 prints and 75 negatives by more than 60 photographers%comma% dealing almost exclusively with Alaska and the Yukon. Main subjects include the towns of Sitka%comma% Skagway%comma% Eagle%comma% and Valdez
column7: modes of transportation%comma% from reindeer and dogs to railroads%comma% ships%comma% and kayaks

column6: Charles Wellington Furlong (1874-1967) was an explorer%comma% writer and scientist who documented his adventures in publications and notebooks and well as in photographs. The Furlong photographs include copies of his artwork%comma% ethnographical evidence%comma% historical events and personalities%comma% and remote corners of the world.
column10: Bonnie McCarroll at the Pendleton Round Up

column6: Dan Powell is an Associate Professor and Head of the Photography Program in the Department of Art at the University of Oregon%comma% and has shown his work extensively both on the national and international level. As an artist%comma% his work includes constructed imagery done in the studio as well as social landscape and physical landscape imagery ranging from such diverse areas as Eastern Oregon and the Western United States to New York City and various European Countries. Typically%comma% his work is interpretive and expressive in nature.

column6: Orla G. Allen (dates unknown)%comma% commonly known as O.G. Allen%comma% was a professional photographer operating in Pendleton%comma% Oregon%comma% circa 1910-1920. "Electric Studio" is a franchise name that appeared in locations throughout the West. The collection documents rodeo people and activities%comma% and a Pendleton event. Unknown. Possibly a donation from Lee D. Drake of Pendleton.
column10: John Thomas fighting a bull at the Pendleton Round Up

column6: Grayson Layne Mathews (1948-2007) photographed the American West%comma% creating a signature series of rodeo images from 1971�-72 through funding from an NEA fellowship. Following a successful career in freelance photography and university instructor in California%comma% South Carolina and Virginia%comma% he returned home to Klamath Falls%comma% Oregon and documented natural and human transformation of the Klamath Basin landscape. The collection includes darkroom and digital prints.
column10: A rodeo clown sits on a fence with a hand raised towards the camera.

column6: James Cloutier is a native Oregonian artist and photographer who began his study of art at the University of Oregon in 1958 and went on to earn an MFA. His drawings and photographs document the history of culture in Oregon%comma% often with humourous twists%comma% such as can be found in his illustrated map of Eugene%comma% Oregon incorporating more than 300 local businesses with cartoon imagery. The images in the University of Oregon Library�s collection feature the people of the small town of Alpine%comma% Oregon from his 1977 book.
column10: Two women visit inside the Alpine Tavern.

column6: Eugene Photographer John Bauguess documented downtown Eugene during a period of urban renewal in the 1970s. Of this work%comma% Bauguess writes: �When I photographed downtown Eugene in the Urban Renewal era of early 1970s%comma% it was home to long-time residents and shop owners%comma% as well as many artists who had rented vacated buildings for studios. When the buildings were torn down%comma% most of the people were gone%comma% never to return. Some did reappear%comma% however%comma% rediscovered three decades later in photographic prints I made from negatives retrieved from dusty boxes. Photographic memories of these people had aged like good wine.�
column10: Black and white image of a man identified as Herb seated at a table at the Brass Rail tavern with a beer in his hand. Other men and women are standing behind him in the background.

column6: Lee D. Drake (1882-1957) was a newspaper owner and civic booster in Pendleton and Astoria%comma% Oregon. The collection includes Drake's amateur work and that of professional photographers from the Pendleton region%comma% capturing images of the Pendleton Round-up%comma% tribal peoples of the region%comma% and Drake friends and family.
column10: A smiling woman in Native American attire holds a sleeping baby that is secured in a cradleboard.

column6: Walter S. Bowman (1865-1938) was a professional photographer who worked in Pendleton%comma% Oregon%comma% from the late 1880s to the mid 1930s. Bowman's photographs document daily life in Eastern Oregon%comma% including special events such as the Pendleton Roundup.
column10: Interior view of William S. Bowman's commercial studio.

column6: Frazier Augustus Boutelle (1840-1924) served in the US Army for 57 years%comma% fighting in the Civil War%comma% in Indian wars%comma% and working as a recruiter in World War I. In 1889-1990 he was Superintendent of Yellowstone National Park. The collection consists of documentation of Boutelle's career: military scenes of the Indian Wars from 1870s to 1890s%comma% images from the Philippines from 1898 to 1899%comma% and the Yellowstone area 1889-1890.
column10: Group at the Great Fountain%comma% Sept. 20%comma% 1890. [Two men and two women on horseback.

column4: Lesbian Intentional Community: Ruth Mountaingrove (b.1923) photographs
column6: Ruth Mountaingrove (1923- ) is a photographer%comma% writer and artist who moved to Oregon in 1971%comma% settling in communes and eventually co-founding Rootworks%comma% a lesbian land in Southern Oregon. Rootworks was home to the Ovular workshops%comma% which Ruth and Tee Corinne%comma% another prominent lesbian photographer%comma% and others%comma% led. The workshops%comma% which ran for six years%comma% were an opportunity for women to learn photography in the context of the Women�s Movement%comma% providing a means for the women to examine the differences between the way men pictured women and the way the women saw themselves. The feminist photography magazine%comma% The Blatant Image%comma% sprang from the Ovular workshops. The Ruth Mountaingrove collection consists of correspondence%comma% diaries%comma% ephemera%comma% and photographs.
column10: Photograph from the Ruth Mountaingrove papers%comma% 1950-1999

column6: The University Archives Photograph Collection contains modern and vintage photographic prints related to the University of Oregon. The photographs depict a variety of buildings%comma% historic scenes%comma% events%comma% students%comma% faculty and staff%comma% and scenes of campus life.

column6: This digital collection focuses on the scrapbooks and yearbooks from the elementary%comma% junior high and high schools%comma% past and present%comma% of Orem%comma% Utah. Several of the schools-Spencer School%comma% Lincoln High School%comma% and Lincoln Junior High School-no longer exist. %newline%The schools included in this collection%comma% and the years of operation%comma% are:%newline%Spencer School%comma% 1883-1989%newline%Lincoln High School%comma% 1912-1921%newline%Lincoln Junior High School%comma% 1921-1975%newline%Orem High School%comma% 1956-%newline%Mountain View High School%comma% 1980-%newline%Timpanogos High School%comma% 1996-%newline%Orem Junior High School%comma% 1963-2010%newline%Lakeridge Junior High School%comma% 1975-%newline%Canyon View Junior High School%comma% 1985-1989%newline%The most recent yearbooks are subject to a five to seven year delay from the original publication date. Missing yearbooks from these schools as well as materials from additional schools may be added in the future as they become available.
